This masterpiece is the best Resident Evil game for ever. It's not the most scary like 7 or 2 but this is without a doubt the most fun and badass to play.

Main story: Good
Separate ways: Bad
The Mercenaries: Mixed
Replayable content: Extremely bad

About main story: Overall, it's been remade just right, and I have no complaints.

Separate ways: Both the story and difficulty leave me with mixed feelings. Especially the fact that Wesker comes to the location feels like a major disconnect.
Also, in terms of difficulty, unlike the main story, there's no armor or even a substitute for it (except for the cap as a clear bonus), so even the standard difficulty feels like HARDCORE level.

The Mercenaries: Fun, except for the "loading docks".

Replayable content: I'm quite dissatisfied. Particularly, the inconsistency of the parry system was extremely frustrating. Hearing the knife sound during a parry attempt only to actually get hit was infuriating. (It seems the parry sound occasionally plays even when you take damage, likely due to timing). This happened frequently, especially on PROFESSIONAL difficulty.
I also dislike elements like enemies only placed in PROFESSIONAL mode (especially towards the end of CHAPTER 12).
Furthermore, as mentioned earlier, damage output becomes a major issue in Separate Ways. I couldn't complete PROFESSIONAL S+ without stress.
As for the remaining The Mercenaries mode, the final stage, LOADING DOCKS, completely saps my motivation to get S++ with all characters. Chaos is enough with MODs...

Many of my hours in game are simply leaving it open. This game represents everything wrong with modern day shooters being slow-brained garbage. Everything wrong with it:

- Graphics are atrocious. Absolutely everything is grey and lifeless. Why is this a thing? It's getting tired
- Obligatory low FOV because that's standard nowadays. "Hurr durr that thing that restricts your field of view below natural eye levels and makes players nauseous - we're going to keep doing it"
- Takes five seconds to reload - the entire challenge of the game is not really ability but willingness to tolerate all the artificial challenges (low accuracy weapons, long reloads, low ammo, awkward player movement)
- Every vase you break involves a 1-2 second long animation (lol)
- Other unskippable cut-scenes/animations (should NEVER be a thing)
- Enemies sometimes have five (or more) second long dying animations wherein you can't tell if they're still alive or where you simply have to wait all that time to pick up the drops
- Can't strafe
- Can't jump
- Reload doesn't work unless you wait until Leon finishes doing everything completely (like switching the weapon, etc) - every single thing in the game is designed to make you wait and prevent you from playing fast
- Doesn't respect Steam binds - you hit Shift+Tab to bring up the Overlay, and the game brings up the inventory or Photo Mode every single time - then the game doesn't respect Windows keys - you press Esc to exit Photo Mode or what-have-you and it doesn't work. Nope; the one key that's been used to exit menus and things for decades on Windows machines won't work here!
- Can't unload weapons - if a gun is loaded with ammo, the ammo can't be used in another gun which uses the same type
- Can't mute the NPC's constant nonsensical chatter despite the dialogue being muted - chatter can be extremely annoying and loud though adjacent walls and things
- Can't craft while attempting to pick up an item - you have to, of course, given the game, exit your inventory, re-enter, craft, exit, re-pickup the item. lol. Once again, EVERYTHING in this game is designed to make you click and navigate as much as possible and artificially engage you

Was a remake of RE4 necessary? No, but they did an amazing job with it. You should get RE4 Remake as well as the original. Both games are distinct enough to provide different experiences while Remake is still faithful to the original where it counts.

The story is less campy than the original but still has its over the top moments.

The combat is extremely addictive and there's tones of variety and different strategies that will make multiple replays worth while.

The length feels right. It's definitely longer than RE2 and comparable to the original RE4. If you complete the extra objectives on hardcore, you can expect at least 30 hours for your first playthrough. Like the original, this game is meant to be played through more than once, as evidenced by some weapons and accessories only being available for subsequent playthroughs.

Contender for the best (Action) Resident Evil of all time, for sure.

Gameplay was remixed, refined and redefined to a degree I never would've thought possible for the original RE4. The amount of depth, replayability and skill expression is off the charts for a singleplayer horror game.

The unique art style of the original is lost, but in its place is something much more familiar to fans of the newer RE games. The story attempts to recontextualize the characters and events as being ultra-serious, and mostly does a mediocre job at it. Pretty much any changes relating to the characters and story were disappointments, but they didn't ruin the experience.

The general combat leans more into the Survival-Horror aspects of the series. Staple elements of the original game's design such as staggering enemies with a single headshot are now based on RNG and your weapon of choice, enemies will often drop crafting resources, forcing you to craft the ammo you want instead of being forced to use what the game gives you. Ashley is no longer stuck standing still or glued to your back, instead behaving mostly independent of you, which creates a lot of frustration as she is relegated to being incapacitated in one hit, and killed in a second hit instead of having her own manageable health bar as in the original.

This game, was so fun for me I played the Main History around 4 times plus Separate Ways. It has a great re-playability value. It let me remember the original many times and it was really entertaining to see the changes they made from the original, and there was more cohesion in some part of the original plot. The style and feeling was really good, some aspects were different from the original of course, but others remembered me to that version. I do recommend this version to players that have played the original and people who hasn't.

[h1] 9/10 [/h1]

[h2] PROS: [/h2]
[b] + Visual Design [/b]
Astonishing graphics as usual from RE Engine. Very detailed, amazing lighting.

[b] + Atmosphere [/b]
Even though the game is more of an action game than a survival horror, it still succeeds in creating a tense atmosphere.

[b] + Audio Design [/b]
Typical strong Resident Evil audio design to set up an appropriate atmosphere.

[b] + Combat Mechanics [/b]
Stealth kills and a parry mechanic are introduced.

[b] + Characters [/b]
Intriguing character interactions.

[b] + Inventory/Merchant [/b]
The inventory management, weapon customizations, crafting and an anticipation for new Merchant's shops feel all great.

[b] + Exploration/Puzzles [/b]
Enough treasures to feel that the exploration is worth it.
Decent puzzles requiring significant brain usage.

[h2] CONS: [/h2]
[b] - Repetitive Encounters [/b]
In the last third of the game I felt burnt out from the sheer amount of enemy encounters you have to deal with. At least it got a bit better near the end thanks to some circumstances and a new enemy type, that is sadly very easily killable once you figure it out.

[b] - No Fear [/b]
The game being more action packed comes at the cost of not inducing the high levels of fear in the player.

[b] - Some Boss Fights [/b]
Several boss fights could have been definitely more creative.

Coming to this game for the first time in 2025 is a bit weird. Technically it is a bit outdated (and I do not mean graphics, just the overall gameplay, movement, combat etc.). It also isn't very horror-y, more like a whack-em 3rd person action shooter. Enemies are more or less the same throughout the game even though their skins develop. The puzzles are relatively easy and not very elaborate.
I didn't hate it at all but I will probably not be coming back. 

A big plus, compared to RE2, is that playing for Leon vs Ada is really completely different experience and you're not feeling like you're replaying the same thing all over.

I first played Resident Evil 4 when I was 11 or 12, and because of the dark atmosphere, I never got past the second level.
Now, almost 15 years later, I wanted to give it another go, and damn, this game is good. The characters and atmosphere are really captivating, and you never notice that this game is actually over 20 years old. This also shows what a good remake this is.

Overall, it's a timeless classic must-play for every horror fan, which also shows that gameplay mechanics for games have stagnated over the last 20 years.

The only point I might criticise is the fact that the craziness of the boss designs and the sense of supernatural abilities or movements in some of the cutscenes for the individual main characters make it clear that this is a Japanese game, and this sense of flawlessness means that some of the enemies can no longer be taken seriously.

Resident Evil 4 was my first in the series, I wasn't really sure what to expect as I don't usually play horror games so it was definitely an experience, I was a bit hesitant to try but I had a friend slightly convince me to get it. They ended up watching me play the entire game. 
While the game wasn't as scary as I thought it'd be It was definitely a lot more enjoyable with someone watching me play it lol.

The game was really enjoyable, the gameplay which was a bit frustrating and annoying at times but most of the time it felt fun and engaging. you never felt like you could thrive and you had just enough to barely get by. 

The story itself was really good too, I loved how its basically one huge map with everything kinda connected to each other.  Leon is really such a lovable character, I love how he is corny and kinda silly sometimes but he also tries to do the right thing even if its not easy and he really cares for [spoiler] Ashley :) [/spoiler] they were really cute together. 

I did really enjoy the game and I am kinda interested in playing other Resident evil games, I at least want to play the other games that Leon is in.


One thing that I did find kinda rough was all those bear traps lol, i dont know who was laying them but I managed to step on every single one of them.

I am here from the original Resident Evil 4 crowd, which I played on the Gamecube religiously - so I cannot say how it will be for new players that never played it. But I think it should be good.

First off I want to say this is exactly how remake should be done. The graphics are excellent, the use of contrast, lighting and shadows provides a constant moody, cinematic feel throughout as does the close-following over-the-shoulder camera. It looks fantastic. But it isn't a remaster like so many developers are cashing in on (because like fuck working for money), it is a full on re-imagining of the game. It's not just quality of life improvements like better controls and character physics, the game has been completely redesigned by today's standards. 

The action is fast paced and requires a lot of finesse. The game encourages you to be constantly moving and very aggressive (like Doom), if you stand in one spot too long or go for defence, you will be taking a one way train to fuck-town. If your hands sweat easily, like mine, then bring some tissues.

The controls feel great. I used keyboard and mouse - I increased camera sensitivity for looking (but not for aiming) so that I can turn the camera quickly without lifting the mouse. I can see what they did with the default control scheme: Q for Quickturn, E for Evade, M for Map, P for Pause - but those latter to are completely unergonomic - M and P are not reachable - remap those to something else. It also uses CTRL for commanding Ashley, again this is really awkward, especially when you use the same key for catching ammo from Luis - but I found remapping to C was perfect for this and doesn't interfere with other defaults. 

The attache case now has auto sorting which really makes it much simpler, but keeps the joy that you can't become overpowered, you gotta pack the right gear and can't get greedy with ammo and healing items. There is a wide assortment of gear keeping the game interesting and encouraging multiple playthroughs as the items are designed to be unique, truly offering a different style of play (unlike the games that give you too many options, but they are all minor stat differences: AABA, ABAA, BAAA etc). There are challenges to complete and new items to unlock. Then there are some new additions such as charms which also tweak certain variables a little, like getting more ammo of a certain type from crafting, selling certain items for more - these are totally optional and add a nice flavour from the old shooting range (which too has been overhauled and improved). 

My main criticism is that enemies do seem to be able to spawn on you or in areas you have just been and were empty. This is discussed - but I am not being paranoid, I had this happen in the Village house when you're with Luis at points where no entry was possible - enemies skipping the ladder and just appearing in a corner choking you. I know they are trying to keep the aggro and intensity up, but I don't like cheap shots. I don't mind enemies spawning in from outside of your accessible environment then walking in and I prefer to have the chance to react first than just getting jumped and choked. 

But overall, the goods far outweigh the negatives in this title, and I am glad I was able to play it. This should have set a standard for how to remake a beloved classic - Looking at you Metal Gear Solid 3, still the same 20 year old game with new graphics. Well I just won't buy those, only excellence drives my purchases, and this is it.

The Resident Evil 4 Remake is honestly one of the best modern remakes I‚Äôve played. The game captures the original‚Äôs atmosphere while upgrading everything to feel fresh and intense. The graphics are incredible‚Äîevery environment feels alive, darker, and more detailed, making the horror hit harder. The updated controls and combat are smooth and satisfying, especially the knife mechanics and the improved aiming.

I also really liked how they expanded Leon and Ashley‚Äôs interactions. It feels more grounded and emotional without losing the charm of the classic. Some sections were changed, but in a good way‚Äîthey added new moments that fit perfectly with the story.

Overall, it‚Äôs a remake that respects the original while improving almost every part of it. Totally worth playing, and definitely one of the strongest survival-horror experiences today.

10/10 horror

[h2] A game I've been hyped to play on my new PC [/h2] 

It's a shame I've tried and tried, but this remake still doesn't convince me. I've completed the game twice; once on Normal difficulty and once on Expert difficulty, but in the end, I was left with nothing. Maybe it's because I've played the original game for so many years, and it feels familiar. I'd also add that I felt like I was playing a Resident Evil that wasn't Resident Evil (hard to explain).

[b] Parrying chainsaws? [/b] 
It's hilarious. The original game wasn't like that. At most, you could shoot crossbow bolts, which was pretty cool for the time. But all that you do with Leon's knife and the knives you find lying around. You also parry incoming axes, or even slashes from sickles and machetes when the ganads are very close. There's this damned parrying mechanic, which many games in recent years seem to have become obsessed with. But that's the way video games are these days, and if developers don't include the parrying mechanic, they're not happy.

[b] "Remake" [/b] 
4K, 1080p? Ultra Textures? Graphically, it's very nice, yes, but it's not as exceptional as it seems. In fact, there are some textures on doors and walls that are low-resolution, even when playing at high graphics settings. In terms of lighting and effects, it's also not great, and if you look closely, you can spot the flaws. Like my Leon's face and the low-resolution 2D fire sprites. However, in my first playthrough, I played with AMD Fidelity on Quality mode, while in the second I decided to play without any graphics optimizations. In the end, not much changed. At least I found it well-optimized and never experienced any frame drops even without AMD Fidelity.

[b] Changes in characters, personalities, songs & world [/b]
For a remake, it's primarily a freedom of reinterpretation. There are some characters who, compared to the original version, are anything but themselves. I'm not just referring to their changed appearance, but also, specifically, their personalities. Ashley comes to mind, who was criticized by some for being completely revamped. This new Ashley isn't really Ashley. Ashley was known for being a pain in the ass, and rightfully so. But Capcom listened and took the opportunity to choose a beautiful girl with a confident, non-annoying personality (too perfect). Or different event choices; where Luis Sera [spoiler] dies from a completely random stab from Krauser, whereas in the original game he dies from Saddler's sting [/spoiler]. Let's talk about the game's songs. Serenity was really beautiful in the original version, but she's been completely changed. She's no longer Serenity, but something else now. It always bothered me to save the game and listen to this new version. [u] The only positive things are [/u] that they've at least expanded some areas that weren't there before and added new puzzles. The merchant with this new quest system is nice and gives you rewards. I probably enjoyed Separate Ways more than the base game [spoiler] (although Capcom even went to the trouble of including Ada's random infection in the story).[/spoiler]

[b] Cut Contents in Dialogue [/b]
Capcom has managed to remove and replace 
[strike] "No Thanks, Bro!" [/strike] in the first encounter with Salazar and [strike] "Women" [/strike] after he's accompanied by Ada to the island. It's probably part of those famous changes. But I think it wasn't necessary. At least they left the Bingo joke in.

[b] Too many useless mini-DLCs [/b]
It disgusted me to see how much useless stuff there is in the Steam Store. Costumes, weapons, weapon mod vouchers, maps, expandable cases, suitcase charms and WTF. And the worst part is that people buy them. In my day, these things were unlocked by finishing the game. It's also absurd to immediately buy charms to make dead enemies drop health, money, and ammo. Otherwise, you can always go to the shooting range and hope for the right charm with tokens (but you're not guaranteed to be lucky).

[u] In conclusion [/u]
This remake is truly soulless. I'll continue to prefer the 2005 original on PS2 (which I proudly own in physical form) and the HD collection on PC, which I have 100% of all the achievements.

[b] PS:  [/b] In the end, tastes are tastes. I didn't say it was crap. I just said I didn't like it as a remake. The only remakes I liked were Resident Evil 2 Remake and Resident Evil 3 Remake (even though everyone hated the latter).

Resident Evil 4 pleasantly surprised me. The new combat system is more complex and fun than in RE2/3, with constantly changing mechanics that keep gameplay fresh. The graphics and sound design are solid, and the merchant/shop adds extra variety. You have to handle a 1v?? shootout in a crowded village where a sprinting chainsaw who is wearing a hooded muscleman eventually shows up. That's the base level of skill needed to deal with the next major areas in the game. At first I thought this was a really hard task, but after a few tries I cleared this first area easily, the control scheme and how movement works while sprinting, walking, and aiming, took some getting used to. I also had a hard time understanding which methods you're supposed to be using in a fight, there's a lot of cool tools and abilities and I didn't know if I was even playing correctly. After a few hours I got very good at the game and the most important thing is what you learn next.

He is an un-killable chainsaw wearing a man, but actually if you shoot the man enough, he will die. I didn't try shooting the chainsaw that much on account of the fact that I love chainsaws. Everything dies if you attack it enough, but enemies have areas you can hit to stall them and land some combos. Your ability to aim at heads, arms, legs, and the weapon the enemy has is important, and each do different things. If it's a non-humanoid, you need to come up with ways to deal with their unique weak points. No matter what it is, when you stun an enemy you usually always have the option to do a melee finisher that sends them into more stun for you to shoot them or it kills them. This game is mostly controlling distance, the area between you and an enemy. Each weapon specializes in different distances, once you learn these you can handle many threats. A problem for you to overcome is you earn different weapons over a fair period of time and you need to have ammo for your weapons, sometimes you may be fighting at a disadvantage, but pushing through it and winning those battles feels amazing, and earning more powerful weapons for the harder ones is awesome.

The 90's action movie plus eldritch horror monster residenciness of this game is amazing, and the progression between settings that look like they are from different games yet somehow all exist in this one will wow you. The characters are honest, straightforward, and feel incredibly capable of doing the things they are doing. I highly recommend it, and if you love it get the Seperate Ways DLC which takes place from Ada's perspective. The Mercenaries mode is an Arcade Shooter variant of the game's general game loop which is fun for a while, the game suggests you complete the game before trying it and this is because it makes use of all your skill progression up until near the end of the game.

I love this game! I am going to watch videos of the OG Resident Evil 4 to see the differences and similarities between the two games, and why the original has such a positive reputation. I'm sure it'll charm me, although I think this game was enough for me to understand the experience RE4 was conveying during a different gaming generation.

‚ÄúA Field Trip Through Chaos, Parasites, and One Extremely Supportive Arms Dealer‚Äù

Resident Evil 4 is the only game where you can politely walk into a remote European village and immediately get greeted with:
‚ÄúHello! We‚Äôd like to kill you with farm equipment!‚Äù
Five stars. Authentic cultural experience.

The remake looks incredible. Almost too incredible. Every time a Ganado sprints at me with that fast-walk-your-grandma-does-when-she‚Äôs-angry energy, I genuinely feel like I need to file a complaint with someone. Possibly HR. Possibly a priest.

Combat is a beautiful disaster. You‚Äôre constantly choosing between reloading, running, screaming, or all three at once. Every time I miss a headshot, I can hear the developers giggling somewhere. Knifing enemies feels amazing though‚Äîlike slapping chaos back into order with nothing but spite and steel.

Ashley is actually competent now, which is great, but she also has the gravitational pull of a missing-person poster. Everyone wants to kidnap her. Everyone. I escort her for five minutes and suddenly she‚Äôs gone again like a cat that heard a plastic bag crinkle in another room.

The environments are a mix of ‚Äúwow, what stunning architecture‚Äù and ‚Äúwow, what a suspicious number of murder holes.‚Äù Every hallway feels like it was designed by someone whose favorite hobby is ‚Äúwatching tourists suffer.‚Äù Barrels explode. Floors collapse. Ceilings drop spiky things. Even the fish in the lake are mad at you.

And then‚Ä¶
The Merchant.
A man. A myth. A walking Craigslist ad with eldritch teleportation powers.

This guy shows up EVERYWHERE. I once turned a corner after barely surviving a mob, and there he was like:

‚ÄúStranger‚Ä¶ you look like you‚Äôve been mauled by God Himself. Wanna buy a rocket launcher?‚Äù

He is your emotional support weapons dealer.

He stands in caves, castles, swamps, air vents, probably the afterlife‚Äîjust waiting, watching, plotting inventory expansions. I‚Äôm 90% sure the Ganados don‚Äôt attack him because they think he‚Äôs some kind of forest deity who sells guns and vibes.

He never explains how he travels. He never explains why he likes you. He never explains what‚Äôs under that mask. Honestly? I don‚Äôt want the answers. I want the mystery. I want the romance of being hunted by parasites but supported by a man whose pockets contain seventeen firearms and one singular, precious ‚ÄúHREEHH-HREEHH-HREEHH‚Äù laugh.

The Merchant‚Äôs shop is the only place in the entire game where I feel like my blood pressure drops below ‚Äúvolcano.‚Äù For 30 blissful seconds, it‚Äôs just me, my attach√© case, and the knowledge that I‚Äôm bad at spatial organization despite having two hands and a brain.

If he ever stops appearing, Leon will break down emotionally, and so will I.

The story is a perfect roller coaster: dramatic, horrifying, absurd, and sprinkled with enough Leon Kennedy sarcasm to clean up an oil spill. Every chapter ends with me asking myself, ‚ÄúWhy am I still here?‚Äù followed immediately by, ‚ÄúOne more.‚Äù

"Ello, Strangah!"

RE4R is the finale in the initial run of the REmake trilogy, just like my other reviews I'll try to be quick and snappy with how this game improves over the original and how they kept good faith with the community after the confusing predicament they had with RE3. 

Likes:
-RE4R's color palette marks an end to the iconic, albeit kinda jarring brown and dark light filters and color palettes that gave the original its atmosphere. But I think it was an improvement to mark this as a full on remake, the game is inherently the same in terms of plot, enemies, and general mechanics. This works in the games favor overall I think and keeps the atmosphere of all the remakes to keep an aura of consistency with the new narrative while also paying tribute to the original titles. 

-God damn do the guns feel good in this game, every bullet fired from a variety of the guns carries weight and feels powerful to account for how many enemies Leon and Ada face across the village, castle, and island. This was really important to nail, considering you spend most of the game in combat and ammo is scarce, but with the crafting system, you could always be somewhat prepared for an encounter before it happens. I think how the remake handled the case and the crafting system is also very strong by allowing a lot more customization to your loadout as well as the charms handing out boons with small buffs to aid Leon and Ada‚Äôs journey to Saddler. 

-Enemy variety is very strong in this game compared to 2 and subsequently 3, while 3 had a lot of different enemy types, the way that each of them were engaged was nothing short of ‚Äúpump it full of lead till it dies.‚Äù But in 4 there has to be an active focus with each enemy whether it‚Äôs a basic Ganado or a juiced up Regenarador ready to pump you full of needles, I still saw myself thinking about the tools in my kit and how to use them. Stingray my absolute beloved, you saved me from so many of those lanky regenerating sacks of meat. This was a highlight in 2 as well, but to a lesser degree, but for how active combat is in this game, it shines really well. 

-The story while essentially a retelling, this game breathed life into Ashley that she sorely needed from the original. While the sections with her are certainly the same level of stress as the original, when gameplay is handed over to her, she‚Äôs a very capable secondary protagonist. I think this works really well in the games favor and makes her feel more like a partner and less an asset you need to drag around and hold you back. And when you take down saddler, I felt even better that all of Leon, Ada, and Ashley‚Äôs work all paid off. 

-Seperate ways was a very strong DLC that told Ada‚Äôs side of the story, I was not expecting iy to pay attention to detail as much as it did, as well as, the length being more than I bargained for. I think this DLC does a really good job of characterizing the REmake Ada into a woman who is confused and wrestles with her own emotions while essentially helping blonde Satan. I‚Äôm very happy to see how she‚Äôs characterized this way, as I believe the original almost left us with too little characterization of why Ada functions the way she does. 

-The merchant. Need I say anything else? THEY GAVE US MORE, I CAN‚ÄôT EXPLAIN IT ANY BETTER, JUST MORE OF HIM AND ITS GREAT!


Dislike:
-The game is a wee bit long for me but that‚Äôs a personal gripe. 

-The economy in this game is pretty saturated with a large bag of goodies, but I think the fact that we find so many weapons as the characters journey across Saddlers expansive settlement, that I kinda lost the fear midway through. I saw myself strategizing more often instead of actually paying attention to the horrors in front of me, this is a bad thing in my opinion considering that the original reason why RE almost died was it lost the horror. I don‚Äôt mind action horror, but the horror needs to be there past BOWs and heavily mutated Ganados, Capcom please, with RE5 and 6, don‚Äôt go back to action. 

-While all of the boss fights played out relatively cleanly and well paced, the sheer number of boss fights in this game contributed to a lot of the length. Again, this might just be a me thing considering I associate RE with selective choices of boss fights in style, I felt similar to 3, this game was setting up set pieces and less trying to show me the horror of it all. It‚Äôs not wrong to make me feel like a badass, but the horror got diluted as a result. 

Overall, RE4R is a clean, crisp, and fun action horror game that stands the test of time with the original. From seeing the priest in the village to fighting a demigod of a man known as Saddler, Leon, Ashley, and Ada shined in this game as characters. I praise the game for its bizarre nature and fun mechanics. I feel like towards the end, it crashes and burns trying to set up set pieces rather than giving me the emotion, fear, and dread that previous entries provided. 

Gonna give it a crisp 8.5/10, I might platinum this one if an apocalypse happens, but it‚Äôs a journey and a half.

I have to give the biggest praise to the new knife parry system. It completely changes the flow of combat and feels incredibly satisfying. The atmosphere, graphics, and sound are 10/10. Genuinely terrifying and immersive. And most importantly: they fixed Ashley! In this remake, she is AWESOME. She's not a burden at all, but a competent partner, and I actually like her character now.

BUT, there is a but, and this is important for those of you playing on PC.

TECHNICAL WARNING:
This game has a pretty severe CPU bottleneck problem. Even my high-end rig still gets annoying stutters. Also, the default image quality (TAA/FSR2) is bad, in my opinion. It causes a lot of shimmering artifacts everywhere and the picture just looks soft/blurry.

IMPORTANT ADVICE:
As soon as you start the game, immediately TURN OFF 'Hair Strands' and 'Ray Tracing'. These two settings are completely unoptimized. They tank your FPS for almost zero visual gain.
Highly recommended, but I really hope these PC technical issues get fixed soon.

.....What else can I say what hasn't already been said?

This is Resident Evil 4. 

A remake of one of the best, most influential games of all time. Without the original RE4, we wouldn't have Gears of War, Mass Effect, Uncharted, Dead Space along with so many other third person shooters.
I would argue that the original RE4 was nearly as influential as the original Doom games were,

The original RE4 was a legendary game without a shadow of a doubt, even with the tank controls it was known for which gave it a very distinctive and recognizable feel whenever you played it.

Does RE4R bring the magic of the original RE4 to the modern age? Yes, it absolutely does in my opinion. With a few caveats.

First of all, Resident Evil's gameplay has never been better in RE4R. I'm serious. The gameplay is as close to perfect as it needed to be, even though it got rid of the tank controls (and most quick time events) of the original RE4. So, that distinctive feel of original RE4 really isn't there anymore, it feels much more contemporary here. Plays more like a hastened Resident Evil 2. However, the act of gunning down a couple ganados, running from a chainsaw guy, being cornered and gorily blowing the chainsaw guy away (along with 5+ other ganados) with a blast or two of your trusty pump-action shotgun has never felt better. The gore is outstanding too. You can sever enemies clean in half with a single trigger pull of a shotgun or a magnum revolver or a grenade. You can shoot ganado's arms off in order to prevent them from swinging their axes at you. There is so much strategy to think about while you are deep in the fray with dwindling ammunition reserves. You need to make every shot count, use every bullet to it's maximum potential. Line up your rifle shots and blow apart 5+ enemy heads in a row. Take aim and fire at the red barrels while here are enemies crowding around it. Parry an onslaught of enemy attacks and roundhouse kick the nearest ganado off the nearest cliffside. Shoot lanterns as ganados walk underneath them. Shoot a ganado's hand holding a molotov or a stick of dynamite and make it blow up in their face. So many options to use mid combat. So many ways to have fun. RE4R feels less like a horror game and more like an late 90s action movie with a horror theme. It's fantastic. Honestly in my top 10 combat systems of all time. Maybe top 5 even. 

Oh, and the environments are incredibly strong as well. Not nearly as good as RE Village's environments but they are still very well done.

The only issue that I have with the gameplay is the weapon bloom. In original RE4, weapons were literally pin point accurate. Even the SMGs. The shotguns are the only weapons in the original RE4 that weren't highly accurate from what I remember. RE4R does away with this and gives every single gun weapon bloom whenever you shoot them, making you miss more shots the more you pull the trigger. 
I fully emphasize that the gunplay feels INCREDIBLE during the main campaign and Separate Ways, but it does get frustrating when you are trying to do the pirate themed shooting gallery that the merchant sometimes hosts during your spooky adventure. Most of the weapons have their own little shooting gallery for you to practice in, and for your reward, you get these gold or silver coins for you to buy charms with. The higher the score and the more targets you hit in the lowet amount of time, th emore of these coins you will get. These shooting gallery sections feel excellent in the original RE4 because every weapon didn't have weapon bloom. You can unload your SMG as often as you want and it would hit the mark every single time. In RE4R's shooting galleries, in order for you to fully complete one, you have to specifically target these skull weakpoints placed on the pirate targets. The weapon bloom in RE4R makes this feel really diffficult to do so, especially during the shooting galleries that have you using an SMG. Instead of specifically targeting a skull with the SMG like in OG RE4, you are mostly just tapping the fire button and HOPING you don't get completely screwed over by weapon bloom in RE4R. Gets incredibly annoying. You won't think about this very much until you really start trying to 100% the shooting galleries.

Another thing that annoyed me in RE4R is the UI design and atmosphere. The UI design itself is fine, great even, the problem is the aesthetics. It looks way, WAY too clean. The grimy but interesting UI design of OG RE4 is gone in favor of something more contemporary and not as unique. The sections in OG RE4 where Leon is speaking with Hunnigan (and all of the other characters) through comms? Those are gone in RE4, all being expressed through a small video in the lower half of the screen whenever it does happen. 
The OG RE4 also has a very dense, intense, dreamy atmosphere to it, almost Silent Hill esque. Slightly foggy environment and film grain. Very gritty. RE4R doesn't have that which does disappoint me. Environments are too clear. RE4R's music isn't nearly as strong as og RE4's as well. Serenity is gone entirely. :(

One more thing I should talk about is the characterization and voice acting. RE4R adds a LOT to Leon, Ashley and Luis. Leon is no longer a corny sarcastic joker, he's now suffering from PTSD (from RE2's events) and uses humor to keep himself sane. Ashley is no longer just an annoying NPC you escort, she actually develops a relationship with Leon as the events of the game play out. Luis is no longer a spanish womanizer, he actually has a really good reason to be part of the story now. So, RE4R does great charecterization for the protagonists, at the cost of the villains. Saddler is no longer interesting as he was before, he's just a big bad villain with no nuance anymore. It's a 1 step forward, 1 step backward kind of deal.

And now, the voice acting. It's generally great. It's several steps ahead of OG RE4. Until you listen to Ada. And, look, she has never looked better in Resident Evil games prior. Visually, she is at her best in RE4R. ....But then you listen to her voice. Her voice acting is terrible, like a wine mom is recording her lines in the closet. Practically Ride to Hell Retribution levels of bad voice acting. On top of that, her lines from the original RE4 have been rewritten. So, as an example, Ada no longer says "I don't kiss and tell" towards Leon, she says "I don't work and tell", which makes the voice acting feel even more grating. And then you have an entire separate campaign with her as the main protagonist? I mean, Separate Ways was fantastic, but MY GOD Ada's voice acting is atrocious. 6 hours of constant "work and tell" dialogue. Bring back Jolene Andersen, Capcom. Jolene did a fantastic job as Ada in Resident Evil 2 and you decided it would be best to replace her? You almost had the perfect Ada. Yikes. Brilliant decision making there, Capcom. Almost as brilliant as the time you rushed out Dragon's Dogma 2 like 2 years too early..

To wrap things up, I thought RE4R was one of the best games I've ever played. It's nearly perfect from a gameplay perspective and gives a lot of much needed improvements even though it doesn't stay close enough to the original RE4 as I would like.

You will have a fantastic time with it. 

And, please, greet those Regeneradors with a magnum round to the dome for me. I don't care if 'it's a waste of ammunition', they deserve it.

Goodness gracious. I really, really want RE5 and RE6 remakes. 

Get working on those, Capcom. I want to punch boulders in 4k ASAP. 10/10

In order to understand what went fundamentally wrong with RE4make we should first briefly revisit what defined the original and what it‚Äôs remembered and still played for.

The original back in 2005 was revolutionary - it established the third person shooter genre and redefined the survival horror one. It placed a particular emphasis on combat, with an integral part of that being tactical and responsive gunplay. Every weapon had an identity and shooting any part of an enemy came with distinct advantages - whether slowing them down, disarming them or blowing up lit dynamite, taking out their allies in the process. Loot and ammo dropping from every enemy and even crows and chicken encouraged you - for the very first time in Resident Evil franchise - to engage with combat mechanics instead of avoiding combat to conserve ammunition, as it was customary for the classic games.

Meanwhile RE4make reuses the combat system from the remake of Resident Evil 2. The slow and methodical gunplay that makes you wait for the reticle to close after every shot; the punishing spread and recoil that discourages firing a submachine gun other than in short bursts; the bullet-spongy enemies that barely even flinch and make it feel like your guns are shooting blanks; the comically overpowered yet ever-breaking knives leaving you defenceless - all that worked well in RE2, portraying the character as vulnerable and presenting even a single zombie as a real threat, encouraging the player to avoid combat rather than engage in it.

Needless to say, it doesn‚Äôt work here. As a result, the remake plays like RE2 with decorations from RE4. This weird mixture of different concepts creates a game that doesn‚Äôt know what it wants from you - to engage in inconsistent, unfair and unfun combat with little room for tactical gunplay, the enemies that will stunlock you while attacking relentlessly and a knife that‚Äôs better than a rocket launcher; or to remove your gear and force you to make use of its new feature, the stealth mechanics. The latter is an afterthought that achieves nothing other than to break the pacing of the game and take away from its combat focus. The 2005 revolution has not been improved upon, but instead was treated as if never happened. The laser sight - arguably one of the original‚Äôs most notable additions to combat - while technically still present as a side quest reward you need to grind for, can now only be attached to a couple of weaker pistols.

As far as the story and atmosphere are concerned, the original is best characterized as an unpretentious B-movie. It was full of cheesy one-liners, silly dialogues and goofy fan service ‚Äúfeatures‚Äù, like looking up Ashley‚Äôs skirt. The game was very self-aware and did everything to prevent you from treating itself too seriously. It did not really try to be a horror either - acknowledging the fact that when a game gives you a machine gun, the only thing you can be scared of is running out of ammo. As a whole, it all worked well to give the original its unique vibe and identity.

The remake, however, goes out of its way to present itself as dead serious. The surroundings and ambience try their best to create a dark, ominous atmosphere. Unnecessary and excessive even by RE standards graphical violence in your face including mutilated corpses and elaborate death animations as well as an annoying mandatory horror segment make it feel like a love letter to Village instead of the original. There‚Äôs no longer much room for based light-hearted comedy in this new game, and drastic changes to characters and dialogues are emblematic of that. The feminine ‚Äúdamsel in distress‚Äù Ashley is gone - replaced by a cringe ‚Äústrong and independent‚Äù Ashley instead. The president did not equip his daughter with ballistics this time round, while a modern take on Ashley‚Äôs lingerie with 4k textures, ray tracing, DLSS and HDR is obviously out of discussion. She now calls herself ‚Äúmaster of unlocking‚Äù, no longer offers Leon ‚Äúovertime‚Äù and (following in RE3make‚Äôs footsteps) wears an ugly skort. Ada‚Äôs red dress was likewise taken away from her in favour of a sweater. Hunnigan is now overly professional rather than casual and flirty. And Leon is now suffering from PTSD one minute and spitting one-liners the next one - unsure of his role in this brave new world. Of course, they did not stop at the tone and character design: the game no longer features many dialogues, a number of areas, weapons and bosses, nor any of the additional content RE4 used to have.

As a result, in RE4make the overly serious vibe strangely coexists with the few remaining one-liners and ridiculous enemies like a giant fish. It comes across as a game ‚Äúgone woke‚Äù and somehow manages to be even less faithful to the original than the remake of RE3 - which, to be fair, at least preserved the tone and spirit of its namesake. The things that made the original so fun are just not here anymore, being ‚Äúreimagined‚Äù, censored or sterilized. In fact, RE4make feels like a completely different game that just so happens to share a bunch of names with the original.

Is this different game at least great as far as modern games are concerned? Unfortunately, this is not the case either. There is nothing here that would bring novelty to the genre or, indeed, even justify the existence of this remake. The only additions to the usual formula are side quests (boring busywork tasks with little variety like ‚Äúkill 3 rats‚Äù and ‚Äúshoot 6 medallions‚Äù) and lootboxes giving you rare and epic charms to boost your stats. The unsatisfying and inconsistent gunplay does not belong here and is not fit for purpose. Continuing the trend set by RE3make level design is full of cramped, claustrophobic corridors as if created to work around PS1-era hardware limitations. The voice acting is sad and uninspired, oftentimes missing its ‚Äúacting‚Äù part. The level of self-plagiarism here is staggering, evident of creative stagnation in the absence of great minds like Shinji Mikami: if you played RE2 Remake or Village (ironically, itself a derivative of RE4) - you pretty much played this one as well.

Of course, a review should not only be concerned with the question of how good the game is, but also how good it is for the asking price. And I see two problems here. First of all, it‚Äôs priced $60 - higher than any of Capcom‚Äôs previous remakes. And frankly, it‚Äôs a big ask considering there‚Äôs no additional content. The second, arguably even bigger issue is the nonexistent regional pricing. For example, as a Ukrainian gamer as of time of this review I can get Cyberpunk for $25, and Hogwarts Legacy for mere $20. Meanwhile Capcom expected me to pay some $55 - about full price.

I‚Äôd also like to mention what I can only describe as aggressive monetization. You see, the progression once again follows the RE3R formula - the higher levels of difficulty are simply brutal and are envisioned to be tackled not as much with skill but rather overpowered weaponry from previous runs (Professional is clearly balanced around infinite rocket launcher). Preorder bonus trinkets actually give you gameplay advantages like more gold and ammo crafted, effectively making Hardcore difficulty not-so-hardcore. Meanwhile Deluxe Edition adds treasures that simply don‚Äôt exist in the game otherwise as well as guns that are all-round better than those you can find in the beginning - and you can now even upgrade them! It all feels very pay-to-win in a singleplayer game. I imagine RE4make was designed as a cash cow and will get All Rewards Unlocked and many other DLC in the future.

TL;DR: RE2make and Village had a baby, allowed it to pick its gender and gave it a famous name just because. It is not another revolution for the genre - it‚Äôs merely a corridor shooter with yellow paint of handholding everywhere. Hard skip if you‚Äôre a fan of the original, grab on sale if you couldn‚Äôt get enough of Capcom‚Äôs recent games on RE Engine and wanted more of the same.

I absolutely loved this game from start to finish. The atmosphere is incredible ‚Äî dark, tense, and filled with that signature Resident Evil feeling that keeps you on edge the whole time. Every area feels carefully crafted, with amazing attention to detail that really pulls you into the world.

The graphics are stunning. Character models, especially the castle plagas and bosses, look fantastic ‚Äî grotesque and detailed in all the right ways. You can tell a lot of care went into updating the original while keeping the tone intact.

Gameplay-wise, the mechanics are smooth and modernized without losing that classic RE4 charm. Combat feels satisfying, weapons handle great, and the pacing keeps things exciting. The balance between action and survival horror is just right.

The story isn‚Äôt groundbreaking, but it‚Äôs engaging enough to keep you invested, and the performances help bring it to life.

Overall, Resident Evil 4 Remake is an amazing experience ‚Äî a perfect blend of nostalgia and modern design. If you love atmospheric horror and tight gameplay, this one‚Äôs a must-play.

After playing several Resident Evil games, I can honestly say this one truly deserves its reputation as the best in the series. What makes Resident Evil 4 stand out for me is how different it feels compared to something like Resident Evil 2. The story here is more straightforward ‚Äî you don‚Äôt need to constantly backtrack through old areas, which keeps the pacing exciting and smooth.

The bosses are absolutely amazing to fight, each appearing naturally as you progress, and every encounter feels satisfying. There‚Äôs a ton of action, and the combat system is easily the most enjoyable in the series ‚Äî fluid, intense, and rewarding.

I also loved that the puzzles are fewer, simpler, and can be solved right where you find them ‚Äî no need to run around the map just to complete one. The characters are great, and the DLC featuring Ada adds a really nice touch to her character and the overall story.

The upgrade system and the shop are fantastic additions too ‚Äî they make you feel stronger and really help you enjoy the gameplay even more.

All in all, Resident Evil 4 is a 10/10 action-horror experience with epic boss fights and an amazing flow from start to finish. I highly recommend it to any fan of the series or anyone who loves a great mix of tension, action, and fun.

best game i have played in a while.

This game is the diamond of the Resident Evil universe.
(I haven‚Äôt played RE7, RE8, or the original RE4 yet.)

We can definitely say Leon was in his prime here. And Ada? Dayummm, she is something else.

Story:

The story is really good, and the best part ‚Äî the game never feels slow.
The pacing is fast, engaging, and you never feel bored (at least I never did).
The way the DLC story runs parallel to the main story was a nice touch.
However, the DLC feels a bit rushed compared to the main campaign.

Combat:

Combat is next-level and a massive upgrade compared to RE2 and RE3.
Not only can you dodge, but now you can also counter and attack with style.
There‚Äôs even a stealth option and some wrestling moves.
My favorite has to be the [spoiler]knife combat ‚Äî parrying is so satisfying here, it almost feels like Sekiro.[/spoiler]
Absolutely loved it.

Enemies:

Enemies are very diverse ‚Äî [spoiler]from village mobs to castle freaks to island soldiers.[/spoiler]
My personal favorite is [spoiler]Chainsaw Guy[/spoiler] ‚Äî I just love parrying his attacks.
Bosses are cool and sometimes genuinely scary, especially that [spoiler]El Gigante.[/spoiler]
The fight with [spoiler]Krauser was absolutely epic, easily one of my favorites since it‚Äôs pure knife combat.[/spoiler]
The final fight was total chaos ‚Äî exactly what I was hoping for.

Characters:

Leon: The GOAT of Resident Evil, no doubt.

Ada: She‚Äôs mine. Leon can take Claire and continue the Redfield bloodline üòè

Ashley: Surprisingly great character ‚Äî someone you‚Äôd genuinely want to protect.

Luis: Have to say, [spoiler]his death made me a little emotional.[/spoiler] Amazing character.

Krauser:[spoiler]Nice villain, loved his fight.[/spoiler]

Wesker: [spoiler]He can only spare 7 minutes, lmao.[/spoiler]

Special Mentions:
[spoiler]The helicopter guy[/spoiler] ‚Äî absolute legend, saved me so many times on the island.||
And of course, the [spoiler]Merchant[/spoiler]‚Äî ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôre ya buyin‚Äô, stranger?‚Äù never gets old.

Overall:

This game is amazing and maybe my best Resident Evil experience so far.
I still have to play RE7 and RE8, but let‚Äôs see if they can top this one.

Fantastic remake of the original game. Not a 1:1 recreation, so it doesn't outright replace the original game, but all the new mechanics and redesigned rooms and fights flow together incredibly well. I really enjoyed the improved Ashley section, all the new enemies as well as the added side quests. Parrying took some getting used to but it's smooth and feels good to perform. Regenerators still make me shit my pants. Insanely replayable both because of how fun the game is to just sit down and play and because it has a lot of fun extra content, such as different challenge runs you can do that unlock different rewards or the expanded upon Mercenaries mode. Can be quite challenging on higher difficulties. As for the negatives despite loving it's DLC, Seperate Ways as well, I'm not huge on how certain parts of the game were cut in order to be resold as DLC and selling all the weapon upgrade tickets feels kinda scummy. Anyway, still a great game that's worth the money, especially since it goes on sale pretty regularly at this point. But even at full price there's a lot to love about this one.

Capcom faced significant pressure in reimagining what many consider to be the best game in the Resident Evil series. The previous installments, Resident Evil 7 and Village, received mixed reviews, and fans were disappointed with the Resident Evil 3 remake. As a result, Resident Evil 4 had big shoes to fill to impress both veterans and newcomers.

I originally played RE4 on my PS4 but completed a second run, along with the ‚ÄòSeparate Ways‚Äô DLC, on PC. Capcom nailed this remake with its fresh take on the story and advanced combat system.

While the story remained largely the same, there were a few rushed story beats; however, the characters retained their essence from the original. There has been some debate about whether the original characters were better, which I agree with, but I also enjoyed the new talent. This time around, I appreciated the latest portrayal of Ashley, who actively cheers on Leon in the shooting range, expresses her concerns about situations, and reacts to the action rather than just shouting ‚ÄúHelp!‚Äù Luis, in my opinion, stole the show. He was the best character adapted in this remake, especially with his ‚ÄòDon Quixote‚Äô references.

The new combat system in RE4 felt very smooth. Capcom‚Äôs improved AI forces players to adopt a run-and-gun approach rather than staying in one spot. It took me a while to adjust, but I understand that Capcom aimed to avoid the stiff playstyle of the previous game. The parry system was a nice addition, especially since enemies rush toward you. Stealth also plays a crucial role in certain situations, allowing players to conserve resources. However, the bosses were challenging and at times quite aggravating when trying to dodge their attacks.

So far, this game has the best combat in the series thus far; hopefully, future titles can adopt.

Overall, the Resident Evil 4 Remake is a must-have for any fan of the series. I‚Äôm excited to see what remake Capcom will take on next. I give it a 9/10.

Resident Evil 4 is really really good and probably the best resident evil game out there right now at least in gameplay. 

Capcom basically took everything that worked so well in Resident Evil 2 & 7, dialed up the action and gameplay by 10 while still managing to keep the iconic horror this franchise is known for. They have successfully struck the perfect balance between action packed power fantasy gameplay, and  iconic resident evil horror. This is something most studios can't achieve, yet Capcom not only did it, but also perfected it in this game.

The cut scenes, the environments, the art direction, the carefully designed details on every surface, it's all done with such surgical perfection and it's only further enhanced by the buttery smooth optimisation of this game. No stutters, No frame rate drops, not even a single bug to encountered in my entire 30 hour playthrough. Every section, level, terrain, item and location not only looks gorgeous, but plays perfectly and just like how it's supposed to. I cannot commend the people behind this engine and games enough. Truly talented tech geniuses and its their innovation that set the ground work for what has made this franchise ascend into god tier quality.

What makes this game stand out so much though is the gameplay. Third-person Blood-curdling action packed linear levels with satisfying gun play that is only further enhanced by Capcom's insane sound design. Every foot step, every gun shot, even something as small as the sound of pages turning is so detailed. When you shoot someone in the head, you feel the impact of the bullet from the sound of skin tearing and blood splatter. When you round house kick, you feel the heavy impact of leon's foot on the enemies neck from the sound of it snapping and cracking. It really brings this game to life. It is truly a technical marvel and i swear no one in this industry does sound as good as capcom does.

Its all further enhanced by the variety of weapons & upgrades in this game. There's enough here to keep a healthy level of flexibility in how you want to play. The progression system in how you upgrade your weapons is also incorporated into exploration, making it always feel rewarding and worth while. The enemies follow suit in quality, ranging from your classic terrifying big monster with dodge mechanics to a slippery assassin scorpion that intelligently uses the environment to sneak up and attack you. Many also have little twists and details that really enrich the way you can approach enemies. Villagers that hold C4's in their hand that you can shoot to blow them and their surroundings up. Infected with regenerative abilities that you need to shoot specific weak spots to kill. It's this rich variety in how you interact with the game that makes the moment to moment experience always feel new. It is what makes this franchise so iconically endlessly replayable.

The story is about what you'd expect from a capcom resident evil game. Nothing insane in narrative, but just enough lore dressing and interesting connections to umbrella to keep fans like me interested in the characters of this game and the world their in. What surprised me the most though is how hilarious the writing is. Leons dialogue in particular. It's bordering Devil may cry 5 levels of ironic but still being grounded enough to feel serious. I think the execution is the real MVP here as it's done well enough to make Leon's silly 2010 esq comments come off as charming and lovable rather than cringe and annoying. The writing really is a product of its time and i'm so happy Capcom did not touch it in this remake because i really love it.

Generally speaking, this extreme of a departure in any franchise, let alone one with horror as iconic as Resident Evil's, usually turns out to be a disappointment. But Capcom really stuck the landing here. They managed to create a satisfying action focused game whilst still having it feel like resident evil. They did it so well, infact, i might prefer this style over RE 2&7's more slow placed horror, as long as it's done well. 

And this game certainly does it extremely well. Which is why I highly recommend it.

8.5/10

I am NOT a fan of horror games. In fact, after playing 4 Remake, I've gone on to try 2 Remake and am not having a fun time of it. What makes 4 Remake special? There's something very satisfying about Leon's movements, gun and knife-parrying mechanics here that scratches a primal itch inside of me. 

Beyond being one of the best video game remakes of all time, this game is one of the best video games ever. Period. Capcom shows that they know their fans. The graphics, voice acting, atmosphere, gameplay mechanics -- all are absolutely stellar. I played the Remake first, sunk more than 100 hours, and now I've just finished playing the original 4 as well. It might be exposure bias speaking here, but I prefer the Remake to the original. I was going to say something about how Leon is somehow hotter wearing the trauma-chip on his shoulder now in the Remake, but all the characters have received a fresh coat of paint here. I just love this game, its story, characters, and gameplay. Also, instantly replayable because of New Game Plus, achievements, and excellent fan-made mods.

If you consider yourself a fan of video games, you owe it to yourself to play this masterful game.

The fact that Capcom took one of their most beloved games and improved on it so much in almost every single way not only speaks of great mastery, but also of great respect towards the original RE4. The remake improves and extends on the combat, level design, level navigation, lore, side-quests, rewards and progression system while keeping the soul of the original game, which in current setting looks to be an insurmountable task for many. Quite a few modern remakes/remasters just reimplement the exact same mechanics while only giving the game a new coat of paint and not improving on it whatsoever (eg: Demon's Souls, Dead Space, Metroid Prime, Metal Gear Solid 3 or Oblivion...). The game also removes some fat from the original, which I understand though removing a particular boss and moving to the DLC I've found kinda weird. 
The original game absolutely deserves a lot of recognition and respect with how much it influenced many 3rd person action games, but looking at it objectively, it has a couple of issues, which this remake addresses, creating a game that easily surpasses the original.

I want to start off with the positives. I love the fight mechanics. Being able to duck, parry and move more freely during combat makes every fight a lot more enticing, and I find myself more drawn in. The visuals are also extremely beautiful. I first played it on PS5, and with a TV screen, it's like a movie.

BUT, what I don't like, is the extremely wild difficulty range. When I perform too well in a few mini-bosses, the game punishes me in the long run, by turning everything 10x harder. I didn't mind, until I got to "house guarding" with Luis. I died there 6 times, until the game decided to go easier on me. And I wouldn't have minded the difficulty if LEON WASN'T SO HARD TO CONTROL. Most boss battles happen in tight places, which I find so stupid. Leon runs like a grandma, turns around like a tank, but somehow is fast enough to catch every punch coming his way?? I have clips in which at least 4 ganados decided to take turns playing punchbag on Leon, not even giving a chance for him to get up.
Which brings me to my 2nd point. We have the mechanic to parry any weapon, heck, sometimes even punches, so obviously they needed to introduce something else to keep us on our toes.. oh, right, EMPTY HANDED GANADOS. They pose the biggest threat in a mass shooting, solely because they can hold you down, and flip you out from your strategies. It gets annoying fast.
However, what's even more annoying is [b]Leon.[/b] I adoreee the old cocky Leon from the og, and I understand the remake wanted a more serious tone, but god are some of his lines straight up embarrassing. When he finally reached Ashley and murmured "huh, that went well" I had to pause the game for a moment.

anywayy, I have a strange relationship with this game, I like it and hate it at the same time, but if i had to recommend it, i wouldn't :D

This is my new favorite resident evil game.  Truly other than the undewhelming boss fight (you literally just need to purchase the rocket launcher to beat it and get to its final phase) this game is absolutely perfect. RE4 is a modern classic in every sense. Not only is it an excellent survival horror, it is also probably the best action narrative game on the market. Everything from the level design, weapons and gameplay are polished and well executed. You would be hard pressed to find better 3rd person gameplay or a more robust roster of enemies to face. 
It isn't perfect, I do have some issues with the constant changes in setting, particularly the island portion in the final act, but the village and the castle are rich in a gothic european atmosphere. The story is also solid, much more an early 2000's action adventure than a horror story, but for the game RE4 is, I think it fits. 
Overall its hard to levy any real criticism at RE4 as I seem to enjoy it more and more with every playthrough. It is likely a game I will continue to replay for years to come.

Recently I have developed a rating system for games to determine whether or not they're good and if I'd recommend them. The system is simple, all I do is ask myself the question. "is playing *insert game title* the first thing I want to do when I have free time?" As an adult in his mid 20s my time is occupied by many things/responsibilities, and playing video games has to be a decision I make, whereas when I was younger it was just a regular part of the day. So when there's game that I want to work into my schedule, it's then I can truly recommend it.

Solid remake, I played through slowly over the last few weeks and had a great time, easily on par with 8 as my last played entry in the series. Combat feels good, shooting is clean and alternating between taking shots, parrying with the combat knife, and running in to roundhouse kick enemies keeps most encounters at a nice scramble. Environment design is solid as one would expect from modern RE and traversing through each area solving puzzles and dodging traps stays consistently engaging without too much backtracking. Really not many notes just a quality remake

Solid remake, done beautifully. Took me back when I was a child and played with my friends on PlayStation 2, but in a modern way with a modern design. I felt that I played a new game as well, I mean, after so many years obviously I'd feel the same playing the 2004 version, but still. The horror is there, surprise is there, RE OG shooting mechanics and camera angles are there, cutscenes are interesting, lovely melee attacks and parrying with knife (you can feel the pressure at each fight and the force of which Leon kicks every time), I love the small changes like the dialogue between characters that's slightly different than the 2004 version, and the game really shows it's value again with this remake after so many years. My experience from the game as an adult now, is very very positive. Money well spent.

This is the third story game I've played. It's extremely fun, the atmosphere sort of changes throughout the gameplay.
I felt in three different areas while playing this. The first one was Chapters 1-6 where it was a village-y/mystical vibe. Chapters 7-12 were medieval/Witcher 3 (lol) vibe. Chapters 13-16 had a futuristic/mechanical type of vibe, kinda hard to explain, but I loved every single one of the chapters.
The villains were insanely interesting, even the chainsaw guy in chapters 1-4 (I think), was hella fun to play around with lol. Birores Mendez was my favorite, he was ominous and had a clear motive - get Ashley and eradicate everything that gets in it's way - didn't work so well though haha.
There was a debate going on the medias - which is better - Silent Hill 2 remake or Resident Evil 4 remake? I've read some reviews and some ideas and I definitely agree with most of them. Silent Hill 2 remake is a dark, ominous, mysterious, psychological-horror with some hidden messages, while Resident Evil 4 remake is an arcade type of game with lots of action, guns and grehnayyyyydes. Both are amazing works, but I must say, I found RE4R much more fun. Definitely recommending RE4R fans to check out SH2R though.
By the way, I'd be thinking when lessons would end, just so I could come home and play RE4R...
Anyways, my rating of this game would have to be a 9/10. Not a 10/10, just 'cause the presumably "strongest" boss battles were simple.. I'd say I had more work fighting off the minions, rather than the bosses themselves. I wanted to sweat a lil.. ü•Äüíî

This is easily the longest run I‚Äôve ever had in a Resident Evil game, and honestly? It was worth every minute. Like seriously, the game‚Äôs just fun, like really FUN. You can replay it over and over and it still doesn‚Äôt get old. Each difficulty hits different and gives you a real challenge.

Leon‚Äôs changed a lot since RE2. He is more confident, more badass. Ashley isn‚Äôt annoying anymore unlike her OG counterpart, and Ada? Total girlboss as always. Stylish, cool, deadly. And Wesker‚Ä¶ oh man... Wesker is awesome. He is THAT guy. The best villain in RE franchise. I seriously can‚Äôt wait for a RE5 remake just to see him again.

Enemy designs are top-tier, both in the main game and in the Separate Ways DLC. Every boss fight feels unique, and the Regenerators? Easily the creepiest things in the whole game. Those freaks are freaky ;)

Took me almost a month to finish everything.  Got all of the achievements and messed around in Mercenaries. Didn‚Äôt bother with the records though, no way I‚Äôm doing that grind. Still, I feel like I‚Äôve done it all and it‚Äôs been an amazing ride.

Big thanks to Capcom for this masterpiece. For those reading this, Resident Evil 4 Remake is absolutely worth your time. Can‚Äôt wait to see what‚Äôs next! Hopefully RE5 or Code Veronica will have its own remake.

Bye RE4, I‚Äôll miss you :(

Tomb raider meets outlast. The beginning gave me more action than horror, but as I progressed the variety of settings and enemies that I encountered tested the waters of what I personally found scarier. Zombies? Meh. Bugs? Shaking a little. Aliens? Pissing my pants. Not to say that any of these were actually in the game; the artists' ability to depict such a variety feel of the enemies while sticking to 'las plagas' I thought added to an immersive horror experience where I found myself shaking in certain chapters.... One complaint. There is no fast-travel, and it sucks when a game doesn't allow the player to revisit chapters freely. Locking achievements behind a "play it again" doesn't add real replay value, but rather takes away from a continuous long journey that is experiencing a game for the first time.

This game is so much fun. I remember the time I played Resident Evil 4 OG in PS2. This remake captures the essence of the original and makes it more fun, a perfect remake. I have not come across many games like Resident Evil 4 with its level design, boss fights, inventory management, weapon store (I spent a lot of time contemplating what to buy and what to upgrade) treasure hunting, side quests, and a Hollywood like story line that seamlessly fits within the Resident Evil franchaise. There are certain sections like the Mine Cart sections that are so fun that you want to play them again and again. I especially like the sections where there are a lot of enemies where you have to carefully conserve ammo and take them down. The game strikes a perfect balance between horror and action  which scratches a very specific itch unlike the games later in the series. I have played a lot of horror adventure games but Resident Evil 4 remains my favourite. Definitely worth playing in Hardcore mode in the first try, because game is very well balanced such that it is not very hard nor very easy, you will have to struggle but you will glad you played in hardcore.

I still remember playing Resident Evil 4 on the PS2 with my older brother.
It wasn‚Äôt just a game ‚Äî it was one of our happiest memories together.
We‚Äôd take turns, shout when the Ganados came rushing in, and laugh when we both panicked.

Now, years later, I‚Äôm here playing Resident Evil 4 Remake‚Ä¶
but this time, I‚Äôm alone.
My brother isn‚Äôt here anymore, and that makes this experience bittersweet ‚Äî
like I‚Äôm playing for both of us.

This remake isn‚Äôt just a visual upgrade.
It captures the soul of the original while giving us something fresh, intense, and modern.
The atmosphere, the tension, the details ‚Äî everything feels familiar yet new again.
It‚Äôs like visiting your childhood home after many years ‚Äî different, but still home.

If you loved the original, play this.
If you never did, now‚Äôs the perfect time.
And if you‚Äôre waiting for a sale ‚Äî go ahead, grab it when it drops.
It‚Äôs more than worth it.

‚≠ê 10/10 ‚Äî For nostalgia, for emotion, and for one last game with my brother.

As someone who‚Äôs been playing Resident Evil since the PS1 days, I went into the Resident Evil 4 Remake with high expectations ‚Äî and it completely blew me away. It captures everything I loved about the original, but with a level of polish and atmosphere that makes it feel brand new again. The visuals are absolutely stunning, the sound design is intense, and the updated controls make the gameplay smoother without losing the tension that made the original so iconic. It‚Äôs like revisiting an old favorite, but seeing it through fresh eyes.

What really impressed me, though, is how much care Capcom clearly put into this remake. They didn‚Äôt just slap on better graphics ‚Äî they refined the pacing, added new layers to the characters, and reworked some key moments in ways that actually surprised me, even as a longtime fan. It‚Äôs still very much Resident Evil 4, but it feels more complete, more modern, and honestly, more fun. this version is something special.

It's always a treat to play a contender for one of the best games of all time and it's rare for that game to come from arguable the most influential game of the last two decades.  The RE4 remake is a dazzling accomplishment in which I found appeal in every aspect.  I have one gripe with the whole game but this is an absolute modern classic and should be played as blind as possible.

(+)  I've played this countless times on PS5 and my PC run still felt fresh as the fidelity is really felt from a powerful rig.  I had everything firing at max settings and it ran beautifully smooth with even surfaces like bloodsplatters hanging in the air and the spent casings from your weapons reflecting light.  The RE engine punches up the impact of everything you do and I felt every knife slash and bullet spent was brought back up to the level of RE2R's gore which never lost its shine and gives the combat back its teeth which was dulled in the RE3 remake.  The sheer variety of enemy design puppeteered by the dynamic and reactive AI means even after 100+ hours on console and hot off a play-through I would be more than happy to go back through using all the different weapons again and again.  The game is split into thirds making this feel like three games mashed into one, even before the spectacular Separate Ways DLC.  I played the classic RE4 before tackling the remake and the remake is lovingly recreated with only a few strands of fat cut off.  The team at Capcom shoved out a flabby RE3 remake but the trade-off meant a timeless masterpiece in the RE4 remake.  I believe this is the perfect action-horror game and its terror is in overwhelming odds, even though I've upgraded every weapon and can get by untouched there's always a gripping sense of panic when enemies burst through walls and crash through doors.  The presentation of the narrative, I thought, was great and a lot more personality and quirks are given to the supporting cast which was a really nice touch showing the attentiveness of the developers in keeping everything consistently excellent.  With just the base campaign there is enough here to prove value for money at full price but I did nab the Gold Edition on CDKeys for around seven pounds which is daylight robbery on my end.  I really enjoyed the Separate Ways DLC as it leans more-so into frenetic combat and gives Ada a more robust arsenal from the off which gives it a nice rapid pace through your five or so hours with it.  The DLC gives a nice twist into offering another perspective of the main story and I felt was a proper realisation of what they were shooting for with RE2R by giving the story an A and a B para-narrative.  What little was cut from the original was in the DLC and I adored how they went the extra effort in bringing that content back.  

(-)  My only gripe with the game is that there's too much yellow paint splashed around, everything you can interact with pretty much has either paint or tape on it.  The game achieves such a groundbreaking level of fidelity in its environmental design that it was always distracting having everything coated in this sickly yellow colour.

Overall, this is a modern day masterpiece and it was astounding to play-through a game I know rocketed right into my favourite games of all time.  I genuinely don't know how they're going to top this but this game should be in everyone's library.  It worked flawlessly with my X1X controller and I had zero technological problems.  I was finally finished with my full sweep in just under 19 hours.  I would absolutely recommend this game to everyone.
