The original Resident Evil 4 has always held a special place in my heart. I got it for my 9th birthday from a friend who was fully convinced I'd be scared enough to never make it to the end. I ended up beating the game way before he eventually did. It, along with Evil Dead 2 (shout out), helped train me to get past my scares and kickstart my fascination for the horror genre. 
  Well, it's a little later down the decades, and I finally got around to finishing the Resident Evil 4 remake! There was so much going through my head during the experience, I decided to write another review for my thoughts.

[h1] Visuals + Music [/h1]

  Captures the exact vibes of the original game, and adds a lot on top of it. The RE Engine does wonders for character models, so you can expect a lot of the enemies you see in this game to look extra gross (complimentary) and tons more satisfying to pop bullets through (see, complimentary). The environments are visually stunning for just being grey castles and European villages. Every corner is filled with grime and blood, with small hints at how life used to be before everything went sideways. 
  The music makes for great accompaniment to everything going on in-game. When you're walking through dark and empty corridors, it's eerie and feels claustrophobic. By the next door you get through, BOOM! a wave of cultists show up and suddenly the music is zippy and action-packed. Themes that should hypothetically clash actually transition into each other quite well, due in part to this game's score.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]

  My favorite thing about RE4 is how organic player progression was. You start with just a simple pistol and the constant feeling of being overrun with enemies. In spite of its semi-tanky controls, by the end of the experience you feel like Arnold Schwarzenegger in Predator. RE4R thankfully maintains the satisfaction of that, while adding more to really sell Leon's "highly skilled secret agent" feel. To start:
[b] YOU CAN MOVE WHILE SHOOTING NOW [/b]
  In fact, everything about the combat feels like a plus, and probably where RE4R does its best work. The weapons handle great and every shot you land on an enemy's weak point is extremely satisfying to pull off. Leon is able to utilize his knife way more too, using it to parry and sneak-attack enemies (yes, stealth is also a thing now, kinda) at the cost of newly-added durability. Inventory management is virtually the same, with the only big additions being the new charms and case types that give you different perks. These new additions, of course, can be earned from the fan-favorite Merchant character, who returns with weapons, weapon upgrades, a shooting range, new side quests to complete, and a lot of things to say (seriously, he gets really chatty in this one).

[h1] Story [/h1] 

  Virtually the same as it was in the OG. Leon S. Kennedy is back in action to rescue Ashley Graham; the U.S. President's daughter; from a cult under the control of a parasite dubbed "Las Plagas". In contrast to the original, RE4R seems to aim for a darker tone that treats its setting and characters more seriously, though not without the occasional comedic one-liner to lighten the mood. To its benefit, this change gives old players a fresh take on the original, while modernizing towards the taste of a newer audience. The darker tone helps ramp up the horror, too. There were sequences in this that went from merely giving me the chills in the original, to having me scream like old-school Pewdiepie as my viewers watch me sprint for the exit. Either the writing got better or I've gone soft.
  Another thing I enjoyed about RE4R is how it fleshes every character out, and I mean [u] everyone. [/u] Though he still has his corny wit, Leon is less of a campy action star here. He's under pressure. You really see how the events of RE2 affected him, and empathize more for his desire to prevent something like the Raccoon City incident from happening again. Luis gets more screentime and not only has his motivations fleshed out, but also plays a more enjoyable comedic foil to Leon's "straight-man" personality. I liked how they expanded on the lore of enemies and bosses here, too, through new dialogue and notes scattered through the locations you explore that dig deep into the history of the game's settings.
  I [i] particularly [/i] enjoyed the changes they made for Ashley. She's evolved from a bratty escort mission, becoming a companion that goes through a far more compelling arc that makes her feel like an endearing friend by the end credits. She's also a lot better gameplay-wise, too, avoiding enemies when needed and even helping Leon out in some of the many puzzles.

[h1] In Conclusion/TL;DR [/h1]

  To this day, Resident Evil 4 is lauded as an all-time great in the survival-horror genre. I'm pleased to say that RE4 Remake lives up to the legacy. Everything they did well in 2004 is emulated faithfully here, but the new additions improve on the experience tenfold. If you're an OG player whose owned/played the original on 50 different consoles and [i] still [/i] want a fresh experience, give the remake a go. If you're a newcomer to the franchise, or horror games in general, maybe this is the game that gets you past the horror scares just like Resident Evil 4 did for me all those years ago...

[b] Wear your brown pants and consider them training wheels. By the end, you'll be fearless enough to let 'em loose! [/b]

As a diehard fan of the original release of RE4 and subsequent ports, my two concerns were freshness and familiarity. The experience is not the same, in a good way, new mechanics add more depth to an already exquisite gameplay (i.e. stealth, backstabbing and knife durability). The "survival horror" aspect is more present, but the "action" part feels heightened as well. Story and locations are scrambled and reimagined, making this feel like a "gaiden" version more than a "remake". These new aspects take some time to sink in, my first playthrough on hardcore ended at almost 30 hours, yet replay value is high and i'm already speedruning the game on professional withouot special weapons. Bonus are a given in these remakes and I appreciate the access to concept art and models. Don't care much for paid DLC though, I'm giving "separate ways" a try at a later date.

Very fun and polished game. I've played a good amount of the original game and this is obviously a step up because of the years of new technology and innovation in the gaming space. The parry mechanic is wonderfully done and well balanced, making the enemies faster and more ferocious as the difficulty scales. The knife mostly justifies the jump in speed. I kinda got whiplash when playing the first chapter as enemies run toward you unlike the slow walk in the original game, this is because the aiming mechanic has changed massively from the original.

While I do think there are very difficult sections where ammo is immensely scarce at parts, but at the same time that makes you utilize the knife mechanics more as you can actively engage in knife-only combat with good movement and good parry timing. This is more because I play on hardcore, but I do enjoy the challenge.

In general, the game is excellently made. Very well polished with no bugs I've experienced thus far. I advise you play this game on standard even if you played the original. It's very punishing and you can't change the difficulty.

I played the original Resident Evil 4 before this game, but I did so in the past few years, not having played it as a kid. I think that gives me a less biased view on the games, and I can readily say this is a worthy remake. I'm not sure I like it better than the original overall, but this game has a lot going for it. I still think the original is very much worth playing even after beating this remake, but you wouldn't be doing yourself a terrible disservice by only playing this. It definitely has a more serious tone than the original; while Leon still cracks one liners pretty consistently, the writing overall is less silly. I don't necessarily mean that in a good or bad way, it's just different. As for gameplay, I really enjoyed it, especially after the early game where I suffered from severe skill issues. Hardcore is a good challenge, and as recommended by the game, I wouldn't play it first unless you've played RE4 or just like hard games. I don't think stuns are quite as satisfying in this game, and enemies seem marginally more bullet spongy, but overall the combat experience is very smooth. Overall, the this remake kept most of what made the original so good, and where it does change or add from the formula, I would say it's rarely for the worse. I think RE4 and its remake have enough differences to make both valuable experiences, and I highly recommend both.

After finishing RE2, I didn't really get the hype around Leon S. Kennedy. This game made me get it, to the point where I'd say he could be in the conversation for greatest video game protagonist. My only real complaint after finishing the game is that I felt it was lacking the horror aspect that I love from this genre, it may be because RE7 and Village was my introduction to the franchise, but there were only a few sections during my playthrough that I'd say was truly scary. But that's the only negative the game had that I noticed. There's an incredibly small number of games that are so well-paced and engaging, that there's never a moment where I'm not having fun, and RE4 is one of them. The combat has no right being as good as it is for a survival horror game, with a satisfying knife parry mechanic, roundhouse kick, killer suplex, and some fun progression in weapon unlocks and upgrades. The music was great and how it could quickly change to accompany crazy action moments to creepy horror sections was done really well. I also enjoyed the chemistry between Leon and Ashley and the little moments they shared between all the chaos. I was also surprised by how quickly the game made me care about Ashley from the first few moments after meeting her. Boss fights were amazing, Action set-pieces were incredible, and a satisfying conclusion to top it all off. I really hope we see more of Leon soon...

Resident Evil 4 Remake ‚Äî Reviewed by Albert Wesker

So‚Ä¶ they‚Äôve done it again.
They‚Äôve taken one of the most flawless specimens in gaming history ‚Äî my favorite experiment in human desperation ‚Äî and decided to reconstruct it, piece by piece. A dangerous endeavor. After all, tampering with perfection rarely ends well‚Ä¶ unless I‚Äôm the one doing the tampering.

Yet, to my astonishment, Capcom managed to resurrect Resident Evil 4 with a degree of precision I can almost‚Ä¶ admire. Almost.

Let‚Äôs begin with the most obvious variable: Leon S. Kennedy.
Still sporting that golden hair and smug confidence, only now he‚Äôs aged ‚Äî seasoned by trauma and polished by experience. He moves with purpose, fights with style, and quips with‚Ä¶ questionable restraint. He‚Äôs matured, yes, but the boy still clings to his delusions of heroism. The man cannot accept that the system he serves is every bit as rotten as Umbrella ever was.
A shame. He could‚Äôve made an excellent operative.

The gameplay ‚Äî improved, streamlined, but never diluted. The knife, once a desperate last resort, is now an extension of survival instinct. It breaks, it mends, it evolves ‚Äî much like the series itself. Combat is fluid, savage, and precise.
For once, I felt the faintest glimmer of challenge.

The village, the castle, the island ‚Äî all reimagined with such atmosphere it‚Äôs almost intoxicating. Each area drips with dread, history, and blood. The Las Plagas return in glorious form ‚Äî beautifully grotesque, endlessly mutating. I find it comforting to see that humanity continues to produce such admirable monstrosities.

And Ada Wong‚Ä¶
Ah, still the enigma. Still a master manipulator in crimson silk. Her presence lingers like a shadow in every scene ‚Äî though her voice this time‚Ä¶ lacks the venom it once carried. A pity. But her mission? Her secrecy? Impeccable.

Then there‚Äôs Luis Serra.
Refined, witty, and finally given the narrative weight he deserved. He‚Äôs no longer a throwaway scientist ‚Äî he‚Äôs a man with ideals, regret, and brilliance. I can respect that. Had Umbrella not imploded under its own arrogance, he‚Äôd have been valuable to my cause.

But let‚Äôs not ignore Saddler and his cult of zealots. Still amusing. Still pitiful. The Las Plagas in their hands are like a masterpiece painted with mud.
To think ‚Äî such potential wasted on religious fanaticism. Typical.

Yet despite these quibbles, I cannot deny the craftsmanship. The sound, the lighting, the tension ‚Äî all re-forged into something elegant and cruel. It feels‚Ä¶ alive.

Still, I must be honest. The remake lacks the raw shock of its predecessor. It‚Äôs refined, but safer. Controlled. Sanitized for modern audiences. The edges have been polished ‚Äî and with that polish, some of the madness is lost.
It‚Äôs no longer reckless genius. It‚Äôs disciplined success.

My verdict:
A near-perfect reconstruction of an already perfect creation. Beautiful. Efficient. Ruthlessly modern.
But where the original was an experiment spiraling into glorious chaos, this one feels‚Ä¶ contained.
Too clinical. Too human.

9 out of 10.
A remarkable mutation ‚Äî but one that still needs a touch of Wesker‚Äôs influence to achieve true perfection.

**Resident Evil 4 Beginner's Memo**

**I. Purchase**  
Buy the Gold Edition of Resident Evil 4 Remake. It is the best version for beginners to experience the  Resident Evil.

**II. Settings**  
After starting the game, go to settings and turn off all online features. In the controls section, familiarize yourself with the controls, then choose "Assisted" difficulty to begin.

**III. Important Controls**  
1. **F Key** ‚Äì Used for important interactions like checking and picking up items. If you get stuck, try looking around carefully and press F on unusual spots.  
   Also, it is recommended to shoot enemies in the legs to stagger them, then press F up close to perform a melee attack. This saves ammo and controls the situation.

2. **Dodge (E Key) & Parry (Spacebar)** ‚Äì Some attacks can be dodged by pressing E. When an enemy is about to hit you, press Spacebar to raise your knife and parry. A successful parry not only avoids damage but also staggers the enemy, creating a good chance to counterattack.

3. **Q Key** ‚Äì Used for a quick turn.

4. **Managing the  Case** ‚Äì Press Tab to open the  case.  
   (Use Shift to move items, Q to rotate items, Alt to organize items, and Ctrl to store/retrieve items in the temporary slot.)

5. **Commanding Ashley** ‚Äì Use the Ctrl key to give Ashley commands, telling her to wait in a safe spot or follow you closely.

**IV. Using flingtraine **  
Play until you find the "Typewriter" save point, save,then exit the game.  
Go to the website of  flingtrainer com, search for Resident Evil 4, and download the trainer.  
This trainer requires REFramework by praydog to bypass the game‚Äôs anti-cheat protection. Follow these steps:  
1. Copy "dinput8.dll" to the game directory (the same folder as re4.exe).  
2. Launch the game.  
3. Open trainer, UNLOCK ALL EXTRA CONTENT SHOP ITEMS , and set CP to 99,999. Use the shop to buy the "Cat Ears" accessory (provides unlimited ammo) and other items you want.  
4. In the game, equip the Cat Ears accessory in the accessories menu, then load game
5. Close Fengling Yueying and save, start enjoying the game.  
6. When you meet the mysterious merchant, you can reopen trainer  to edit PESETAS  and  SPINELS for easier shopping.

The original RE4 is a masterpiece -- I would honestly have to say this improves on it in every single way. The new gameplay mechanics are excellent and bring everything in line with the modern RE titles. Graphically the game is absolutely stellar on max settings. And the somewhat darker vibes compared to the original go a long way in upping the ante. 

I adored RE2R and would have said it was my favorite Remake of any video game ever released, but, I don't know anymore. This one might have topped it!

I highly recommend this one to anyone, from longtime RE fans, to newcomers!

Resident Evil 4 Remake is an awesome game!
I've never played the Original on the Gamecube or any other system so I can't judge how faithful to the original it is but even  on its own it's a great game.
It plays alot like Resident Evil 2 Remake or Resident Evil 3 Remake, but is way more action-oriented than those two.

The greaphics are great while still not insanely demanding. I am hitting between 80-144fps at WQHD at max details, without RT, with a 8086k and 6900XT.

The sound and music amplify the mood and atmosphere. I mean if you are sneaking through a dark laboratory complex why wouldn't you want to hear a raspy-breathing in the dark while reading about a new kind of monster they've created?!

The storyline is typical Resident Evil, so basically a hommage to the action/horror movies from the 90s and 2000s.

If you like either Third-Person-Shooters or Resident Evil you really should tryout this game. The original is hailed as one of the best games of all times and this, while not perfect masterpiece, is a great game as well.

Resident Evil 4 belongs in the video game remake hall of fame. It's almost perfect in every way. It is an absolute "must play" for all fans of action and survival horror games. As a long time fan of the series, I can confidently say that Capcom totally nailed this one.

Genuinely adored this game. It's not survival horror like re1, but damn does it feel good to play.

The game offers a lot of replayability, so the price is 100% justified.

This game is a remake of the Resident Evil 4 Game from 2005.

It's fun as the original. :D

Such an all-around great game. RE4 has some of the best TPS gameplay I've experienced with tense close-quarters combat requiring a good deal of spatial awareness and resource conservation. The story is as deeply fascinating as it is creepy as hell, set in some backwoods part of Spain seemingly forgotten by time. Creature designs are grotesquely cool and characters benefit from unexpectedly good EN voice (re)casting that is pleasantly grounded and doesn't detract at all from the immersion. 

Many will attest to RE4's stellar combat and story experience, but I particularly want to highlight its impressive replay value. Most games naturally want to keep you engaged with optional achievements and collectibles, but they rarely succeed in actually making me [b]want[/b] to play through the game again. RE4 does just that. This is primarily a testament to the game's excellent gameplay, but players are also encouraged to approach a 2nd (3rd, 4th...) playthrough in meaningfully different ways. 

There are achievements that reward self-imposed handicaps that make the game more challenging, but the rewards earned for clearing the game on each difficulty also add to or enhance your arsenal in ways that will give you an edge during future playthroughs. I am not someone who is typically interested in attempting speed runs, but the reasonable length of the game and the variety of ways these upgrades allow you to better manage, avoid, or (amusingly) trivialize certain parts of the progression make aiming for those higher rank speed-based completions legitimately enticing. 

The only criticism I might offer is that incoming boss attacks can be awkward to avoid due to how sluggish movement is compared to the dodge and roll mechanics of more modern games. I consistently end up tanking several hits and think I'd enjoy these fights even more if the dodging were primarily QTE based. Honestly though, there is so little to complain about. This is likely one of the best remakes of a classic ever produced and the things they changed or added - including the Separate Ways DLC - only make the experience that much better.

The best game I have ever played. I first played the original when I was about 5 years old with my dad one night later than I should've been up and since then I have probably played through it more than 5 times and I don't plan to stop re-visiting.

Now I know why RE:4 is considered the best Resident Evil game. This game was SO enjoyable.

Leon is back (my favorite twink cop) and DAMN is he well written, and awesome. From what I've heard this Remake changed a lot of things, and it focused more on Leon as a whole instead of other things in the original. I personally like this.. since I love knowing more about Leon. 

The gameplay is SO GOOD!! In RE:2 / RE:3 I more or less shot stunned enemies a lot because everyone was a bullet sponge, but in this game? You can KICK them if you shoot them in the head most of the times. I had a blast killing enemies in this game, and there's a lot of variety. 

I also really loved the exploration element. I truly felt rewarded every time I went for every piece of treasure, and the merchant is a great addition! It felt so nice upgrading my weapons, etc. His challenges were also neat! Overall I SERIOUSLY like the merchant. 

There's nothing else to add (I can talk about the story, but I won't spoil) I highly recommend this game! And I highly recommend playing RE:2 before this one.

An otherwise amazing game that is heavily burdened by the fact that the developers decided to put in multiple points where you cannot backtrack to pick up missed treasures, weapons or requests, with absolutely no warning that you will not be able to return, making it an absolute pain in the fucking ass for completionists. I understand not being able to return to the previous major area after you move on to the next one, but why block off a random staircase? Why can't I climb up a ledge that looks the same as every other clime-able ledge in the game? It's absolutely ridiculous and annoying as all hell. A chapter select option would fix ALL of this, but I guess this game came out a bit half-baked like most of the other remakes. If you're looking to get every achievement for this game, be prepared for a long and arduous journey.

Resident Evil 4 Remake is one of the most fun and action-packed games in the series. The story is solid, the pacing is great, and the mix of intense combat and cinematic set pieces keeps things exciting from start to finish. There are tons of weapons to choose from and a good variety of enemies, so the gameplay never feels repetitive. The music fits every moment perfectly, from calm exploration to chaotic boss fights.

The characters are great and have real chemistry, especially Leon and Ashley. Leon‚Äôs cheesy one-liners are back and they still make me smile. This is easily the least scary Resident Evil game, but it makes up for that with nonstop action, amazing level design, and over-the-top moments that feel straight out of an action movie. My only real complaint is how often Ashley gets captured‚Äîit starts to feel a bit repetitive after a while.

The Separate Ways DLC adds even more to love. Playing as Ada was great, and it was really cool to see what she was doing behind the scenes while helping Leon without him knowing. It makes the story feel more complete and adds nice replay value.

Story: 8
Combat: 10
Graphics: 9
Characters: 10
World and Immersion: 8
Music and Sound: 8
Polish: 9

Final thoughts: Resident Evil 4 Remake is less about horror and more about pure action, but it works perfectly. It is stylish, fast, and full of personality. With great gameplay, memorable characters, and an awesome DLC that ties everything together, it is one of the best Resident Evil experiences you can play.

Pro:
Capcom has once again proven that they know how to bring a classic back to life. The remake of Resident Evil 4 captures everything that made the original special while modernizing it in all the right ways.

The graphics are absolutely stunning ‚Äî every dark corridor, eerie forest, and rain-soaked village feels alive and cinematic. The attention to detail is incredible, from Leon‚Äôs expressions to the atmospheric lighting that constantly keeps you on edge.

The gameplay feels smoother than ever, with the updated controls making combat more responsive and satisfying. The balance between action and horror is perfect ‚Äî intense but never overwhelming.

The writing and voice acting are top-tier, and Leon‚Äôs charming one-liners are still here, now delivered with even more style and confidence. The pacing is tight, the boss fights are thrilling, and the overall tone perfectly walks the line between scary and fun.

Capcom also managed to enhance the story and characters, adding emotional depth without losing the campy charm of the original. It feels respectful and fresh at the same time ‚Äî exactly what a remake should be.

---

Con:
Honestly, it‚Äôs hard to find real flaws. Some fans might miss the original‚Äôs goofier moments, and the difficulty spikes can be a bit rough at times. But those are minor nitpicks in an otherwise masterful remake.

Rating: 10/10

Resident Evil 4 Remake is not just a nostalgia trip ‚Äî it‚Äôs a brilliant reimagining of one of gaming‚Äôs best experiences. Capcom managed to refine, expand, and modernize everything without losing the soul of the original. It‚Äôs a must-play masterpiece that sets the standard for how remakes should be done.

TL;DR: remake is worse than the original, particularly lacking enemy flanking sound queues and some basic sound design. Seems to go out of its way to make combat more unpleasant & less fun with spongy enemies that don't react to bullets.

I grew up playing RE4 on the gamecube. Spent easily 1000+ hours on it doing lots of challenge runs and speedruns because i just loved the shit out of that game. Approaching this game with some of those tactics still in my head 20 years later may have tainted my experience. I played this with a controller, which was probably a big mistake.

1. Limited enemy reaction to damage - staggering enemies is either RNG based or hp based. Old game, you shoot a guy in the head or knees, he staggers and you can melee. this was critical for early crowd control when your primary tool was the pistol. Now in the remake, I regularly shoot enemies in the head 3 times without getting a stagger, sometimes twice without even a hitstun. Effect here is likely by design since it forces more usage of shotgun and grenades in order to handle crowds, but making generic enemies eat bullets to the face with no reaction feels awful, especially since this was a huge selling point for the original game. Maybe the short-term solution is to bench the pistol?

2. Crosshair depth - old game rooted you in place when shooting, and you aimed with a laser pointer. Now you have classic shooter crosshairs with variable spread etc, but you don't have a laser projection from your weapon, if enemies get too close your ability to hit them greatly decreases since your aiming function sources the camera, not your character model.
 
3. Lack of sound cues. This is probably the worst one for me, and I doubt I can mod it away. Maybe I leaned on these too much back in the day, but having an enemy grab/chop/stab you from behind with zero sound cue that you're being flanked was very unpleasant, especially with how the game forces you to tunnel-vision on the targets in front of you with the aim camera and fov zoom. Having to shoot the guy in front of you 3+ times in the head while being unable to hear the ladder being placed behind you or getting a sound cue from a flanking foe really highlights how they made the game worse.

And I'm only two hours in. I have no idea how this game is being reviewed so well when its objectively worse than the original. I hope I can aggressively mod to mitigate these issues, or faster aiming with m&kb could make issue #2 more tolerable.

In the original game, combat was a relatively slow and calculated process that spawned an entire genre - juggling enemies with the ammo and tools provided with reliable enemy hitstun and stagger, and that proverbial boat was rocked when a parasite head or a thicker enemy type appeared - this changed your priorities, forced a brief retreat, reposition, or weapon swap. This design spawned an entire goddamn genre.  Now your boat gets rocked as soon as more than two enemies are in your line of sight, not to mention the silent/invisible enemies behind you due to lack of basic sound design. Maybe this is more survival-horror-y? I find bullet sponge enemies in this game tedious, especially when there's a wall of them in front of you.

I can only fathom the overwhelmingly positive reviews are due to lack of experience with the original game, or if m&kb really fixes everything. The original was a vastly superior experience - and Salazar had a nice hat that I now have to mod in. This remake, so far, feels very small time. Huge disappointment.

p.s. i would give away instant grab-breaks and the upgradable combat knife for the old game's unbreakable basic knife without a moments hesitation.

first Resident Evil game I have ever beaten. I was hooked from the start. The story, the gameplay mechanics, everything was phenominal. Most likely one of my favorite games to date.

[b]+ Combat:[/b] Feels challenging due to reduced mobility. Limited ammunition is a constraint but you rarely run out. Scripted stages where you are swarmed and need to defend a position are tense and fun, especially in Act 1. Unfortunately, the slow movement speed (even when running) makes boss fights annoying. It forces you to exploit the environment to avoid projectile hits (e.g., Act 2 boss) but then again, there are empty arena stages where you don't have any cover.

[b]+ Well paced:[/b] Each chapter takes ~1h to beat, there being 16 chapters total. During each chapter you get 1-2 save points, so you can play the game in short stints of 20-30m.

[b]+ Atmosphere:[/b] All three zones feel unique and interesting, although I prefer Act 1. The deserted villages and dark woods make for a better horror setting. One small annoyance is that sometimes, the tense music persists even after dispatching all threats in the area. Otherwise, the game blends serious themes with lighthearted moments very well (e.g., optional shooting ranges available at the vendor from time to time).

[b]- Companion:[/b] Utterly useless and can largely be ignored. Her story arc should see her become more independent and actually useful until the end of the game, but this is only shown in cut-scenes. During fights, she gets constantly downed or abducted, which represents a game over if not prevented. Would have liked to see her become more involved in fights as the game progresses.

[b]- Leans towards action:[/b] At this point in the franchise, the game started to resemble more of a zombie shooter than a survival horror, which is a shame. There is a short sequence in Act 2 where you play as Ashely (the companion) and due to her lack of combat skills, that ended up being one of the highlights of the entire game.

[b]- Act 3:[/b] To me, the first 2-3 chapters of this act ruin the whole game. Initially, it gives the illusion of stealth-based approaches to each level, but the stealth mechanics are so poorly implemented that you get spotted almost immediately: stay out of spotlights but still get seen, enter a room only to instantly alert all mobs on the floor. Ammo drops (and gunpowder - for crafting) are also significantly reduced in this act. This becomes a problem when a new monster type (the Regenerator, I think it was called) is introduced. It can only be killed by using an IR scope to target its weak points. This scope can only be attacked to rifles and SMGs. If you lack ammo for these weapons, you're shit out of luck.

Resident Evil 4 Remake and Its DLC Separate Ways

*Resident Evil 4 Remake* and its DLC *Separate Ways* deliver a masterclass in modern survival horror. Capcom has not only revitalized a legendary title but expanded its universe with elegance, intensity, and emotional depth.

---

üéÆ **Resident Evil 4 Remake: A Reinvention Done Right**  
This remake elevates the original with fluid controls, refined combat mechanics, and a perfectly paced blend of action and tension. Leon S. Kennedy returns with sharper wit and deeper characterization, navigating a world that feels both familiar and freshly terrifying. The RE Engine brings every shadowy corridor and grotesque enemy to life with stunning realism.

üß† **Narrative Depth and Character Evolution**  
The story is more mature, with richer dialogue and stronger emotional stakes. Ashley is no longer a passive companion‚Äîshe‚Äôs smart, capable, and well-written. Villains like Salazar and Krauser are more menacing, and Luis Serra becomes a standout character with surprising charm and complexity.

üé® **Visuals and Sound Design That Stun**  
From the eerie village to the gothic castle and militarized island, every location is dripping with atmosphere. The lighting, textures, and animations are top-tier, and the sound design‚Äîcreaking floorboards, distant screams, chilling music‚Äîamplifies the dread at every turn.

---

üî¥ **Separate Ways: Ada Wong‚Äôs Moment to Shine**  
This DLC isn‚Äôt just an add-on‚Äîit‚Äôs essential. *Separate Ways* offers a parallel storyline that fills in narrative gaps and adds new layers to the main plot. Ada Wong is sleek, mysterious, and deadly, with gameplay that emphasizes agility, stealth, and gadgetry. Her interactions with Wesker hint at deeper conspiracies, enriching the lore.

üß© **Smart Level Design and Fresh Mechanics**  
Ada‚Äôs missions are varied and cleverly constructed, with new puzzles, combat scenarios, and traversal options. The pacing is tight, the stakes are high, and the boss fights are unforgettable. It‚Äôs a thrilling ride from start to finish.

---

‚ú® **Final Verdict**  
Together, *Resident Evil 4 Remake* and *Separate Ways* form a complete, exhilarating package. They honor the legacy of the original while pushing the franchise forward in bold, cinematic ways. Whether you're a longtime fan or a newcomer, this is survival horror at its finest.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

‚úîÔ∏è Stunning Graphics              ‚Äì Highly detailed environments, realistic lighting, smooth animations  
‚úîÔ∏è Immersive Sound Design        ‚Äì Creepy ambient sounds, intense music, strong voice acting  
‚úîÔ∏è Fluid and Dynamic Gameplay    ‚Äì Precise aiming, parries, dodging, varied combat mechanics  
‚úîÔ∏è Enhanced Storytelling         ‚Äì Deeper character development, improved dialogue, emotional stakes  
‚úîÔ∏è Charismatic Characters        ‚Äì Leon, Ada, Luis, Ashley‚Äîall more nuanced and memorable  
‚úîÔ∏è Smart Level Design            ‚Äì Well-paced zones, hidden secrets, clever enemy placement  
‚úîÔ∏è High Replay Value             ‚Äì Extra modes, collectibles, challenges, multiple playstyles  
‚úîÔ∏è Captivating DLC (Separate Ways) ‚Äì New perspective, Ada‚Äôs unique gameplay, expanded lore  
‚úîÔ∏è Memorable Boss Fights         ‚Äì Intense battles, varied mechanics, cinematic presentation  
‚úîÔ∏è Technical Optimization        ‚Äì Fast loading times, stable performance, minimal bugs

how to make delicious Butter Chicken.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Ingredients for 4 servings,
2 lb boneless, skinless chicken breast (910 g), cubed
salt, to taste
pepper, to taste
2 teaspoons chili powder, divided
¬Ω teaspoon turmeric
6 tablespoons butter, divided
1 ¬Ω cups yellow onion (225 g), diced
3 teaspoons garam masala
1 teaspoon cumin
1 teaspoon cayenne pepper
1 tablespoon ginger, grated
3 cloves garlic, minced
1 cinnamon, 3 inch (8 cm) stick
14 oz tomato sauce (395 g)
1 cup water (240 mL)
1 cup heavy cream (240 mL)
rice, for serving
fresh cilantro, chopped for garnish.

Preparation
In a large bowl, season the chicken breast with salt, pepper, 1 teaspoon of chili powder, and the teaspoon of turmeric. Let
sit for 15 minutes to marinate.
Melt 2 tablespoons of butter in a large pot over medium heat. Brown the chicken, then remove from the pot.
Melt another 2 tablespoons of butter in the pot, then add the onion, garam masala, remaining teaspoon of chili powder,
the cumin, ginger, garlic, cayenne, cinnamon, salt and pepper. Cook until fragrant.
Add the tomato sauce and bring to a simmer.
Add the water and cream and return to a simmer.
Return the chicken to the pot, cover, and simmer for another 10-15 minutes.
Stir in the last 2 tablespoons of butter and season with more salt and pepper to taste.
Serve the chicken over rice and garnish with cilantro.
Enjoy!

Mixed review.

The shortest way I can describe for the Resi4 Remake is that it delivers same passion and example as the original one with a few changes. Most visible ones are few skipping shortcuts, new weapons some being stripped down or another and some cut content from the original. My biggest complaints are timings and hitboxes with parry system additionally given the different directions with the cutscenes. I wouldn't mind these things a lot but trying to go for speedrun achievements kinda made me realize that they've not polished some hiccups with the new systems provided for the game. And it feels way more stripped down as some of the content is not here and moved towards Separate Ways DLC, which is behind paywall and not coming in for free with the whole package like in the original. Additionally skipping on filler Assignment: Ada. (Still odd how in remake Ada and Krauser never make any eye contact)

Now allow me to also break down the more bull turd mechanics added in. Previously in the original Resi4 you had collectible blue medallions used for gallery view with playable sounds and whenever you win all the shooting gallery rounds. In Remake however, you can test your skills by perfecting them. But you also get special medals now, being silver and gold which doesn't really matter- since you still get random chances of playing gacha unlocks. Yes, they added gacha in Remake. Worst part is that there's a speed bonus charm you can attach to your attache case. Which ruins the immersion and the illusion of Leon not running fast enough as his movement is nerfed due to charm's existence. Thus having all of the charms being from the original Resi4 models isn't cute, it's a tease. Makes you wanna question why even bother making HD Project as an official release for Resi4 Original in the first place.

Regardless, I think I had my dosage of repeating this game multiple times but I'd still prefer the original due to enough cheesiness and one-liners with movie cliches given. In Remake you're given less of it. I'm also not too keen how they've pumped up DLCs with "easing" up your runs? Yes, some folks don't have much time but also defeats purpose even further on completing these games.

The original RE4 (2005) is about as close to mechanically perfect a game that‚Äôs ever been made, and still stands as an action horror masterpiece, and the fact they managed to remake it exceptionally well and not mess it up, is pretty incredible. They definitely play differently and have their own feel, which lets both the original and the remake stand on their own. 

Taking the excellent movement and gore damage system from Resident Evil 2 Remake and adding a much faster pace to Leon, as well as the inclusion of the Parry mechanic to the combat works brilliantly. 

Leon, Ashley and Luis Sera are all exceptionally well characterized. Luis Sera especially in this remake is a standout, they did a fantastic job with him. Leon is a complete badass like he‚Äôs always been, he has the natural evolution you‚Äôd expect from his experience in Raccoon City to becoming a highly trained operative, he‚Äôs excellent. 

Ashley Graham was beyond irritating in the original game, whereas here she comes across as a real character, who is understandably horrified by the situation she‚Äôs in and defers to Leon‚Äôs experience and relies on him to get her out this situation alive. Great stuff, it makes both Leon and Ashley super likable the entire way through.  

The environments are remarkably faithful to the original while adding logical changes, the Ganados, Verdugo and Regeneradors are spot on. The RE Engine still looks amazing graphically and the boss battles are super fun. As far as remakes go, this is up there with Resident Evil 2 and Dead Space Remake for sheer effort and quality. 

RE4R is awesome.

I've been interested in game design for years at this point and for like 15 years, I knew the RE series is held in high regard in that matter, especially 2 and 4. Then 4 got the remake, and I, again, needed 2 years to finally play it.

God, I need to let that sit a bit, but this was such a great experience. The game is fast and hectic if it needs to be, it's scary in the horror parts, it's rewarding in its puzzles, it can be cozy at times and even chill. The art style is crazy, the gameplay in itself is a masterpiece. Guns sound great, the impact they have on the enemy is great, there is room for your own individual route cause u kinda need to focus on 5-6 guns to be able to afford upgrades, even fucking melee is fun as hell. The boss fights are all great, the pacing of this game is incredibly well done, from hectic to chill to action to puzzle to boss, nothing ever gets annoying. What can I say, I am in love. I need some time to process the whole thing, but this is top 5 games ever for me, pretty sure. Get this, you won't regret it.

Can't believe I forgot to rate this when it came out. Resident Evil 4 and the original are timeless classics. RE4 being an incredible remake of one of the greatest games of all time.

The remake modernizes the combat and gameplay in an incredible way and makes everything feel familiar but fresh! All of the characters we know and love are brought back in a spectacular way. Leon the badass doing unnecessary backflips. Louis as charming as ever. Every boss fight just a joy and also terrifying at times. 

The optional side quests add such a fun and unique aspect to the game. Heavily expanding the original's blue medallion side quest and I absolutely love it. Unique enemies, items and treasures all can be found as a result. At no point was I left feeling underwhelmed. 

Then the Operation Ada DLC brings back one of my favorite enemies in an incredibly fun way... Literally cannot say more good things. If you played the OG, or are a fan. Or even a casual observer that thinks it could be fun. Do it!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Wait for one of the juicy capcom sales and snag it for a few bucks and enjoy.

At first I was not very fond of the "massive enemy waves" gameplay loop, especially after RE2-3, with more survival based approach and relatively rare enemies. But with time, especially on the second playthrough with unbreakable knife, upgraded weapons and general knowledge of the game - it kinda grew on me. I have to admit it was kinda good. When you figure out how this game runs, dealing with many enemies at once becomes manageble and you can conserve plenty of ammo with strategic crossbow usage.

Compared to the original (I have never played it, but saw screens/gameplay) - I absolutely love updated Ashley design. She is incredibly lovely! Tbh, the whole second playthrough was just that I could spend some more time with her, lol.

Visuals? Well they are great. If you have played any of the new/remastered Biohazard games you already know that the RE-engine is capable of stunning graphics with a hi-rez textures and a solid FPS-counter as well, even on a low-mid tier machines. Absolutely no complains here.

Vibes-wise Re4 is closest to the Re8:Village. They honestly feel kinda the samey - lone european village with a castle, with some influental mid-bosses and a mysterious "profet" running the whole cult. But gameplay wise I have to armit that Re8 is far superior to the 4th. Here we mostly fight hordes of enemies and that's it, while in Re8 there are many different gameplay segments with widely varied mechanics, vibes and enemy types. This doesn't make Re4 "bad" but just shows that modern gameplay design has indeed evolved and is capable of much more than before, which is good. But still you can see many ideas from Re4 being implimented (and elevated) in Re8. So if you have funds only for the 1 game, you will have to decide what is more important to you - overally better and deeper gameplay (and dommy-mommy Dimitrescu) or an old-school familiarity (and cutesy Ashley-chan).

In my opinion both are good. :)

Definitely give the Resident Evil series a try if you have not played it before. Updated and new games in this series are really good.

Resident Evil 4: Gold Edition ‚Äì Worth Every Second

As someone who loved the original Resident Evil 4, I had high expectations going into the remake ‚Äî and this Gold Edition absolutely delivers. It‚Äôs the complete package, and honestly, the best way to play the game if you haven‚Äôt already.

The base game is just fantastic. The story is intense, the atmosphere is creepy in the best way, and the gameplay feels smooth and modern while still keeping that classic RE4 vibe. Leon is still the sarcastic action hero we remember, but the tone is darker and more grounded this time around. The combat feels great, especially with the new parry system. It adds a lot more depth without being overwhelming.

What really makes the Gold Edition shine is the Separate Ways DLC. Ada Wong‚Äôs story adds a ton of value. Her missions feel fresh, and the grapple gun changes how you move through the world ‚Äî it‚Äôs fast, fun, and gives you more tactical options. Plus, it fills in a lot of story gaps from Leon‚Äôs campaign in a satisfying way.

The graphics are top-tier (seriously, some of the environments are jaw-dropping), the sound design is on point, and there‚Äôs a ton of replay value between the main campaign, Ada‚Äôs story, and Mercenaries Mode.

If you‚Äôre new to Resident Evil or just want to revisit one of the best entries in the series, this is the version to get. The Gold Edition is absolutely worth it.

As a lifelong Resident Evil fan who‚Äôs played every mainline title and remake, I can confidently say: Capcom nailed it.

The Resident Evil 4 Remake is everything a remake should be‚Äîfaithful, modernized, and full of smart refinements. Combat is tighter and more intense, the atmosphere is darker and richer, and the characters are better developed (Ashley is actually likable!). The parry system adds depth, and the side content is a welcome addition without overstaying its welcome.

It‚Äôs not just a retread‚Äîit‚Äôs a reimagining that respects the original while improving nearly every aspect. This is survival horror and action in perfect balance.

Whether you're a veteran or new to the franchise, this is a must-play.

First off, don't be fooled by the playtime you see on this review. I have 100% completed this game on Xbox.

The first thing that I would like to get out of the way is that the original Resident Evil 4 is among my top 10 favorite games of all time, but the weapon upgrade tickets that they sell as DLC? COMPLETELY unacceptable. This is absolutely the WORST kind of microtransaction. This is made even more egregious than you might think on its face, because some of the weapons in the game receive infinite ammo when you use one of these tickets. Furthermore, in order to unlock everything in the game, you are expected to get the best possible grade while beating the game on Professional. This requires you to beat it under a certain amount of time while using only one save per chapter. Infinite ammo trivializes this and the only way to get a full playthrough with infinite ammo is to buy one of the tickets. I can't think of a more scummy thing to put in a single player game, especially when the original game did not contain those types of requirements to unlock everything. If this is a dealbreaker for you, I understand. It's a good thing, then that the rest of this game is incredible.

You might have read this far and thought "Why is this review positive? It sounds like he hates this game." On the contrary, they have done such an incredible job in every other aspect of remaking the original game that I still wholeheartedly recommend that you play this game yesterday. Especially if you loved the original, but you'll still love this even if you hadn't. It has been expanded and some of the content from the OG game ended up in the Separate Ways DLC. I do not have any issue with this. The DLC is awesome and a cut above the original Separate Ways in the OG RE4.

The engine that Capcom uses to make these games is stunning. Every single game they have developed in it from Dragon's Dogma to Monster Hunter and Devil May Cry is just an absolutely beautiful feast for the eyes and Resident Evil 4 is no exception. The music is perfect for the game. I even sometimes put the save room theme on loop to go to sleep or just to lay down and think. 

The combat has been greatly updated. It is fun, fast paced, and challenging. Playing on harder difficulties will test your limits. Getting S rank on Professional without the weapon upgrade tickets is truly an incredible test of your gaming prowess. Not for the faint of heart.

The story of this game is pretty cheesy. But they have put in a lot of work to make it feel at least a little less so. The OG has the charm of a silly B-movie that I will always cherish, but I don't disagree at all with the shift in tone. It has some really great characters with interesting personalities and I think I might be in love with Ada Wong. Leon also takes a few moments to check in with Ashley and make sure she is okay along the way. Something he did not do in the original. So even though this is about being a secret agent that goes to some other country to rescue a kidnapped daughter of the president, you will soon forget how ridiculous that is and get invested in the story.

So, altogether, despite some business practices that I vehemently disagree with, I can only recommend this game wholeheartedly. I love it.

Really great game with a decent story. The first quarter of the game was more annoying than anything due to all the bear traps just placed everywhere. It was more map exploration than action, as you had to find a specific item, run across the map, insert an item, realize that the next puzzle requires you to run across the map again, and the cycle continues.

Once you get past this initial point, the game accelerates with somewhat better puzzles, action, and enemies. More characters are introduced, you reach the peak of the story and gameplay, and you should have enough money to buy and try various things. Puzzles require more thinking power, and it becomes less of a treasure hunt but still on par with that.

I did not really enjoy the demo, but I enjoyed the game as a whole. Definitely a step up to the other RE games I've tried.

[b]tl;dr: The original is better, didn't sneak gambling into the game after reviews.[/b]

[h1]The Long (but necessary) Preamble[/h1]
I was hyped for RE2RE. I put Hours into the Demo alone.
For a while, it met my expectations. I hadn't thought too deeply into many aspects of and surrounding it.

Then RE3RE, which was 1/3rd the game. It put a [b]very[/b] sour taste in my mouth, because I Expected Capcom To Be Greedy [b]Again[/b] and FELL for it anyways.

As much as I adore this IP, I also can't allow that to cloud my judgement as a consumer, the other half of the free market, the Sole regulator of it. A logo is a logo. A Product is a Purchase.

I already found the DLC of RE2RE disgusting-
But it only got worse as [i]users would attempt Honest to God Library Spreads[/i] as if that was hustle culture, and [i]they'd Lose Every Time.[/i] There's something sad about that, someone Definitely Struggling, Definitely Younger, desperate to own Anything, hoping this stupid Steam Library means something because a Home won't be in their future. The idea someone barely better off than them, respecting themselves enough to call out anti-consumer practices, it's just Foreign to them. Their self-worth is tied into these soul-sucking products that barely resemble the imaginative ever evolving world of gaming 15-20 years ago.

It's Depressing. The old guard lost, there's at least 2 generations of kids who have only known deliberately incomplete products and proudly hired aid towards giving them gambling addictions.

RE4 came with Seperate Ways [b]For Free.[/b]
Little excuse for greedy behavior. Graphics are not a good reason, the game is not fundamentally more complicated to deserve a Double Price Increase from the original, and no, game prices from the NES-N64 don't count. 
To simplify: Nintendo controlling manufacturing which lead to companies like Atari getting pissed and trying to supersede it, publishers went to Sega because of this, who had lower prices. Discs dramatically furthered lowering costs, Digital Distribution cut that in half, games today should cost FAR less with easier tools, reusable assets, so much information, guaranteed sales, Streak Record Breaking Profits these same developers call disappointing.

Understand this is my Third Rodeo, I can Only Hope some kid sees this, understands they're not lesser of a person for not being able to afford a home, that it's okay to be proud of your games, don't believe it gives you greater value, it just means Mom's Credit Card does alot, that's fine, we were all young.

[h1]Onto the REview:[/h1]

RE4RE has moments where things just Work, but better than the OG?

Another pre-amble, as RE4OG normally, controls rather poorly.

So I'm discussing the (rather small) RE4_Tweaks mod for RE4OG, if you've played with it, you understand why.
THIS, is RE4, pushing boundaries of mechanics to go faster, confident in execution, back to back gameplay. Satisfying gameplay that makes you feel like Wesker without the drugs!

It's not utilized as much as I'd like, but you could barricade doors, then shoot holes through them, it's not used outside of [b]one[/b] missable section, but it's there! Could be expanded upon?

The crows! I love how they're treated like a Crate but moves! It's moving items! Memory, much like with OG RE1-3, IS REWARDED! Replayability!

The treasures? Almost always along your path, makes repeat playthroughs rewarding just remembering there's a treasure in one of the flame lamps without going out of my way.

The Inventory management? That is what DEFINED RE4 for me, it's STILL a unique mechanic, there's nothing more refreshing than adjusting your inventory, it even mattered how much you could carry at anytime, it wasn't mindless how you set it up!
Real consideration by the player for something personal, lovely!

[h1]The Actual REview[/h1]

I've completed all difficulty modes. Not on here. I was weak and got this on sale, supporting an anti-consumer company. It happens, we're all Pay Piggy Useful Idiots at times.
Just think, this sale would be meaningless 10 years ago when "patient gamers" became a wider thing. Now it's a big sale! Hooray 40% off! 20$... off... oh.

[b]RE4RE has a Very Rough Beginning,[/b] I'd argue the game only gets good the second After Ashley gets taken away the first time, second half isn't too bad. It's almost fun! When it wants to be.

[b]RE4RE is not a remake of RE4.[/b]
Re-imagining on a budget for gameplay. If this was a remake of RE4, they'd understand the Back To Back nature the original ALMOST had, that a modder easily fixed. They'd see potential, and adapt that, not discard it completely.
Instead, this game will have Leon play Long Animations that have few I-Frames, which is Dreadful for anything trying to be RE4.

RE4 has an unspoken mechanic that makes it Gold. When you do something, climb a ladder, vault a fence, you're invincible for a short while. Does this Look Realistic? No, but it's fun that the [b]Entire Environment[/b] actually plays some significance to the gameplay. 
It wasn't some guaranteed never get hit mechanic, you still had to Think.

RE4RE doesn't have this. It has Some I-Frames, mostly for melee, but generally you'll try to kick a ladder down, instead, Leon jumps into a crowd of enemies, spends 1.7 seconds to do his land animation, a .5 period before you regain control, then gets shoved around, dies because this game doesn't understand fun or control. God forbid I have any control to make my own fun in a moshpit.
realism. it feels...bad?

[b]Stealth[/b]
It tries to introduce Stealth, but it's infrequent, so slow that failure means you won't try it again. There's one section you can break by going a different way than intended, even then you can still stealth the intended way despite the enemies able to see you. 
It's just not an addition. It's Filler.

So gameplay is a bust from the start, they messed up crows, and treasures are a bore to find.
Inlaying gemstones is fun though, A+.
What of the new mechanics?

[b]Parrying[/b] is not a fun mechanic.
You're better off getting a mod.
Half the time it keeps you from a game over you could Not Possibly Avoid. Otherwise it's as bad as Jill's Dodge mechanic in RE3RE, it doesn't work, but they designed most of the game around it. If you like it, great, it should've been Intuitive, maybe treated as cool points, not a requirement.

[b]Dodging[/b] is the other half of Parry, it's even worse, the keybinds are hardlocked in ways that are user hostile and don't allow you to change a control that is already binded to another, unless [i]They Themselves have done it.[/i]
Which is infantile, it means they could, but refused your ability. 

Dodge could be C, CTRL, E, or F, depending on what you set your Use and Crouch buttons to be, meaning you Have to give up a leg to dodge.

[b]Movement[/b] Leon is Drunk and can't turn without a full half circle approach, gets stuck alot.

Compounding this comes another flawed mechanic, Bullet Spray.
Why in gods name did they add Bullet Spray.
Skill and Effort to RNG.

Charms are abhorrent. I hate having to swap around 8 charms every time I go to the merchant and leave. Awful. Could've been cool, but Micros.

[b]Gameplay Conclusion:[/b]
You're expected to Dodge, Parry and Aim, and all of it is RNG based or unintuitive, meanwhile the game's controls fight you, half taking away control and half not not taking your inputs. And then they have a shooting gallery with gambling mechanics tied into microtransactions snuck in after reviews.

Ashley is fundamental proof they did not playtest her. There's 0 reason for her.

[h1]Conclusions(mostly in comments)[/h1]
I've not much else to say. This isn't an unlovable game, but it's not a game you can fix either. Befriend it, don't stick your dick in it, stick your dick in RE4, it's old enough, I think... yeah 20 years old let's go I'm old AAAAAA

I also plan to give the original Resident Evil 4 the same dedication. I can‚Äôt wait to see what Capcom has in store for Resident Evil 9 and what other exciting things are coming later in the series.

Resident Evil 4 is my favorite in the entire franchise. What makes it stand out is Leon ‚Äî he‚Äôs not the nervous rookie anymore, but cocky, confident, and surprisingly funny. I loved seeing how his character had changed, and even when he‚Äôs mowing down enemies like a one-man army, he still manages to make me laugh.

The cast around him is great too. Ashley has been rewritten into someone who isn‚Äôt just a burden, and she even manages to tug at your heart a little. Luis is lighthearted, fun, and such a good presence that it hurt to lose him when he died. And Mike, the helicopter pilot who swoops in to help, was such a high point ‚Äî which made it sting all the more when his helicopter went down. Ada never clicked with me, but it's fine, i'm not the audience here, she's the seductive character for the boys. And the rest of the characters more than made up for it.

What really seals it is the mix of atmosphere and action. The setting is eerie and tense, but the game still finds ways to be fun and over-the-top. The bosses are wild and memorable, and even for someone like me who usually hates boss fights, I found myself enjoying them. The resource management, puzzles, and survival tension are still there, but RE4 layers in this crazy, entertaining energy that makes it unlike anything else in the series.

Thanks Capcom! :)

The Good:
- This game definitely speaks to the Chud fantasy, Raccoon city has fallen, billions have become infected and you're the President's top guy to save his daughter. 
-The President's daughter is very likable, Although her AI could've been better.
-The atmosphere and visuals are top notch. A spooky rustic Spanish town infested by a plague that has turned them into mindless cultists.
-Gun play is fun
-Leon is a cool, likable and an interesting character, And I Like his character development from a naive young cop in the 2nd game to a hardened special forces unit we see in this game.

The bad:
-Everything about Ada Wong is frustrating, She is an annoying girl boss and adds nothing of value to the story. She has as much personality as a plank of wood and is nothing more than the result of garbage feminist wokery garbage that's all too common in video games nowadays. I'm glad they didn't try a romantic angle between her and Leon; although it is somewhat implied, A Useless character except to throw a bone for the rice bunny lovers
-Some enemies are bullet sponges
- This game puts various characters in life and death situations, Why are they quipping like this is some cringe Marvel movie? dumb writing and unnecessary, It breaks immersion at times.
-Leon also has quips, I'll admit 2 of them caught me off guard and cracked me up but still it has no place in a game with such a serious tone
Still, RE4 and RE4 Remake are the best games in the franchise.

Alright, story time.
I can't remember if I ever reviewed the original on here, but I did have some choice words about it back when I played. Not the biggest of RE4, just opening with that as a preface.
Naturally, I had to play the remake, and my judgement is so:
If this had to be compared to one of the previous two remakes, it's more akin to Resident Evil 2 Remake (rere2 for short). It contains most of the story beats and visuals, but often lacks context for them and are just essentially member-berries. Though the game does have some general gameplay improvements from original, it also has glaring flaws, such as the RE Engine games' lovely "stand still to shoot or your accuracy goes down by 90%", and the most absolute brainlette of a decision to make the effing survival knife breakable AGAIN, *as well* as take up *three* slots in your briefcase. Even better is that the game really expects you to have that knife handy at all times despite it shattering every two seconds, so I get killed by things like the spiny regenerators and the game has the gall to go "oi m8, you need to use your knife when they grab ya or they'll kill ya instantly" and I'm just like "OH, REALLY? JUST. USE ME KNIFE? GEE, I WOULD DO THAT, BUT THE THING FUCKING BROKE AND THE DEMON GRABBED ME FROM ACROSS THE ROOM AND I COULD DO LITERALLY NOTHING TO COUNTER IT BECAUSE THE SYSTEM DOESN'T SYNC WITH ITSELF".
Now, unlike last time, however, I don't think this was made to sell the Infinite Ammo DLC‚Ñ¢ as enemies aren't bullet sponges like they were in ReRe2, which is good because the game likes to drown you in enemies, which halts the game to a stop because everything group pulls in an area and you can't do anything until you've killed all 20+ Ganados or whatever. Plus, they brought back the bowgun for this game (but not rere2 for some reason?), and it's GOATed because of all the enemies that come often out of literal nowhere (had moments where my back was to an empty room and I still get ganked because the game director spawned some goobs in there), letting you reclaim your bolts...if the game doesn't glitch out. I've had plenty of instances where if you shoot an enemy in their death animation, the bolt is just erased from existence.
The game has a lot of segments and context for things cut out, I've noticed. The entire gondola segment, the canyon monster, Salazzar becoming a monster out of nowhere with his one minion he fuses with in the original just ...not appearing in this episode (he was previously seen in the throne room scene). like, half of the final island.
On a final note, the voice acting. Generally, it's pretty decent. Leon's spot-on, Luis is good, Ashley...doesn't sound like Ashley, but her new voice is okay. But Ada Wong? No. To call her VA a Voice Actor would be too generous. Whoever was hired to voice her should not return. The best I can describe is that got someone's disinterested Aunt into the recording booth and had her mumble out her lines because they ran out of budget or something. Every line Ada utters is just merely read out. There is no acting. And she doesn't even *remotely* sound like Ada Wong.
I guess you can she sounds....wong.

Gloria a las plagas! Pero vivir es playing the original other than this soulless husk.

This remake, despite looking somewhat decent in graphical terms, completely fails to capture the atmosphere, overall vibe and horror elements that the original had. The art direction from Resident Evil 4, which is responsible for the absolute masterpiece it used to be, just wasn't followed. The remake doesn't replicate the ambiance, foggy weather, dirty looking aesthetic. Lighting is just modernized, visuals look realistic rather than stylistic. Lacks the tension we used to feel back in the day even when there were no enemies around. Basically enshittified Resident Evil 4... The original has small things nobody appreciates until they're gone. Crickets, wind sounds, sometimes even weather effects aren't present at the same locations, not immersing the player as much as before.

If there's positive things to say about the remake, is that it's superbly well optimized. There's some CPU problems, but it runs pretty fine at 60fps on slightly older PC builds few years older than its release date. There's tons of graphical settings to mess around with, so getting good performance shouldn't be impossible. Separate Ways was a welcome addition, adding further lore and gameplay, as Ada this time. Nothing to write home about however. Movement is leagues better than in the OG: WASD controls rather than tank controls truly make a difference.

Back to how it plays out: certain moments and many cutscenes were changed to accommodate the new level redesigns, sometimes taking away from RE4's personality, like Leon having a cut on his cheek after the Krauser fight for the rest of the game, which doesn't happen here. Several location edits were done, not necessarily for the best, but rather just for the sake of being "remade", to better showcase the technological leap. Again, not exactly to improve on the original.

RE4R just isn't worth it. It's universally loved, but at the end of the day, it's nothing but mob mentality gobbling up fan service.

Combat is the highlight: smooth gunplay, a satisfying variety of weapons, and boss fights that are both fun and challenging. Even the breakable knife, which I disliked at first, eventually grew on me.

The story is solid, but the atmosphere and map design really stand out. Each region feels distinct, and the side quests and shooting range add variety, even if they aren‚Äôt particularly memorable.

This remake leans more into action than survival horror. It‚Äôs fun, but it sometimes reduces the tension and resource management that define classic survival horror.

Overall, this remake strikes a great balance between action and survival horror. With its thrilling combat, memorable enemies, and impressive atmosphere, it‚Äôs easily one of the best Resident Evil experiences ‚Äî 8.5/10.

Resident Evil 4 was already a legend, but this remake doesn‚Äôt just honor the original ‚Äì it redefines it. I went in with high expectations, but what I got was an unforgettable experience that reminded me why I fell in love with survival horror in the first place.

From the moment Leon sets foot in that eerie Spanish village, the game grabs you with its atmosphere. The lighting, the sound design, the way the environments feel alive ‚Äì everything builds tension and keeps you on edge. Every creak of a floorboard, every distant scream, every glimpse of a shadow makes you second-guess whether you‚Äôre ready for the next step forward.

The characters feel richer and more human this time around. Leon is still the witty, unshakable agent we know, but now he carries himself with a little more weight, more weariness. Ashley is no longer just an escort mission ‚Äì she‚Äôs a believable, sympathetic companion. And the villains‚Ä¶ grotesque, unforgettable, and terrifyingly real.

Gameplay is a perfect balance of action and horror. Gunplay feels punchy and rewarding, inventory management is just as tense and satisfying as ever, and the redesigned encounters are brilliantly paced. Every fight feels like survival ‚Äì not just shooting. The remake respects the DNA of the original but modernizes it in a way that makes it feel fresh and exciting without losing what made it special.

On top of that, the visuals are breathtaking. The RE Engine has never looked better, from the dripping rain on Leon‚Äôs jacket to the grotesque details of every monster. The soundtrack hits hard, too ‚Äì haunting when it needs to be, explosive when the action kicks in.

When the credits rolled, I didn‚Äôt just feel like I‚Äôd replayed a classic. I felt like I‚Äôd lived through a new experience that stood on its own, even while paying tribute to the past. Resident Evil 4 Remake is not just a faithful recreation ‚Äì it‚Äôs a masterpiece of modern horror.

If the 2005 original was a revolution, the 2023 remake is the cathedral built on its battlefield.

Funny Things:
If a creepy villager whispers ‚Äò¬°Detr√°s de ti, imb√©cil!‚Äô, it is already too late you are about to get yeeted across the village square like a sack of potatoes.

The Merchant is the only man in Spain who can sell you a rocket launcher in the middle of a swamp at 3 a.m. and make it feel normal.

Ashley‚Äôs ‚ÄòLeon, help!‚Äô is the official soundtrack of panic.

She can‚Äôt climb a ladder without assistance, but can survive being carried off by a 7 foot cultist like it‚Äôs a casual Uber ride.

In RE4, you will break into a villager‚Äôs home, steal their ammo, eat their eggs raw, and still feel like you are the victim.

Nothing says ‚Äòsurvival horror‚Äô like stopping mid-battle to solve a sliding tile puzzle while a parasite monster waits politely.

Phenomenally fun, packed with content, somehow gets even better on subsequent playthroughs. With the way it carries over from one difficulty to the next, I've never been more satisfied with NewGame+. Difficulty ramps up massively, but there are crazy powerful weapons and upgrades that carry over with you, making it an entirely different experience. Once you start aiming for the best unlocks through the greatest challenges (e.g. beat the game with only pistols and knives), the challenge comes back to meet your newfound mastery. None of this is unique to this entry, but I do feel its done best in RE4.

Is it my favorite Resident Evil game? Maybe. That is a very hard question, which is really just a testament of how great the franchise is as a whole. It isn't the scariest, it's a complete re-imagining that somewhat lacks the benefit of nostalgia, and is overall very different from the original, let alone the other RE games. And yet I‚Äôll say that it is probably the most entertaining.

This being a horror game with an action-star protagonist is pretty impressive as it maintains the horror, creepiness, and grotesque perfectly well. Didn‚Äôt scare me like some of the others, but it left a lasting impression to say the least. Every night I am awoken in a cold sweat, rattled by the sickening sound that lingers in my inner-conscious from now unto my final breath. The sound of Ashley Graham. ‚ÄúLEON!‚Äù

The Resident Evil 4 Remake is not just a faithful reimagining of a beloved classic ‚Äî it's a triumph in modern game design that masterfully blends nostalgia with innovation. Capcom has managed to preserve the heart-pounding tension and iconic moments of the 2005 original, while refining every aspect to meet today‚Äôs standards.

From the opening village ambush to the chilling depths of the castle and island, the game is a non-stop thrill ride. The graphics are stunning, with richly detailed environments, realistic lighting, and character models that breathe new life into Leon, Ashley, and even the nightmarish Ganados. The atmosphere is thick with dread, and yet, it never loses that pulpy charm that made the original so memorable.

Gameplay-wise, everything has been tuned to near perfection. The over-the-shoulder shooting is tighter and more satisfying than ever, and the addition of modern mechanics ‚Äî such as stealth options, improved knife combat, and crafting ‚Äî enhance the experience without diluting the essence of what made RE4 great. The pacing is spot-on, balancing action, exploration, and suspense beautifully.

Leon Kennedy‚Äôs witty one-liners are still intact, and Ashley has been reworked into a much more engaging and less frustrating companion. The story is more cohesive, with deeper character moments and a darker, more grounded tone that still knows when to lean into its campy roots.

Whether you're a die-hard Resident Evil fan or a newcomer to the series, Resident Evil 4 Remake is an essential experience. It respects its legacy while confidently stepping into the future ‚Äî a benchmark for how remakes should be don

THIS game is the leading champion of how a remake should be ! Everything was improved !! Let me break it down:
- Graphics - let's get the obvious out of the way. the models, the lighting, the background all dialled up. For some odd reason, my brain thinks it's not so different, until I watch comparison videos.

- the characters: this is my biggest surprise. Yes they've improved with new scans of real life models, but here is the thing; the writing improved too ! Ashley in particular, becomes prettier and more likeable. She shouts and screams in fear realistically, like you just want to protect her. She's vulnerable, but courageous also. OG Ashley was all over the place, imo. Too bratty. The new voice actress did a muuuch better job. Same goes with Leon and Luis, I think.

- the writing: the core of the story is the same, but how it plays is a little different. It's cinematically improved, not sure how else to describe it. Things make more sense here, and less campy.

- gameplay: the OG was already revolutionizing this aspect. The remake is simply perfecting it. Some extra stuff like the new parry system adds flavour to an already yummy dish. New puzzles, completely redesigned areas are all welcomed. The suplex is back, baby !!

10/10 !! extremely highly recommended

An absolute masterclass in how a remake should be done. This game is a near perfect love letter to the original, retaining what made RE4 so special whilst modernising the gameplay, characters and fleshing out the story. Considering how beloved RE4 is the devs have gone out of their way to really show their love for it also, the music is familiar, many of the challenges are named after Leon's cheesy one-liners, and the locations have been so lovingly recreated that the whole game feels totally familiar whilst still presenting a brand new experience.

It's impossible to say if this is better than the original due to how influential it was, but this version is absolutely the best way to experience RE4 in the modern day. An absolute 10/10 masterpiece.

I have a lot of nostalgia for the original RE4 and due to that I was initially a bit reluctant to try the Remake, both because I felt that a remake is not necessary and that I didn't want to be biased towards it. However, after finally having played it, it's a great game.

The atmosphere is in-line with Resident Evil 2 Remake (but of course, more action focused) and the gameplay is very well-designed. The island is just as menacing and iconic as it was in the original, and almost every single thing is kept intact. The inclusion of modern controls does make the game more fun and less clunky to play, which is something I appreciate. And the graphics, of course, are amazing as usual with the line of Remake games in the franchise (yes, even RE1R).

I do have a few issues with the new personalities for the side characters/antagonists and some of the visual design choices - but they're minor and don't get in the way of how fun this game is. I wouldn't recommend playing the original over this to newer players and can accept it as a decent replacement.

I wish Capcom could go back and just release an expanded version of RE3R because they almost had a perfect streak here.
great

After 70 hours of playing, yeah I had a lot of fun.  Been a long time since i've done multiple playthroughs for a game.
Its a lot more action-heavy, RE4 was the one that started the trend of Resident Evil games becoming more action as time went on before they pivoted back to horror in RE7.   But man is this game still fun to play.   Great pacing, great action, great atmosphere. 
There's something charming with them being more serious compared to the original RE4 but still keeping some of the more outlandish stuff.  Like Leon occasionally roundhouse kicking a villager or doing flips.  He's still makes his dry humor one-liners but in a more "welp, time to deal with this BS" kind of delivery which I like.
Leon is basically a Metal Gear character at this point.   Some parts of the game even reminds me of Metal Gear, especially in the final chapters when you reach the Island. 

I would sometimes play the original 05 version, mainly just to see the differences and how much as changed in the almost two decade difference, thats crazy to think about.
There are some aspects that I wish they kept in but I think the remake did an outstanding on job at expanding some areas that were lacking in the original or replacing with something else to help with the pacing more.  
Music however is a lot more better in the original.  Luckily there is an option to enable classic sfx, mainly for menu interface and music.  

Mods also definitely helps with replayability.  Favorite one, and one I highly recommend if you're looking to go through another playthrough, is the classic RE4 laser mod available at Nexus.  Makes the gameplay feel like a hybrid of classic and modern RE4, just make sure to pair with the classic enemy stagger mod as well.

This is definitely one of the rare times I'd call a game 10/10.  Really curious on how they're gonna handle an RE5 remake, if there's even gonna be one.   Though lots of rumors that Code Veronica might be the next one to be remade.
Best RE ever made/remade. This was awesome. Make sure to get the separate ways DLC.
