The best remake out of Resi 2, 3 and 4. This is an absolute masterpiece and a must have in any Resi fan's collection.

Gameplay is slower than the OG Resi 4 which I prefer as it makes you more vulnerable and makes timing more important with reloads, parries and dodges. Boss and mini boss fights have been tweaked. Most remain similar but some got an overhaul such as Ramon, though I have to admit I kind of missed the OG Resi 4 Ramon fight and the setting for it. The strong threat fights as well as the requests for the merchant were also a nice touch. However having the Punisher only purchasable via the Spinels challenge system when it was free in the OG Resi was a bit of a kick in the teeth.
The weapon system is brilliant as each gun feels like it has its own merits and it doesn't mean guns you get later are a straight upgrade to the ones you have, I'm looking at you Resi Village. The one exception was the handcannon which is 1/3 bonus weapons you can get. It's the hardest to unlock and is a straight downgrade to the Broken Butterfly in my opinion and isn't worth the effort.
One of the few complaints I had with the OG Resi 4 was atmosphere because along with the faster pace gameplay and quick time events with fairly comfortable reaction windows it felt like the Resi franchise was moving away from horror and more towards action hence Resi 5 & 6. This remake along with the Resi 2 & 3 remakes and Resi 7 solidifies the direction of travel is horror (Can't wait for Requiem) and I'm here for it. The general tone is darker and along with the gameplay that leaves you more vulnerable it really gets the heart pumping. Every time a scene plays to introduce a new special enemy you can feel a shift in the pixelated air and you're excited and dreading what's around the corner. 
The graphics bring a legendary entry in the Resi franchise to a more modern era. The RE Engine has shown its time is not up which given it was created in 2014 is an incredible feat. Lighting which is so important in horror games was used to great effect where even during the day you can feel the tension and in dark scenes the game came into its own. Sound design was on point, again another vital part to any horror game, with each creak and screech making your heart skip a beat. 
This review is quite late so the game will be on sale fairly often with each season so the pricing is a bargain when it's on sale but for the OG price of ¬£34.99 this game was still more than worth it and I can't recommend it enough. You simply won't regret it.

If you made it this far thanks for coming to my Resi TED talk and remember to aim for the head.

The pacing in Resident Evil 4 is nothing short of masterful. It constantly shifts gears, moving players from unsettling rural villages to towering gothic castles and finally to eerie, militarized islands. Each new location introduces fresh enemy types and challenges, ensuring the gameplay always feels dynamic. Set pieces like the tense cabin siege or the unforgettable lake monster battle raise the stakes at just the right moments, delivering thrilling bursts of action without ever overwhelming the steady flow of suspense and strategy.

Great remake of an already great game.

RE4 is a fantastic experience, being revolutionary back in the early 2000s, and this remake stays mostly true to its vision while streamling some of the less enjoyable sections and adding some. Some content is missing but is part of it is restored in the Separate Ways campaign DLC, which I also recommend getting.

The dialogue has better writing for the most part but it lost some of the camp and more edgy lines by Leon, a sign of the times unfortunately.
The soundtrack serves the game well, being a mix of the original with new tracks, though the lack of ambient music/soundscape for moody scenes (such as the church during the thunderstorm) definitely makes it lackluster compared to the original in this regard. It's something you'll probably won't notice at first but comparing the two it's evident this remake is more "quiet" overall.

Tech-wise, it looks good but requires a decent PC to run well and not be an eyesore (RX 6600/RTX 3060 for 1080p at least). The dithering is still present as well as some aliasing that TAA can mask a bit at the cost of sharpness. Speaking of sharpness, FSR 2 has a horrible implementation here, looking softer than FSR 1 and Interlaced. If you're looking for more frames, I suggest switching rendering mode to Interlaced (Capcom's version of checkerboard rendering) which does a decent job and looks better than previous RE Engine games in the series.

This was an amazing game. 
Loved every second of it from the start. RE4 is what you get if you mix the puzzles & backtracking of RE2 and the (sometimes over the top) action of RE3. 
What's especially good about this game is the total package that you get. The level design, the story & characters, action sequences. The only thing I think that could be better were the puzzles. They're not as braindead simple as the ones in RE3, but they are a bit too easy sometimes. But besides of that one little critique, this is (again) some fantastic work delivered by Capcom.
RE4 remake is one of the greatest games I've played in a while and will absolutely get a spot in my top 10 of all time.

One thing I do not like about this game is point of no returns. If you miss something you will have to do a mandatory NG+ which sucks.

RE4 I just started CH.6 and so far it's different from the past RE games. Which is why I said survival horror up above. RE2 RE3 and some RE games from before aren't like this one. This one still has puzzles and quirks from the past games, but it's so far different. This is based on all the way to the end of CH.5. It may or may not shift back to the usual. 

So far it's a solid 8/10. -1 for the no point of return. For some sections of the game there should be ways to go back at least. The castle area kind of did that. 

The game is a solid 8.5. Part of the game made me not sell stuff so I can upgrade, once you get bugs that drop blue jewels keep at least 3 (5 if you feel it's too little) on hand and sell the rest, trust me, like seriously. You will have so much more room to work with on upgrading your main weapons. 

The quest tracking was üí© there was 1 medallion left and I couldn't go back, it literally didn't even show. I didn't get achievement for it. I don't really care about achievements, but that, it just annoys me. 

Performance, all the way to the end of 15 was üëçliterally no problems. I'm surprised my system handled this game on 1440p with pretty much high on all. not max. CPU: 5800x GPU:RX 5700
However, during chapter 16 the last chapter my performance started dropping. I was getting frame drops/stutters whichever. Not the whole time, but frequently, both cutscenes and non cutscenes. 

This brings the game to an 8.5. The achievements and that performance drop didn't affect the score. The DLC will not bring the score up, but will stay as 8.5/10. On to playing it. It didn't improve the score, it would actually make me drop the score if I were to include it as a whole game. The upgrades, lockouts in areas and somewhat progression in areas, weapons and etc. was not the best imo. (quests were kind of üí©) The quests actually felt like they ruined the pacing, the pacing was actually not the greatest besides the quest. I did like Ada though.

Overall, I did have a good time with the game. A change of pace and besides the stutters on the game towards the end (which may have been my system screwing up) the performance was amazing. (Will be doing a small break and getting back to it soon) RE5 is next!

This game is a masterpiece. The combat is fluid, intense, and deeply satisfying. Parrying with a knife, stealth takedowns, and smart enemy AI make every encounter feel fresh and strategic. The environments are jaw-droppingly gorgeous and haunting. Every shadow, every grotesque creature, every flickering torch feels meticulously crafted. The sound design from the chilling ambient music to the terrifying Ganado whispers are pure perfection.

Ngl, I've always found RE4 a it overrated as in, if it's a 8-9/10 game, people treat it as a 10/10 game. Although it's a good game, at the end of the day, the controls are clunky and it's dumbed down for "the modern audience". And Ashley is still the worst companion ever...

Compared to the OG, the plot is toned down a lot but it's still the same old goofy plot. And personally, this is the main reason why I don't like RE4 as much as others because this is the exact entry where the plot in every campaign has started to get too goofy.

The controls are very similar to those of RE2 Remake and I loved them back there as they are a perfect fit for a survival-horror title. However, since RE4 is more action-ey, they just fall clunky for an action game. The aiming is slow. The movement and running are slow. Th FOV isn't great. Parry and dodge windows are tight... It rather felt like playing DSR in 2025 but with guns instead. In addition, they should have implemented parry and dodge mechanics properly instead of relying them on QTEs.

Lastly, the dumbing down all over the place felt like an insult to my intelligence like the infamous excessive usage of yellow paint (which became a meme over time) and giving vocal hints as soon as you go in a wrong direction or try to open a different door (just like GoW 2018)

This was a very well-made remake of an influential classic. I must admit that way back when there were rumours of this game, I was not really excited about the idea of a RE4 remake as I thought there wasn't much Capcom could do with this game like they were able to with 2 and 3, but after playing this, I'm glad to see that I was proven wrong. This is a remake that offers an exciting experience for both newcomers and RE veterans.

The remake feels both distinct and yet familiar, providing a unique experience from the original. It offers a lot of useful updates and new QOL to the game (especially with Ashley), and plenty of additions that add to the meal. The graphics, environment and art style are beautifully designed, and it really feels like a breath of fresh air. The new areas were well-designed, and I enjoyed my time exploring them. Combat has also been updated, and it's awesome; it feels both intense and very satisfying when you fight enemies.

Capcom knocked it out of the park with this remake.

I now understand why people worship this game out of the other games in the series. Now if i had  to compare to RE2 remake:

Inventory System: I would definitly go for RE4's inventory system. It feels less punishing to save ammo, the key items are seperated from the inventory which feels satisfying. You almost never run out of space unless you are explicitly trying to do so.

Exploration: This game clearly has more exploration than RE2R has. whenever you see a yellow box, you kick it. It's that simple yet so satisfying to do. Puzzle-wise, RE2R has more puzzles and they feel more rewarding. The game pushes you to keep exploring and running back and forth to unlock previously locked places. (Which could have been a better experience if running wasn't so slow)

Combat: RE4R definitly wins the cake here with much dynamic and diverse combat mechanics. An actual dodging system i wished RE2R had. Ran out of ammo? no problem you can just craft more. 

Story: Both games satisfied me with their stories, however... RE2R felt repetetive after finishing Leon's story.

Overall, i liked both games and fell in love with the series. Hopefully i can finish the series before Requiem launches.

Even better than you remember it being. I've completed the original Resident Evil many times, from the original GameCube to Wiimote controls .... every other version was great, but this is the best one. They really took their time and gave it polish. There are so many memorable setpieces and it's a blast from start to finish, from fighting jaws to the minecart shootout. Some of the new sidequest stuff is pure filler, but it's optional and whenever I felt like it was about to slow down the pace of the game I skipped it. Stopping right before a boss fight to go chase down 4 rats? Nah actually, I'm good.

The game is more scary and atmospheric than the original, with more detail put into certain sections and puzzles. Gameplay wise it feels very similar, but with the modern polish you'd expect; You can move and shoot now, and the knife plays more of a role with knife parrying, but newly-limited endurance. Overall it's a fresh spit-shine on a classic game that makes it worth playing through again. If you've never played the original? Then you're in for a treat.

RIP ballistics

Its the GOAT. If you know, you know. Game runs incredibly well, everything cranked to the max, including ray tracing. I am running a 4090 though, but even without ray tracing it looks incredible. Enough has changed that more than once I was caught off guard, but then again, I hadn't played through the game in probably 15 years. A lot of the same old tricks that worked in the OG still work here. If you've never played a Resident Evil game, or are sensitive to scares, this is a great one to start with. The RE2/3 remake are quite "scary". This one is just right. 
Everything feels really well tuned. The old tank controls are gone and replaced with something a bit more modern. There are some changes I didnt love, but got used to, like the knife having durability that diminishes and breaks after so much use. Another thing that was hard to get used to was the fact that your aiming reticle is no longer a laser sight, and is replaced with cross hairs. You still have the same kind of recoil and what not, but now you have to deal with bloom. 
Either way, I quickly got past both of those two "issues" and very quickly forgot about them. All in all, 10/10 game. 10/10 for a remake/remaster.

[b]Kinda meh[/b]
Of all RE remakes, RE 4 is definitely the most boring. 
It is nice to complete it a few times, but when the game locks rewards behind specific difficulty and specific setting and specific condition, forcing you to beat it multiple times, I genuinely lose interest. 
I made 7 main campaign playthroughs and 3 for its expansion. A bit too much. But hey, [u]if you don't care for the achievements, you'll play less! [/u]
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3547107929
[b]The best of 4th is...[/b]
Second part of the game - is the Castle with its dungeons, cannon siege and possessed knights episodes. Mini puzzle games with tiles, fancy giant halls and statues here and there... Hence the title of my review. 

I got a bit fed up with the Village part, where everyone grabs me and stabs me (certified skill issue, I admit). Dogs and bear traps were fun though. Them and checking trees for hanging lanterns with precious gems, exploring corners of a lake for extra resources. 
But once you reach the castle and have to face blind enemy with long metal claws, have to survive lurking knights and then travel across the mines, oof, yeah, it instantly outshines everything before and that's easily the best part of the RE 4.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3551629741
There's also a third part. The island with its regenerative enemies, giant biomass and QTE (sort of) fights. Hmm... the same place felt more tense in the Separate Ways, but the main game you can easily stealth you way in. Which makes it 1 memorable area out of 3. Castle > Village > Island. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3548959731
[b]Lore is getting out of hands[/b]
For me RE universe was always about just T-virus. But then RE Village introduced mold. Now, RE 4 disclosed some amber bugs. *shrugs in oblivion* It's cool the franchise expands, but for me, not a hardcore RE fan, it's getting confusing to follow "who, where, when got infected, mutated and why". All those beings (RE 4 bosses) clearly existed for a long time, yet haven't made connections, influences outside of their small area, nor draw attention to themselves, yet got impressive firepower and gear. Oh well. Not a biggie. 

RE 4 remake is a nice game, multiple replays are certainly for RE fans only. I'm glad I played it, but wish it didn't require so many completions. And why does it look worse than RE Village?

Best remake!

A wonderful experience!

Unlike RE2 and RE3 which relied more on artificial difficulty by limiting your resources (giving you as few rounds of ammo as possible, have enemies that grab you practically automatically damage you...) this game relies a lot more on the action heavy sequences and gives you plenty of ways to kill your opponents as well as giving you ample resources for it. 

The story itself is truly nothing special, all things considered. Luis's involvement and his research on the Plaga and him being a determined force to stop Saddler within his laboratory is probably the best element. The fact Leon got himself out of plenty of situations, but for some he needed Ada to progress is also a nice touch. Wouldn't be a RE story without the best side characters dying, though...

The dialogue is hilarious, not as quip-y and raw as the original game, but still does a great job. 

The game itself looks fantastic, giving a fantastic look to ALL characters and enemies. Lighting is done just right, and despite the heavy focus on action and adventure and less on puzzles and horror, there're still elements that made me spooked and puzzled, particularly the lab where you discover the regenerating enemies, that section without power is fantastic horror, as well as many areas in the castle.

Voice acting is also on point. Some folks aren't a big fan of the Luis or Ada voices but I found them plenty enjoyable and very accurate. 

The game's plenty fun, has TONS of content, and if I ever choose to replay any RE game (which would only happen if I wanted a second, harder playthrough) it'd probably be this game. 

Fully recommended!

I am never buying another mystery holiday ever again. 

Ninety-nine of our great british pound sterling, there was the chance for New York, Reykjavik, Warsaw, Sorrento and I ended up pulling 'Undescript spanish village'

What the frickle frackle?!

Anyways, the luggage allowance was tiny, only enough in my case to pack a gun, some healing spray and a couple of herbs which was bad enough but then the bus to my hotel was cancelled so the police gave me a ride into town. 

Anyways, the welcome was very unfriendly to say the least. The villagers attacked me on the spot and stole my jacket. Some doctor with a chainsaw really wanted to give me a vasectomy and the president of the united states' daughter latched onto me as I was the only other English speaker in the whole town. 

We checked out the local sights together and came across a castle on google maps that was rated 1.5 stars but considering the only other option was drink rusty tap water and get ran through by some crazy Abuela with a pitch fork, we figured it would be better than nothing. 

Major disappointment. The owner must have been home for the summer and let's just say he failed to inform us that tourists were no longer welcome until the fall season. He kept calling me 'Meeester Kennedy' even though my surname is Bobertson. Maybe the last US president he'd heard of was JFK and he assumed the president's daughter was a Kennedy and I was too? 

Anyways, I shot him and he turned into a slime monster so I made a quick slime ASMR vid for my tiktok which killed him. 

Would not recommend.

best game ever remake recommended

TL:DR
This game is amazing, and perfects the original. Make sure to close all other programs on lower end computers in order to prevent crashes. I hate the way you get charms. The graphics can be pretty blurry, but unfortunately that seems to be a trend in modern graphics, like how the original was covered in sepia.

This game is absolutely excellent in nearly every way, and perfects the original, which I say as someone who has actually played the original (granted, on the Wii Xd). 
What the original already did well, this remake improves upon, and where the original faltered, this one at least makes the annoyance tolerable. While the more serious tone is certainly a change from the original, I can't help but feel that this helped the story shine in ways that the original couldn't. There was actual character development and depth in my silly Shooty Action Resident Evil! 
I do have one minor but incredibly frustrating criticism and one major criticism, which are the changes to the shooting gallery and the actual stability and graphical fidelity of this game.

Let this paragraph serve as a warning to new players about this mechanic, though do keep in mind that the rest of the game is still excellent. Basically, the system is a complete crapshoot, and it's entirely possible that you literally won't get anything but the same 3 common charms again and again and again. This is because the charm system isn't random each time you put in tokens, but instead is predetermined upon creating the new save, and only gives 8 charms for each token combination, distributed in linear fashion, and there will certainly be duplicates among any given combination. Also, the combinations using more gold tokens don't get better charms than the other combinations. I got almost all common charms the 4 times I put in three golds, and a legendary and epic, among various rares, from using three silvers. It's honestly impressive the devs managed to make something so inoffensive so frustrating. I do love listening to Ashely and Luis commenting on my performance though :)

This game is extremely intense on your system, to put it bluntly. I basically have just above the minimum specs to play this game, and while I am still able to squeeze some good graphics out of the game, I have to basically close everything else running at the same time to prevent crashes. Actually, I should put this in all caps for the overwhelming majority of you who don't read crazy long reviews. ON LOWER END COMPUTERS, CLOSE OTHER PROGRAMS BEFORE BOOTING. THIS SOLVES SOME CRASHING ISSUES. Even on high graphics settings, though, like most other modern triple A games, can be weirdly blurry, which is a pretty common problem when looking at the ground or dimly lit rooms. This seems to be a cost of business. On the upside, this game presents an incredible breadth of customization options in every facet of the game, and even provides examples of how your graphics settings will affect performance and the way the game itself looks. I adore this feature of the RE remakes, I cannot stress enough how awsome this is and how this should be the staple for all big budget games going forward.

Personally my favorite REmake so far. A reimagining that doesn't stray horribly far from the original, superb graphics, incredibly engaging gameplay, and an Ashley that I generally wanted to protect this time around. Biggest problems to me were the loss of the cheesy action movie vibes from the original and Ada. Ada like most have stated sounds like a plank of wood and portions of the original game have been reworked where Leon no longer goes through them but Ada does instead. I believe everyone should play both the OG and the remake as both offer something unique that the other doesn't. 9/10 with a high recommendation!

This is an incredible remake - I believe that it is the best Resident Evil remake that Capcom has made thus far (and the standards are very high)

Honestly loved pretty much every second of this game - it is really authentic to the original game which I started around a year ago. The encounters are not only action-packed but also terrifying, with the better graphics and new enemy designs creating truly gruesome monsters to fight.

I played the game on Assisted mode (which I regret severely!) and this was great for a first playthrough so I could get a story-focused game, however I think I could've managed Standard at least as the game was ridiculously easy - I would literally kill bosses in 4 shotgun shots.

Of course I also love the original story and all the characters, they really bring the people in the game to life and create some fairly emotional moments - special mention to the merchant who they did a great job at recreating within the game to be his usual dodgy self :)

EDIT: I have now played the Ada DLC ('Seperate Ways') and it is awesome as well! Made sure that I used different weapons in this run like the machine gun! The gameplay is fairly similar and same with the areas, but the different perspective provides enough interest for me :) There were also some new areas and many bosses which were awesome to fight, although I will say that the final boss of the the DLC is largely underwhelming :/ I played on Standard difficulty and this is definitely the best option as it is not ridiculously easy but it's not too hard either. Overall I'd say that this DLC adds to the game significantly!

9/10

I firmly believe that Resident Evil 4 is the greatest video game ever burnt to disc. I played the original at least 12 times when I was a kid on my WII, and this does EVERYTHING that game did but WAY BETTER! The action is perfect, the game is legitimately scary at times, the story is impeccable, the characters are AMAZING.  The puzzles are relatively simple but still interesting and makes backtracking fun and worthwhile. Leon Kennedy makes for a great protagonist, dropping iconic one-liners through the entire game, and still showing a legitimately caring side when it comes to Ashley. The added background with Leon and Krauser at the beginning, is seriously icing on the cake. Every addition from the original to the remake is so well thought out, and the entire game feels similar but is VERY different. I think this game is a MUST BUY, when it comes to games in general.

Resident Evil 4 Remake is a masterpiece that perfectly balances horror and action. The game shines with stunning, highly detailed visuals that bring every environment to life, from creepy villages to dark, atmospheric castles. Combat feels fluid and rewarding, with a variety of weapons and strategic encounters that keep you constantly engaged. The remake also smartly updates the controls and pacing, and its excellent optimization ensures smooth performance across all systems. With a gripping story and memorable characters, this game proves that even decades later, Resident Evil 4 remains a benchmark for the genre.

For the year it came out, the story feels very engaging and the atmosphere pulls you in right away. The graphics are also fantastic for their time, and they still hold up surprisingly well even now.

What I liked most is how the game keeps a balance between action and storytelling. It‚Äôs not perfect, but it delivers an experience that feels unique and memorable. For anyone who enjoys survival horror or just wants to experience a classic reimagined, this is definitely worth playing.

Resident Evil 4: Remake is a Remake of Resident Evil: Dead Aim.

You play as Leon Scott Kennedy, a former rookie in the Raccoon City Police Department turned secret service member for the United States Government. The Presidents daughter is kidnapped by a mysterious cult, and you have to be a bad enough dude to save her! 
Luckily, this time, Leon understands Spanish and can just ask his way around. But it doesn‚Äôt help because the evil cultist guys attack him with axes and knives and other sharp/blunt objects. 
So now, with nothing but 6 bullets, a knife, and the ability of Karate, Leon ventures further into this WORLD OF NIGHTMARES


Resident Evil: Beat Everyone‚Äôs Ass Edition, is a third person action shooter that pretends to be a horror game for maybe the first 40 minutes before you remember you can round house kick people‚Äôs heads clean off. 
You need to understand just how big of a deal the classic Resident Evil 4 was. It became a blueprint for games to come in the future, because apparently no one thought to put a camera over the character‚Äôs shoulder and let you aim with the R button (R1 if you played on Ps2. I don‚Äôt know what the Wii‚Äôs was, A, probably.) 

RE4 mixed high quality graphics with cool gunplay and quick time events that totally weren‚Äôt going to be overplayed in the future. It was this game where you could never take it easy because you could just flat out die in cutscenes if you did. 
Limb based damage was also a thing, shooting dude‚Äôs in the face or the knees set them up for some wicked melee attacks like a spin kick on a suplex. There was also a bunch of unlockables, a handful of completely separate campaigns involving Ada, and other neat stuff to keep you busy like MERCENARIES because they realized they were doing good with the combat and made a mode entirely about the combat. 

So how‚Äôs the Remake? I like it, I think its pretty cool.

I guess. 

Its kind of nostalgic to play, much like the Ganados, I too understand what it‚Äôs like to get kicked in the face by a cop. If I were stupid I would say ‚ÄúIts how I remember RE4 looking.‚Äù but that‚Äôs really dumb because I replayed RE4 in 2018 and before that in 2015 and before that in 2013 and before that in 2010. I remember what RE4 looks like. 

For some reason, the nice shiny graphics remind me of another game called Haunting Ground that came out roughly the same time as RE4 classic, I don‚Äôt know why. It does a good job with fog and other effects, giving the forgotten Spanish countryside this really shitty and dingy feeling, but in a good way. All of the buildings look like they‚Äôre barely being held together, and everyone that isn‚Äôt a regular human looks REALLY gross, which is also a good thing.

This time around, Leon is a lot more mobile, capable of moving while aiming, which is REVOLUTIONARY and I won‚Äôt let you tell me otherwise. Not only that, but Leon can also parry melee attacks and a bunch of ranged attacks as well. Its fun to just go ‚ÄúNope‚Äù when one of the suckers gets too close and then kick him in the face anyway.

Also, you kick a lot of people in the face in this game. 

I like the new Leon. He‚Äôs still that funny action hero type, but now you get to see a lot more of that RPD rookie in him. He‚Äôs more assuring and empathetic to Ashley and other characters, but he‚Äôll still drop a sick one liner after a boss fight.
Its the perfect combo. 

It knows what it is now, doesn‚Äôt try to hide anything you know is coming. The Plaga makes itself known from enemy one, a cutscene that was once an easter egg is now just part of the main story. Instead, it hits you with new stuff, like an open-area boat section for some reason and new twists and turns to keep you guessing. 

And if you really need to know and somehow don‚Äôt know yet. Don‚Äôt worry.
Huey is okay. 

Its not a 1:1 remake, which is nice, it hits you with new stuff, enemies behave differently, you find certain weapons at different points, some characters have bigger roles than they had before. So what IS wrong with it? 

Well, Ada sounds like she wants to see my manager. I get that hiring practices have changed for voice acting because pulling the ladder up behind you is RIFE in industries like this. But you don‚Äôt actually have to hire the first lady to apply for the job, you can still have standards. 
And sometimes I felt like the game dragged on a little longer than the classic version, some scenes feel needlessly longer and events can go on and on. 

Also, there‚Äôs $201 of DLC. Most of it is just cosmetics and cheat-code DLCs for if you‚Äôre stinky and suck at the game. But Separate Ways, which came with the PS2 version of the original and then every version of that onward, is DLC for the Remake, which feels like a cop out. 
Assignment: ADA is also nowhere to be found, and there‚Äôs probably other modes that I just can‚Äôt remember that are missing. Maybe, I dunno. 

U-3 is also just missing, I‚Äôm not going to explain what that is in case you, somehow, haven‚Äôt played RE4, but I liked that fight, I thought it was fun. Quick time events are also gone, outside of some context gameplay parts, if you cared about those then I guess that‚Äôs a problem.

Ballistics are also gone. Unacceptable.

Outside of that, I think its a good way to experience Resident Evil 4. I would still recommend playing the original as well, either before or after the Remake, just so you can get a feeling of how much has changed. 

Game looks good, combat is fun, guns feel good to use, you have a parry now, not much to actually hate. There are probably better reviewers out there that can go into details of why this game is actually doo doo paper, but 99% of the games I review are positive on my curator.

I try not to buy bad games, is the thing.

Resident Evil 4 Remake Review ‚Äì Masterpiece Reimagined

Resident Evil 4 Remake is everything a modernized classic should be. From the moment you step into the eerie village to the heart-pounding castle sequences, every moment is cinematic perfection. The controls are smooth, the combat is tight, and the visuals are jaw-dropping‚ÄîLeon‚Äôs journey has never looked this good.

I‚Äôve just completed the main story with Leon, and wow‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs a thrill ride from start to finish. Each encounter keeps you on your toes, puzzles feel satisfying, and the tension never lets up. Now I‚Äôm diving into Ada‚Äôs separate mission, and I can already tell the experience will be just as gripping, offering a fresh perspective on the story we all know and love.

Verdict

Resident Evil 4 Remake is a flawless reimagining of a legendary game. Whether you‚Äôre a longtime fan or a newcomer, it delivers perfect pacing, intense combat, and cinematic horror.

Score: 10/10 ‚Äì Leon‚Äôs story completed, Ada‚Äôs mission awaits, and it‚Äôs pure survival-horror bliss. üî•üßü‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

I've been skeptical about all remakes recently, especially when it comes to "classic" like RE4.

This one wildly exceeds expectations. I jumped on the Resident Evil bandwagon with RE5, and have always been more into the action portion of the saga. Even though, RE4 became my favorite for the balance it managed to achieve because "spookyness" and "action".

The remake sublimate the formula. It fixes lots and lots of issues the original had (weird pacing, weird architecture, questionable plot points, insufferable NPCs...) while modernizing the graphics and the control (You can shoot AND move now. And you aim and reload like John Wick !) to make a remake that's really better than the original and well worth your money. 

Hell, they even remade the Separate Ways DLC and fleshed it out completely when it left a very bad taste when I played it in the original !

So, yeah. I recommend Resident Evil 4 Remake. I even found myself booting it up for fun just because I love the gameplay, and I generally don't boot up games I finished because of my back log !

Also, it may say I played it on Steam Deck. I did actually play it on a computer running Bazzite with an OLED/HDR enabled monitor. It was one of the few game I felt the investment was worth it.

Is what I would say to capcom even after I got the remake at 50% off because this remake is lacking and boring in the story and action and camp department. Apparently, this remake is trying to take the plot so seriously, that it lost the unbeatable charm of the original resident evil 4. I noticed that they don‚Äôt do jokes and that the characters aren‚Äôt having fun [u] (I mean it is a life-threatening situation but come on, its Leon Kennedy, the superhero of the resident evil franchise aside from Chris the boulder-puncher) [/u]   I noticed that they were taking this remake to be more of a horror thriller when they got chased by the Big cheese and then the bridge exploded, u know, the cutscene before the Big cheese boss fight. The original was more of an action comedy and I really missed that but don‚Äôt get me wrong, I will still keep playing this until I finished it for the nth time because of the level design and the overall gameplay and gunplay but I do wish it stuck more to the spirit of the original

[b] PROS: [/b]

[list] 
[*]  Ashley ‚Äì jesus Christ shes immaculate here, almost rivals the beauty of Lara Croft from the survivor trilogy
[*] Improved level designs ‚Äì the starting areas in the levels were improved, the area after the lake bossfight also seemed to be an open world of sorts
[*] Opening village fight ‚Äì the opening scene where the Ganados burn the Spanish policeman and the ensuing fight was still exhilarating like the original
[*] Good graphics on a 4 gb vram laptop
[*] Parry system ‚Äì the added parry mechanic made the game faster and is probably best played on harder difficulties [u] (I played on hardcore for my first run) [/u]
[*] Gunplay ‚Äì much more smooth and fluid than the original (you can also move while aiming! [u] (The original makes u stand still whenever you aim and is really really clunky by today‚Äôs standards) [/u]
[*] Overall character models ‚Äì ada, leon, Ashley, luis, the main bosses all looked really cool
[*] Side missions ‚Äì made the game longer and that‚Äôs ok because its fun
[/list]

[b] CONS:  [/b]
[list]
[*] Voice-acting: they do a really good job in the acting but it seems that, since the plot is more serious now, they seem muted or dead or lacks charisma and doesn‚Äôt really seem alive 
[*] Mood - It‚Äôs a bit more scary but the original had that campyness to it, like the evil dead film series so I kinda missed that
[*] No door physics ‚Äì in the original, you can shoot holes on doors, and with those holes, you can also shoot the ganados
[*] Miscellaneous cut content ‚Äì  wheres the giant Ramon mech scene? wheres the popstar Ashley costume? wheres the P.R.L 412? wheres the ada's assignment mini game?
[*] the ada dlc shouldve been free since it only takes 5 hrs to finish
[*] Resources ‚Äì why add this? We do not need this but I guess it does leave the player so many choices on what ammo or grenades to craft
[/list]

The Resident Evil 4 Remake has caused a lot of love and hate amongst fans of the original RE4. However, one significant improvement is noticeable in the writing. As entertaining as the original was in action-movie-style environments, the writing always left much to be desired as the storyline did drag on. The Remake turns it to eleven by creating a coherent narrative and dividing parts into more streamlined chapters. (With some much-needed cut moments, although there are a few which are missed.)

In this way, players are encouraged not just to run from one part to the next but to take the time to explore the area, find notes and files, and learn more about the environment they are exploring. It also improves the character development for Leon, Luis, and Ashley (and even unlikely antagonists such as Mendez, Ramon, and Krauser) in a way which fits the slightly rewritten events.

The game's tone is noticeably a lot darker than the original. Even as someone who played the remake before the original, I have to say this doesn't inherently make the game "better" or "worse." The remake‚Äôs decision to use its models and environments through the RE Engine is primarily stunning. (Ashley, Luis, and Ada are the most noticeable to receive makeovers, while even Dr. Salvador and the Chainsaw Sisters remain much more frightening renditions of their appearances). The environments feel stunningly out of a dark fantasy novel and fit the moodier tone of the writing. Additionally, the audio remains crisp much like the original for its time, from the ganados' Spanish dialogue to the eerie ambience of background music.

The addition of stealth, crouching, and, of course, parrying makes combat much more entertaining and, in a surprisingly fun way, personal, as the player can decide how they want to approach chapters or entire boss fights. Enemy types‚Äô AI works more ‚Äúsmartly‚Äù in the remake when attempting to dodge or evade your attacks. The additional abilities to now craft items, store them in an inventory, and, of course, not have to endure as many QTEs make the game sleeker in its combat mechanics. The game also returns to Resident Evil's core by enhancing puzzles to make them slightly more challenging and tense. For example, Ashley‚Äôs section is given an improved makeover, proving that there are moments when the game goes above and beyond to deliver an entertaining final product.

The 2023 version has additional options from challenges to complete, requests from the Merchant (who still serves as a likely fan favourite), unique weapons or extras to buy from points collected, and, of course, charms from the shooting gallery. Like the original, the game gives you the option of additional difficulty levels and new game plus.

However, the remake also has a few flaws. One of the weirdest for a 2023 game has to be the odd glitching effect when enemies behind doors or walls begin phasing through with their weapons. Additionally, items can remain hanging in the air for several seconds before the animation kicks in, and of course, the grainy effect over some models‚Äô facial expressions (without enhancement mods). The cutscenes are remarkable with animation, but they sometimes create an uncanny impact when panning over faces in gameplay.

One major issue I did have with gameplay was Ashley's AI in the remake. While, as a character in the original, Ashley could be a little grating, her AI mechanics were pretty straightforward: she would get behind you in combat or listen to commands to "stay" or "follow," making engaging in battle much easier. In the remake, Ashley suffers from the opposite fate: better writing but arguably more annoying AI. Don't get me wrong‚ÄîAshley‚Äôs AI is much more advanced and an improvement in certain areas (including climbing ladders, locking doors, and even helping Leon), but in close combat, her AI is sometimes akin to a weighed-down anchor.

Of course, the game wants to keep you challenged and multitask, but there's a fine line between strategy and a pure test of sanity when Ashley dive bombs out of a locker in front of a brutal enemy (especially on harder difficulties). As much as I love the improved writing of the game, Ashley's AI wasn't it.

One thing I did notice (much like the original) is that Resident Evil's writing struggles in its final chapters, specifically around the Island. The lack of narrative buildup in favour of big-budget cutscenes and enemies makes going around sections a little tiresome.

Overall Thoughts: Resident Evil 4 (2023) is a remake with a lot of time and effort put into it, as well as a good action game in its own right. It attempts to streamline the original's over-the-top events while still maintaining an element of freshness. Although the game does sometimes suffer a bit with its tonal shift, there are significant improvements in writing, graphics, and mechanics. Resident Evil 4 (2023) is a brilliant game worth replaying.

So I'm sure I'll never hear the end of this, especially since I always allow comments on my reviews, but I hate the original RE4. Yes, I know, but hear me out. RE5 always gets crapped on for turning the series into an action shooter. Well, RE4 kinda did it first. At least RE5 had some kind of connection to Umbrella and Wesker. TLDR: No RE4=No RE6. You feel me? So with that said, I love the remake. It actually feels scary. Yes, it keeps the action from RE4 OG but the tension is so much higher in this remake. And they flesh out the story more so that it connects more with the original games. REZero, RE, RE2, RE3, RE Code Veronica... all of those games feel more like prequels to this remake than Shinji Mikami's original RE4 2005. So, if you are new to the series and can't decide if you want to get the 2005 version or the remake, I'm going to have to recommend the remake. It's just a better sequel and actually has the scares to make it fit more comfortably in the Resident Evil universe.

Resident Evil 4 Remake is a thrilling reimagining of the 2005 classic, following Leon S. Kennedy on a high-stakes mission to rescue Ashley Graham, the U.S. President's daughter, from a sinister cult in a remote European village. I started this game back in late 2023, played through chapters 1 to 9, but life got in the way, and I didn't pick it up again until 2025 to finish chapters 9 to 16. Honestly, I'm a different person now compared to when I started, which makes reviewing this game a bit tricky, but let's dive in.

The story is pretty good, delivering a gripping narrative that follows Leon's journey to save Ashley from a creepy cult. Ashley herself is surprisingly likable, not just a damsel in distress, which adds depth to the plot. The pacing keeps you hooked, and the cult's eerie vibe sets a great tone, even if the game leans more action-packed than terrifying. It's a solid, engaging story that carries the game well.

Gameplay is where it truly shines, it's the meat of the experience. The action is polished and fun, with a great balance of challenge on standard difficulty. It's not particularly scary, probably the least frightening of the recent Resident Evil releases, but that doesn't detract from the enjoyment. The weapon variety is impressive, giving you plenty of ways to tackle enemies, and the enemy diversity keeps encounters fresh. Puzzles are straightforward, avoiding frustration, and the game's length feels just right, not too short, not dragged out.

Visually, the game is stunning. The environments are richly detailed, and the character models are incredibly well-crafted, bringing Leon, Ashley, and the creepy cultists to life. Performance-wise, it runs smoothly even on my older laptop, which was a pleasant surprise. No hiccups or lag, just a seamless experience that lets you focus on the action.

I still have to play the DLC and finish the 100%. I guess that's not happening till 2027 :p 

[b]TL;DR: All in all, Resident Evil 4 Remake is an absolute gem. Whether you're a longtime fan or new to the series, this remake is a must-play ![/b]

Resident Evil 4 Remake is an incredibly enjoyable title that modifies and expands upon more from what the timeless classic - Resident Evil 4 (2005) - had to offer; this makes it a really worthy successor to the original. 

The combat is definitely the highlight of the game with crazy addicting roundhouse kicks from Leon and insane grapple takedowns from Ada will leave you feeling like the most badass person alive. It would not be Resident Evil though if it was not survival horror based; you can feel the game limiting your drops of ammo and throwables, especially on professional difficulty. If Resident Evil 2 focused on absolute nightmares in the dark and dilapidated cramped hallways of the Raccoon Police Department leaving you absolutely frightened to even open the next room while having next to no ammo, Resident Evil 4 throws you in a freaking rural Spanish home in a storm with a horde of crazed Spaniards with pitchforks and torches absolutely hatcheting their way into your safe space until you find a way out. Professional difficulty really brings out the horror of how well can you keep your nerves and rise above the situation with limited resources. See an oil lantern above the entryway? Shoot it down to deny them from encroaching on your space. See a shelf next to a window? better move it to buy you some time. See ladders being placed? Kick it down to prevent yourself from getting overwhelmed. Its nerve wracking and intense, as the game tests how you can make the most of the situation.

Having played both the original and the remake, I can definitely tell that Resident Evil 2 Remake laid the groundwork for Leon S. Kennedy's character progression. From a really naive and highly impressionable rookie cop to a certified BADASS of a special agent. His cheesy one liners from the original that made him so lovable for fans to this day is still alive in the remake! However, on a serious note, he does drop some powerful liners too. The line that really made an impact for me was: "this time, it has to be different." as he tries to save this innocent girl from the cult. I could immediately tell this was not the same Leon that Ada Wong played like a fiddle.

Ada's campaign was really cool too. The game shows how much of an ultra confident and outstanding spy she actually is. At the end of Resident Evil 2 do we only get a reveal that she is actually an undercover mercenary and it is such a delight to see how she works. She still keeps her theme of dress to impress persona in such stressful scenarios, which i personally found comical. Its kinda crazy too how so much of the events that Leon handles in the main story is actually a result of something she throws his way or personally decides to intervene in. Its pretty obvious she cares for Leon even if she manipulates him in this installment, just like in Resident Evil 2.

Luis Serra Navarro is DEFINITELY the character that has received the most expansion compared to the original. In this one, he has a more fleshed out backstory that most players might have missed. He used to live in the game's village with his grandfather who is the town's hunter. His grandfather and the chief took note of his outstanding curiosity and noted he might have become a great scholar if he was not stuck in the village, which is exactly what he ended up doing. Coming back to the village to see the chief and so many people from the village he used to know become crazed fanatics must have been so heartbreaking to him. Its so saddening from the village chief's notes of how he loved the village. He loved taking photographs of the village and was proud of it. It was so wholesome how the villagers were already happy seeing their tools sharp and clean, how delighted they were that their new diesel powered engine for their fishing boats would help them catch fish better and would race them across the lake for sport, as children lay around in a circle to listen to the guitar player like music is exotic in this part of the world. It makes their inevitable invasion by Osmund Saddler all the more bittersweet.

Overall, the game is awesome! Story 10/10 Combat 10/10 Replayability 10/10

I'm a die hard Resident Evil fan. Played most of the games, watched most of the movies, read most of the lore. RE4 2005 was and is still one of my all time favorites. The quirkiness, the difficult battles, the fact the stakes were high but the game didn't take itself too seriously. 

Re4 2005 was and is a love letter to the good old 80's-90's action cheesie action hero genre. Leon saying "Where's everyone going? Bingo?" or "No thanks.. Bro" reminded me of Arnold schwarzenegger in True lies saying "You're fired" before launching the BBG at a building while attached to a fighter jet's missile. 

Leon has the personality of a wet slice of bread now. Ashely is now a generic millenial (like me, boohoo), Ada Wong is a manipulative unlikeable btch... The only character who got an improvement was Luis, but only cuz he has more impact in this game and they KEPT his quirky "good for nothing guy who happens to be quite the ladies man" attitude. 

The combat feels weak. The guns shoot like shit. We don't even get enough bullets to justify a bullet spread like counter strike or any reticle oriented game. 

I tried to like this game due to my love for the franchise. But I won't be finishing it. It is just too boring.

Resident Evil 4 Remake is a greate remake of a legendary game.
It modernizes everything ‚Äî from combat and visuals to character depth ‚Äî while staying faithful to the tone, pacing, and absurd charm of the original. Whether you're a veteran or newcomer, this is essential survival horror.

Pros:

Incredible third-person combat with smooth gunplay and satisfying feedback

Gorgeous visuals, atmospheric lighting, and improved level design

Expanded story and character moments, especially for Ashley and Luis

Smart reworks to puzzles, boss fights, and pacing

New parry and stealth mechanics add variety

High replay value with New Game+, Challenges, and Mercenaries Mode

Cons:

Some iconic lines and campy moments were toned down or changed

Knife durability might annoy players early on

A few boss encounters are less memorable than the original

harder than it needs to be as some area have hordes of ennemies with little to any Ammo

Paid "P2W" DLC in a solo game

Final Thoughts:
This isn‚Äôt just a remake ‚Äî it‚Äôs a redefining of what a remake should be. Capcom nailed it. RE4 Remake respects its legacy while boldly pushing the franchise forward. Action, horror, and cheese ‚Äî perfectly blended.
The most fun of the remakes so far‚Äîless frustrating than 2 and more substantial than 3‚Äîthough the storyline gets worse with each entry.

performance: dogshit, if it got any worse we would get negative framerate. i can run it but anyone using graphics cards before the 40 series should just not even try or get some mod that improves it.

tldr:

Ada as a character is not my cup of tea. I didn't like the "Separate Ways" DLC. Literally backtracking with a bunch of new cinematics with Ada.

Heavily recommend buying and experiencing this journey.

Pure cinematic masterpiece.

Q: Would I recommend?
A: 100%

[+]
1) Highly cinematic visuals
2) Overall good performance
Some traversal stutters, but other than that it's a smooth ride.
3) Great design (characters, weapons, etc.)
4) Excellent sound design
5) Punchy weapon sounds
6) Smooth transitions to cutscenes and back
7) Great character animations
8) Top VA (Japanese)
9) Some popular movie-inspired scenes (Alien, etc.)

[-]
1) Wobbly movement
Leon wobbles to the left a lot.
2) Lighting glitches
Some sudden changes in lighting when moving from one room to another.
3) Censored
Heads do not explode, etc.
4) Yellow paint
5) Some traversal stutters

Conclusion: 10/10
ELLO STRANGAH
Goated Game

Few games manage to take a legendary classic, elevate it in every possible way, and still preserve the original magic. Capcom has done exactly that. Resident Evil 4 Remake isn‚Äôt just a remake ‚Äì it‚Äôs a redefinition of what a remake should be.

The visuals are absolutely stunning, breathing new life into the eerie villages, the gothic castle, and the sinister laboratory with cinematic realism. Lighting, atmosphere, and environmental detail all combine to create a chilling and unforgettable world.

Combat has been reimagined with smart refinements: shooting feels weighty and precise, parries with the knife add layers of strategy, and every encounter feels intense, unpredictable, and deeply satisfying.

The story remains faithful to the original but benefits from stronger writing, improved pacing, and deeper character portrayals ‚Äì with Ashley in particular receiving a more respectful and well-rounded treatment. The balance of horror, tension, and high-octane action keeps you hooked from beginning to end.

Sound design is top-notch, with an atmospheric score and terrifying audio cues that keep you on edge throughout.

Capcom has set a new gold standard for remakes. Whether you‚Äôre a longtime fan or experiencing Leon‚Äôs journey for the first time, Resident Evil 4 Remake is an essential experience ‚Äì intense, polished, and unforgettable.

‚≠ê Final Verdict: 10/10 ‚Äì A survival horror masterpiece reborn.

It's Dope

Overall, the game is a pleasant surprise: it runs smoothly, the optimization is decent, and it's fun to play without any major technical issues. The atmosphere is well-crafted, and some parts work really well.

On the other hand, there are some design choices that somewhat spoil the experience. The garish yellow markings on the crates give the impression that the developers are treating players like idiots, as if we're incapable of exploring on our own. It's a real drag on immersion. Another unfortunate point: the corpses disappear far too quickly. In Resident Evil 2 Remake, the fact that they remain reinforced the heavy atmosphere and the feeling of constant danger. Here, it breaks the tension a bit.

In short, a generally solid and enjoyable game, but one that would have benefited from trusting the players more and paying more attention to these atmospheric details.

I will preface this by saying that original RE4 is one of my favorite games and the only RE game in my experience. I played it in my childhood (I think it was a crappy port with keyboard controls) and I got all achievements in Steam version. I had high hopes for the remake and it did not disappoint.

My first playthrough was on Hardcore without guides, which was pretty difficult. I noticed that combat is generally different from other third person shooters like Max Payne. Since there are very little hitscanners, I‚Äôm free to run around enemies. Even though Leon can now move while aiming, the slow speed reminded me a little bit of original tank controls. Guns feel powerful, and shooting them is great. Speaking of shooting, the shooting range is a mixed bag. Challenges themselves are good but randomized and repeating rewards discouraged me from doing it in consecutive playthroughs. This took 15 hours in game and 26 hours in real life.

I rarely replay games, even more so when it comes to multiple playthroughs, but something about this game really made me want to replay it. I think it‚Äôs a combination of relatively short length, abundance of shortcuts and skippable cut scenes. I was surprised end credits were skippable too, because a lot of Japanese games don‚Äôt let you skip them (Metal Gear Rising, Dark Souls, Yakuza). Anyway, my second playthrough revolved around collectibles and miscellaneous trophies. It took 7.2 hours in game and 13 IRL because I forgot some treasures and had to load back. Some of the points of no return make no sense here.

My third playthrough combined minimalist and silent stranger. Blacktail, Red 9 and Primal Knife were my best friends. This was the only time I didn‚Äôt cheese Saddler with Rocket Launcher and one of two times I didn‚Äôt egg Salazar. 4.5 hours for this run.

Since wanted to optimize things a bit, I combined Professional A rank and Frugalist in one run. I thought infinite RL would make this super easy, and for the most part it did. I only took long term damage against Krauser knife duel and his final form, although I did load saves many times when being hit outside of bosses. 4.5 hours in game, 8 hours IRL.

Ok, whose idea was it made Hardcore S+ and Standard S+ achievements not stack? I chose to bite the bullet and beat Professional S+. I took as many shortcuts as possible (Ashley armor, sunglasses, Chicago sweeper), but it was still tough, especially in Village section. I can‚Äôt understand how people manage do this stuff without these legal cheats. 5 hours in game, 10 hours IRL.

Overall, this was my best gaming experience so far this year. My only pet peeves are that pressing ‚ÄúContinue‚Äù after death doesn‚Äôt reset timer and the aforementioned lack of S+ achievement stacking.

Revisiting Resident Evil 4 once again kinda felt surreal. I wasn't really sure what to expect going into it. I knew that the game was faithful to the original game but also changed and updated the game in some significant ways too. So after spending just shy of 20 hours on my play through is this more remake or remaster? Honestly I feel like its a bit of both.

The first time I ever played Resident Evil 4 was the HD version on the Xbox 360. I had actually played Resident Evil 5 before I got a chance to play 4, beat that game on every difficulty and unlocked everything you could possibly get. And after all that I still sunk another 100 hours into the Mercenaries mode, so needless to say I was very excited when Resident Evil 4 HD got announced. Much like RE5 I would end up playing this game front to back, unlocking everything I possibly could, going for the fastest complete times I could get.

Starting RE4 Remake feels... comfortable, like I'm slipping into a familiar pair of shoes again. The shooting and controls that RE4 became legendary for have been updated and modernized for a whole new generation. I don't want to come off hyperbolic when I say this but there's really no dancing around it: this might be the best playing third person shooter I've ever played. I felt that way back in 2011 and now I find myself feeling that exact way again. Having played RE2 Remake I knew they were likely going to add moving while shooting to RE4 but I did not anticipate the impact that would have.

Leon controls so much more fluid now, easily bobbing and weaving out of the way of enemies and effortlessly popping headshots off on zombies foolish enough to charge you. You definitely do NOT need to fear enemies in this game like you did RE2 Remake. You would think that giving the player that kind of power would impact its ability to scare you but I'm happy to see that isn't the case. RE4 was never really a "scary" game so much as it was an intense one. Each scenario is like a little combat puzzle where the game turns up the heat with more enemies and more enemy types to try and catch you off guard.

I'll tell you right now though despite having so much more control over Leon and often times feeling like an unstoppable killing machine there was one area in the game, or rather one enemy type, that ALWAYS made my skin crawl. No, not the Regenerador, and no not the Verdugo either. Though I will give credit where it's do when the Verdugo first appears he absolutely scared the hell outta me. It was: the Novistadors. Yeah those giant camouflaged flying bugs. The sound they made, the ambient music that would kick in, the fact that they were just EVERYWHERE and very often blending into the environment. I felt like I had to take a shower after encountering these things every single time.

Presentation wise this game is a top tier offering on just about every level. There are very few games out there today that not only look as good as RE4 Remake does but also run as good as it does too. Across my nearly 20 hour long play through my game was running maxed out in 4k and I stayed at a rock solid 120 FPS for most of it. There were definitely some sections towards the end that got a little intense but nothing game breaking or egregious in any way. It's incredible to me that Capcom has been able to craft an engine like this that is so strikingly beautiful and performant off the heels of their last big engine success: MT Framework.

It's been a long time since a game had me up until 6am because I couldn't put it down, but that is exactly what happened to me multiple times with RE4 Remake. Resident Evil 4 was the greatest third person shooter ever made... until Capcom decided to reinvent the wheel.

Resident Evil 4 Remake is once again at the top of the mountain and I'm not sure anyone can knock it down again outside of Capcom themselves.

I haven't played the original, so this review is from the perspective of someone playing this as a fresh experience with no prior knowledge of the story.

The game is fantastic. Another example of how well made some of these new Resident Evil games have been. The story, graphics and gameplay are all top tier.

This one has a bit more of an RPG feel to it than the previous games, which I like. You can see a lot of Resident Evil Village in this game, which I really enjoy. I hope Capcom do more of this in the future as it adds a strategic element to the game with building your loadout and choosing which upgrades to purchase etc. It means you can take on each chapter in a variety of different ways to suit your preferences (and also ammo availability, although on normal difficulty you don't tend to run out).

Some RE purists may not enjoy this as much as RE:2 but that really comes down to personal taste - the enemies are less zombie like and the level design is generally more open than Raccoon City PD etc. but there are moments where you will get closed in. Puzzles aren't as frequent or as much of a focus either, but they are still here.

The remake is a perfect example of what a remake should be. Not only does this feel like RE4 but it improves on it a lot. New puzzles and mechanics. Love the knife blocking, feels awesome. I have played a ton of the original RE4 on PS2 and PC and I couldnt be more happy with the remake. Capcom knows how to make remakes

Holy shit is this game an absolute banger. Back, to back, to back bangers from capcom. The controls are the best I've seen in the series so far except for Ashley, the story is on point, and although the series from now on takes a spin down the action horror genre and strays a bit from the original concept of 'real survival horror'. Having never played a Resident Evil game before, I finally understand what all the fuss is about. This game is a masterpiece with very few things holding it back. 

I was surprised to find its barely a horror game (a good thing for me), its more of an action game with horror themes. The gunplay is very good, especially on a mouse and keyboard, and the resource economy is tight but fair. I very rarely found myself completely starved for ammo/health items, but regularly found myself coming down to my last few bullets. This kept things tense enough to be interesting, but not so scarce that I was stressed while playing. 

The game is beautiful, with loads of graphics options to tweak (though no DLSS which was disappointing and bizarre in 2025). And whats better, it played at 70-100 FPS the whole time on my 3080/R7. They even fixed the HDR issues that plague all Capcom games, meaning I didnt have to use AutoHDR, SpecialK or Nvidia HDR. No crashes, no game-breaking bugs, and no necessary mods to fix basic stuff (except again, should have DLSS).

The story is fine, but god-damn do I love Leon. He's a bad-ass quip machine, and everything that came out of his mouth had me smirking. Ashley is a good character, but her damsel-in-distress gameplay segments SUCK, and are the one thing holding this game back from perfection. I died maybe once before meeting her, and I immediately failed/died 15 times over in the first gameplay with her. 

After playing this, I've discovered a whole new series (and genre) of games to play. I love this game, and I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a 15-20 hour action-horror romp.

The gameplay is polished and fluid, with smooth controls and well-designed characters that make the whole experience shine. The story is straightforward but engaging, and even without much background on Leon, it was easy to get in to it . I also liked the chapter system‚Äîit gave a clear sense of progress and helped keep the pacing tight. The included minigame was fun too, though I think it could have been fleshed out more to really add to the experience. My only real complaint is how difficult it is to 100% the achievements, which can get frustrating other than that It Good.

I didn't play the original so can't speak to its faithfulness, but this was a decent Resident Evil game. It was definitely more action oriented than the classic REs, though. Of all the REs from 7 onwards, I would rank them so:

1) RE2make
2) RE 7
3) RE4make
4) R3make
5) RE Village

[h2]Good[/h2]
- Good length as far as modern games go that aren't endless online games (~25 hours for my non-rushed playthrough)
- Gunplay is all fine and well
- Graphics all good
- While there are no side games that I could see like in previous entries, the shooting range serves as a minigame and I found it far more fun than the bonus game modes in the other REs. Not just kinda fun, but also unlocks rewards for your playthrough and you don't have to quit story mode to play it. I did have to watch walkthroughs for a couple though.
- Decent variety of locations
- While it wasn't addicting/bingeworthy, I found it fun enough to keep chipping away at over a period of months
- The damsel in distress was surprisingly not annoying

[h2]Bad[/h2]
- Addition of stealth knife kills is appreciated, but stealth as a whole is untenable in this game; crouch system isn't really meant for hiding just going under obstacles, so you crouch behind a small wall and it doesn't matter, some villager on a roof spots you and yells and the whole area comes at you, and they spot you from pretty far away
- Usually in these games if you haven't done something the first time you've gone to an area you come back to it later in the game to finish, so there were sidequests I didn't do straight away. As it turned out most of them you do have to do straight away because you actually don't come back to these areas in later chapters. Occasionally the trader will comment "Make sure you finish all jobs before you leave" but often by that point it's too late because a scripted event where something collapses and blocks an entrance has occurred and you can't go back to do it. Even after I got used to that happening and vowed to do all jobs as I came across them, it didn't work; there was one late game job where you had to destroy all the medallions, but I simply couldn't see two of them from any of the positions I could take in the area, so I figured "Okay I must get a better vantage point to see and shoot them later in the chapter"... nope!
- I know you don't want every game to be the same but this one does not have a spooki sequence where you have to avoid a scary mfer slowly coming for you like RE2, RE7 or even RE8. Lame guy chasing you out in the open while villagers shoot arrows at you doesn't count, doesn't make you shit your pants.
- This game allows you to use a sniper rifle, which is nice since so much of the game is outdoors and enemies can be spotted a while away; however this is hindered by the amount of invisible walls blocking bullets. An example is like a balcony wall with lots of big gaps in it, try to shoot someone through those gaps and nope... the gaps have an invisible bullet stopping wall in them. You try a slightly different angle just to be safe and nope... now you've just wasted 2-3 rifle bullets which are quite precious in this game, so much so that I often had to reload autosave. Another one is the binocular points in the game, sometimes you look through the binoculars and Leon goes "Look at all those bad guys", I then put down the binoculars and aim with my sniper but what's this? There's now a giant fucking wall in the way and I can't see anyone. As it turns out a lot of the binocular spots are faked, and when you enter them you actually get teleported into the air so you can actually see everything... really clumsy design in a game where you give players a sniper rifle.

[h2]Summary[/h2]
A game that probably won't have you hooked or addicted, with a bit more action than horror overall, but is good enough to play to the finish, and you definitely won't regret if you buy [b]on a discount[/b].

I am currently playing Resident Evil 4 Remake after finishing RE2 and RE3, continuing the series. The graphics are a clear step up, and exploration is interesting since the map doesn‚Äôt show if you‚Äôre leaving items behind, so you really have to check every corner. Exploration 10/10!

Unfortunately, that‚Äôs where my enjoyment ends. The game has introduced a merchant in the middle of a zombie-infested world, turning what should be a tense survival horror game into an arcade-like experience. Buying guns, ammo, and items in the middle of nowhere literally destroys any sense of survival. The zombies feel more like ‚Äúsemi-zombies‚Äù; they can use weapons and are far too easy to kill. There‚Äôs a simple tactic: shoot the head and kick them, rinse and repeat. It‚Äôs not challenging, and it doesn‚Äôt feel like classic Resident Evil anymore.

My only positives so far are the graphics and the exploration mechanic, but the core gameplay and atmosphere have been ruined by the arcade-style design. If you love survival horror, I cannot recommend this game. It‚Äôs a joke compared to the tension and challenge of the previous RE games.

If this is the direction they‚Äôre taking with the game, I hope they eventually make a proper open-world RPG where you can interact with survivors who trade and sell items (similar to Fallout 4 or other open-world survival games). Just imagine how popular it would be an open-world with Resident Evil. However, as it stands, I don‚Äôt enjoy this new trading mechanic; it feels childish and completely breaks immersion.

A pretty good remake of a game that probably didn't need the remake treatment. Combat feels good, dismemberment and gore is fun and satisfying (albeit toned down somewhat from RE2 remake) and the performances of the characters are good. I know the actor who played Ada got a lot of flak but I like her performance here - detached and cool works for Ada - though I do think she could have benefited from better direction. The merchant is a little too chatty for my tastes. 

 The one thing that is  a step down is the mercenaries mode. It's fine but not including Waterworld from 4 is a misstep. It also seems a lot less chaotic than something like 5's no mercy mode and enemy counts are much reduced.  The character loadouts also seem very limiting especially considering the variety you get in RE5. Graphically it is impressive and well optimized like all RE engine games at this point. 

Capcom if you are listening please don't remake 5 - it is fine as it is. If you want to touch 6 - then by all means but 5 is fine just the way it is.

It's a good game but it isn't something I could see myself coming back to either for new game + or more mercenaries.

A solid remake. Be warned however. Much of this games design is two steps forward and one step back in a lot of areas. Many deviations from the original game have made the game play worse and less user friendly. Ashley has been genuinely made worse in every way end of discussion. You can no longer decide where to position her. She will actively work against the effort of the player in virtually every instance by intentionally running into crowds of enemies and in my case actually camp the doors that they use to take her through and end your run attempt many times. This "design choice" almost turned this into a not recommended  review its so bad. The shooting is fun but RNG based in terms of accuracy and damage. Accuracy due to cross hair bloom and damage because of crit chances. Don't even get me started on the abysmal shooting range situation because of it. The game introduces a parrying knife mechanic that is only useful against single enemies because all a group needs to do and will do is offset their attacks to punish the window where the player is locked in the parry animation. The positives are that this obviously looks amazing down to every last inch you can see and sounds incredible as well. The world of the original has been faithfully recreated as perfectly as could ever be expected and the characters have been expanded and improved in every way as well. Give it a try for sure. Overall its made many improvements over the original and has nearly perfected what RE4 could ever be.

Resident Evil 4 Remake is a masterclass in how to modernize a classic without losing its soul. It takes one of the most influential games of all time and enhances every aspect: the story is richer, the characters feel more human, the environments are more immersive, and the gameplay has been refined to perfection.

The atmosphere is darker and more intense, the pacing is spot-on, and every encounter feels even more dynamic thanks to smarter enemy AI and expanded mechanics. The combat is fluid and satisfying, with just the right balance between survival horror tension and action-packed firefights.

It is easily one of the best remakes ever created, rivaled only by Resident Evil 2 Remake in terms of quality and respect for the source material. Capcom has proven once again that they understand exactly how to bring a classic into the modern era without compromise.

If you have never played Resident Evil 4, this is the ultimate way to experience it. If you have, you will still find yourself surprised and impressed at how fresh and engaging it feels.

Score: 10/10 - A perfect reinvention of a genre-defining masterpiece.
