Resident Evil 4 (2005) is a game I like a lot. It's got a lot of fun aspects to it, so much so that I bought it on Xbox 360, Switch, and finally on PC to play on my Steam Deck. I have to have beaten it at least 4-5 times on Standard difficulty, and I regularly replay it. I actually first played it in roughly 2016, so it wasn't a strictly nostalgia thing as to why I love it so much.

I write that preface to say that I [b]absolutely[/b] HATE this Remake, only two hours in. I'll break it out into my personal, somewhat subjective Pros and Cons list,

Pros
1. Absolutely gorgeous - the game is graphically tremendous, looking visually fantastic. This is the way that I imagine most people remember Resident Evil 4 who played it when it first came out in 2005, and it really sticks the landing in that respect.
2. Level Design Changes - the levels have changed dramatically, so much so that it's difficult to compare it to RE4 when evaluating it. The entire game is different. If you played the original and want a twist on the original, there's a reason to play it there. 
3. Leon controls better - 2005 utilizes tank controls. This mean Leon controls independent of the camera and Leon IS the camera. It's difficult to explain, but this game is fluid whereas 2005 is rigid.

Now onto the long list of cons...
1. Reload animations - Worse. Far worse. The default handgun in the original game had a snappy, quick reload. In this game, Leon reloads... Then puts the gun to the side for a second, preventing him from quickly firing off more bullets. 2005's reloads had a small amount of lag time for Leon to bring it back up, but here it feels so weird, out of place, and much longer. They're also not cool anymore, and instead are "realistic" as opposed to being Leon loading two shells to load 6, or just shoving an entire clip of rounds into the Rifle in the original.
2. Weapon balance - In the original game, the Shotgun establishes itself early on as the "Get Away From Me" stick. Enemy in your face? Shotgun it. Chainsaw Guy getting in your face? Shotgun him, knock him back a few feet. The Shotgun here feels so... Whimpy. No longer does Chainsaw Guy get knocked back 6-12 feet from a blast. Enemies don't get knocked around by it. The Pistol itself also feels like it has dramatically less impact on shots. Enemies in the original game couldn't take much before they recoiled in pain, whereas here it feels inconsistent and difficult to line-up shots to do enough to get a melee strike in.
3. Knife Counters - I. Hate. Knife. Counters. I hate them a lot. The Knife in this game is a limited use counter object, whereas in 2005, it was only really used as your (free) melee attack. This limited use knife can be repaired, but it costs LIMITED currency to do so. Don't get grabbed? See point 2, enemies just shrug off attacks and power through anyway. In the original game, you have the ability to quickly mash/twist your joystick to get the enemy off without suffering much (if any) damage whereas here you HAVE to use the limited durability knife to save yourself. I want to use as few resources as possible in my Survival Horror, but you're forcing me into using this thing for a lot of "things," and I don't like it. At least make it free but do dramatically less damage or something.
4. Crafting - RE4 did have some very light crafting elements. Here, your inventory is filled up with garbage resources to combine and I don't like it, I'd rather just have the ammo than two-slot big part bags or one-slot big gunpowder. It feels like it's here because RE8 had it, not because it should be here.
5. Voice Acting - Leon's original voice actor ate up his scenes. He really sold himself as this confident, in control and cool action hero (which was intentional) whereas this Leon is just... Tired. And I get it, Capcom has been making the Remakes substantially more serious, but it's less fun as a result. Leon doesn't sound cool, he sounds bored. 
6. Leon's Quips - After killing enemies, Leon will sometimes shout a quip like "Another one down" or "How many more are there?" It's lame. Leon's quips in the original game were only for cutscenes, their brevity and one-time use ensured they were memorable. Here, their re-use and general lack of "cool" factor makes them very aggravating. 
7. Story - Capcom has been making these things more serious, which I find at odds with RE4's story. RE4's story, much as I love the game, is [i]really[/i] dumb. But the original game played into that, leaned into it being a stupid silly thing as opposed to it being this serious, grounded and gritty game. It made a nice contrast between the more brutal combat (for the time). Here, it's just dour, downtrodden and bored without any sense of levity. It is also at odds with general gameplay things - Leon just has an ammo press to make ammo, Leon can just deflect a chainsaw with a kitchen knife... It's feels very tonally all over the place, with gameplay not matching the more serious nature of the remake's story
8. UI - Gone is the GPS/Computer-esque CODEC Leon used that aimed for immersion. Now it's just RE Engine slop like RE7, 8, and 2. That CODEC helped establish RE4's identity, and this feels far more soulless. It really misses the mark for what made RE4 so cool and fun, and doesn't portray Leon as the super spy as well when it's just a black and white menu with colored objects on it. The Typerwriter UI where it looked and functioned like a typerwriter is also gone completely and it is far worse by comparison. The end splash screen would also show 1-3 pictures of Leon and Ashley that were quite well rendered and fun to look at. This is absent as far as Chapter 3, so far. These things helped make RE4 very unique and flavorful, and their exclusion is painfully noted.
9. Censorship - so far, the line about "Guess there's no gender discrimination here..." is missing and I know the line about the President equipping his daughter with... Ballistics is also missing. Both lines served well to characterize the world and characters within it, and missing both of them is really bad. I genuinely hate this aspect of remake culture where they sand off all the edges and things people might not like. You do a lot of damage to the story and characters by doing that.

TL;DR - I find this remake to be worse in most ways compared to the original. Yes, there are parts I like and think are cool. But if you can stomach the objectively worse controls of the original, I think it's a far better game than the two hours I've played thus far. RE4 2005 felt like a passion project whereas this feels like something they made because they had to after making RE2R and RE3R... And because RE4 is the popular one that sells well.

I'll finish it out because I can't refund it, but thus far, I am hugely disappointed as big fan of the original game.

This is an incredibly high quality remake that exceeded my expectations. I knew the game would be good as the original is one of the best gamecube games I ever played, and the RE2 remake was amazing, therefore I was expecting a lot. I would have accepted a simple graphical and mechanic rebuild and been happy, but wow these devs did so much more than that. Not only does it look and perform amazing, the entire game was redesigned to feel modern. While keeping the spirit and feel of the original, I am not sure there is a single zone in this game that hasn't been redesigned for the better. There is more back-tracking and exploration, more secrets and side-objectives, better enemies and completely redesigned boss fights. This is not just a modern coat of paint and does not lean on its nostalgia at all, you can tell this was a full-scale project at Capcom. This is a truly 10/10 video game experience and delivers in every way possible. If you even remotely enjoy this genre, this game is a no-brainer.

Classic gameplay perfection.

I never played the original or the HD version so I jumped in completely blind. The first chapters are mainly combat oriented; because you only get a handgun and the villagers offer no enemy variety, I found the start quite rough. After reaching the castle the game slowly shifted, there were more puzzles, more guns, more enemies and it turned into the perfect action adventure. Worth at full price.

Resident Evil 4 is hands down the best game in the franchise by a large margin and a huge inspiration point for gaming. I can't believe the original was made in 2005, that blows my mind. No wonder why CAPCOM developers were afraid to do a modern remake, that game was way ahead of it's time and it shows. They still made it and oh boy, this turned out to be one of my favorite games of all times!

This game does everything near perfection, it's such a great experience to play it, it's action packed with lots of powerful and good feeling weapons, lots of tension moments and an amazing narrative story. Unlike the previous entries, Resident Evil 4 focuses less on the horror aspect and emphasizes more on the killing monster stuff. Leon is not the rookie from Resident Evil 2 anymore, he trained for 6 years to become a secret agent for the White House and his mission is to rescue the president's daughter, Ashley. There are a total of 16 chapters and in your first run it will take about 1 hour to complete each one if you are also exploring and I highly recommend doing that because the progress system in this game is so incredibly well done: you collect Pesetas (currency) from killing enemies, destroying crates or finding jewelry and sell it to the merchant. In fact, everything can be sold to get new weapons, upgrades or resources, but making the good combinations will give you the best bang for your buck. The game usually places you in larger open space areas and less inside buildings, which makes weapons like the Sniper Rifle a true powerhouse, but the trustworthy shotgun still packs a punch from close range and the best part is the upgrade system that really makes you feel rewarded for your exploration.

There are also a lot of other small quality of life improvements that really makes this game shine: having a generous inventory space right from the start (arguably the most annoying "feature" of RE2 and RE3), having a dedicated tab for key items (this and the previous one makes it a lot easier to mange your inventory), having prompts for recipees and not needing to memorize them, the kill confirmation once the enemy drops an item on the ground (in RE2 you could literally burst 20 pistol bullets in a zombie's head and unless you got a lucky critical hit, you'd never know if he's dead for good). Another strong point are the DLCs: the Mercenary Mode is just pure fun, you can play it for hours and kill Las Plagas left and right with 8 different characters + Separate Ways got to be one of the greatest additional content in any game, it keeps the same pace from the main game, it expands the story and you get to play from Ada Wong's perspective (it takes about 5 hours to complete). My only negative towards this game is that they didn't keep the silly jokes from the original and they cut some small pieces of content, like Luis Ballistics joke or the war against USA propaganda, so big L to all the whiners that asked for it (I hope they can still remake RE5 and ignore all the snowflakes). That's still a small price to pay for this masterpiece and it doesn't really impact my final verdict.

This game is a 10/10 in my book and I highly recommend playing it at least once for the story and more if you want to challenge yourself. This is worth the full price without a shadow of doubt and I wish I was a fan on release, but at least I can be there for future releases.

Resident Evil is one of those franchises that I was fascinated by as a kid and only got to play when I was older. But despite having many opportunities as a teen, I put it on the backburner. 
As I fell in love with horror I found myself drawn to the new entries like RE7 and 8 but I still decided to give the earlier games a proper shot first.

Although I was dead-set on playing RE4 original, the remake just looked too good to deny and so I went with this first. What a fantastic choice. This is by no means disrespecting the original game, and I still plan on playing it eventually - but Resident Evil 4 Remake is an absolutely enthralling game.
If someone asked me "what is the most exciting game to play as a newcomer to the medium?" I would be hard-pressed to not immediately gush about RE4.

This game is filled to the gills with incredible action and setpieces. It has an incredible pace by which it dolls out encounters and challenges to the player and is by far one of the most expertly paced action titles I've played.
The story is simple compared to other RE games (based on my experience with the franchise) but it really drew me in and I found myself completely immersed and hooked.
It honestly never gets old going into a room and needing to take down hoards of Las Plagas infected villagers. In action games I tend to rely on an extremely limited amount of items and weapons because I just don't care for all the options the game offers me, but in RE4 I was constantly shifting weapons in my inventory, trying out everything, switching weapons on the fly in a panic when running out of ammo or needing to mow down enemies. All the weapons are fantastic.

I absolutely adore the difficulty scaling in this game.
Just when you get comfortable with the game and encounters, the devs almost sense that you need something unexpected to shake you up. The perfect example is the scene under the castle. PURE TERROR.

Maybe my love of hammy action films from my childhood made me gravitate towards RE4, but aside from the cheesy one-liners Leon spits and the over the top action hero sequences, this game truly deserves every bit of praise it gets.
This is all not even mentioning the REengine which has got to be the most incredibly optimised modern game engine I have played in. The visuals are consistently breath-taking and the game never had any issues with frame rate, lag or graphic quality.

By all means, this is a totally radical game that everyone should play.

At this point I'm sure that the majority of gamer would have heard about Resident Evil 4 Remake and how it is an outstanding game. It is truly the peak of survival horror ever since the original version came out in 2005. I'm very happy to say that the remake is just as good if not better than the original version. 
The combat is smooth, fun and very addicting. The graphics and character design is beautiful while still keeping a similar tone to the original. The amount of content in the game is also great, offering the main story, ada seperate ways story as well as the well loved mercenaries mode.
This game along with Resident Evil 2 remake are both excellent game that you definitely need to play if you enjoy survival horror games.

Excellent game, I have not played RE3, but this is a major step up from RE2.
- The objectives are a lot less scattered around the map and therefore easier to follow
- They've added the options to crouch, parry and evade certain attacks
- Leon has learned parkour and can jump down from most heights as long as he can land safely.
- The puzzles are simpler and there's a lot more action, which we all want from horror games

It also has some replay value due to the vast array of weapons available, so this game is definitely worth the full price.

Took me 23 hours to complete my first playthrough of the game. Absolute peak.

I really enjoy the game a lot. The merchant missions are fun to do, the merchant in general is awesome to get new weapons and upgrade ones that you already own, and of course finding the treasures to sell, all very much fun and makes me greatly enjoy exploring the world!

I also enjoy the combat mechanics, they definetely make fighting a crowd more fun in this game compared to the previous games (RE2 and RE3 remakes), since you can actually reasonably fight back in this one.

While there are different suitcase upgrades, I genuinely foudn the increased handgun droprate suitcase to work the best for me since I suck at stealth and often run out of ammo fairly quickly if I don't have that one equipped.

Also I both like and get annoyed by Ashley. Like she is a fun character, and she can be helpful at times (opening up places to get treasures), but othertimes she just... gets annoying. Specifically when I tell her to keep close to run past enemies (or quickly run past the catapults), yet she is still somehow 5 kilometers behind me because she got stuck on god knows what.

Othertimes I tell her to keep away so I can figth enemies without her being hurt, yet she somehow is still quite close to me as if I never changed how close she was supposed to be... I don't know if others have the same issues or if my Ashley is just buggy, but it's quite annoying to deal with at times.

The regenerator section was awesome tho (the one where you first get introduced to them), was pretty scared first walking through that... until I got the thermal scope and just started blasting anyone I saw, lmao. Iron maidens were also pretty nice and added a few more stakes to fighting them.

The bossfights were awesome, especially loved the ones against Krauser, was finally able to use the full potential of my fully upgraded knife :D.

Also adored Luis and how kinda goofy he was at times (at least I found him kinda goofy sometimes, lmao). Ada was... well... Ada. I do preferred the voice actress for Ada in RE2 (remake) tho, this one sounds kinda just bored most of the time (this goes for the english version of the game)

Remaking an iconic game like Resident Evil 4 can't be easy...

Aside from a few performance issues which get fixed if I change the frame rate gets fixed somehow, the game is one of the best games to start for someone who fears RE horror. Resident Evil 4 Remake ‚Äì My Review

The Resident Evil 4 Remake offers impressive visuals and maintains the core gameplay mechanics of the original. However, several issues detract from the overall experience.

Pros:

High-quality graphics that enhance the atmospheric tension.

Faithful recreation of the original's gameplay elements.

Cons:

Censorship: Many suggestive and flirty moments and dialogue with Ashley are removed or altered.

Character Design Changes: Ada Wong's outfit is censored; the "boob window" is removed, and Ashley's upskirt shots are eliminated.

Gameplay Downgrade: The remake does not offer smoother gameplay; it feels downgraded compared to the original.

Performance Issues: The inclusion of Denuvo DRM has been reported to cause performance problems on PC, including stuttering and frame rate drops, even on high-end systems.

Weapon Customization Limitation: The Blacktail handgun lacks a laser sight option, a feature present in the original.

Voice Acting: Ada's English voice acting is considered subpar by some players, leading to the use of mods for improvement.

Final Thoughts:
While the Resident Evil 4 Remake brings updated visuals and attempts to modernize the classic, the censorship, performance issues due to DRM, and other design choices may detract from the experience for some players.

Score: 6/10 ‚Äì Visually appealing but hindered by technical and design flaws.

After completing it, I'll try to boil down why I think you should play this.

1: It's unnecessary, but not unneeded. RE4's PC ports have pretty much all been awful, and the HD edition is literally the same version as the IOS one. The game does look better but quality of life changes make the whole experience a much smoother time, which in turn lets you drink in those old environments in the new flashy graphics. It's not a bad game at all.

2: You have already played RE4 and that's why you're reading these reviews. This game is different but not always better. Many famous moments have been switched around or changed slightly, usually just because they didn't just make exactly the same game again. For many those moments are very impactful and changing them is just ruining iconic moments for a profit. Those people aren't wrong. Some of the reworked scenes are better, but some are plain worse and they stick out more.

It *really* should have had co-op in Mercenaries mode though.

This serves as a retrospective but still a review, more or less.
	From the achievements titled after many of iconic corny one-liners in the OG to the shooting range bonus time theme which will make you shed a tear of nostalgia, RE4R is a [b] beautifully-crafted love letter [/b] to all the 2005 fans, with even more replayability than the OG ‚Äî all while being perfectly suitable for newcomers.
	It's wild how fans who had been skeptical about a 4 remake, came to love this more than the OG. Overall (putting nostalgia blindness aside), it IS  superior to OG, and man new Luis is just [b] PEAK [/b]. I love his new suave voice and how he stole more scenes than in the original becoming more than just comic relief. This time Ashley isn‚Äôt a pain in the ahh anymore, now with more realistic vulnerability and fear of getting possessed. Let's dive into it.

    [b] First thing you realize when opening the game is [/b] main menu is now night-dark instead of the og bright morning, conveying the change in the remake before you even play it. Storytelling is a big improvement over the OG which felt kinda isolated, we hear more about EU Umbrella, Luis, and Wesker. First cutscene explains a part of Leon's past, training and how he was assigned the mission. 

    [h2] 30 seconds... [/h2] 30 seconds is all it takes for the first ganado encounter. Everything feels familiar with an emphasis on a darker/scarier atmosphere. While a lot of games bore you with long prologues with dialogues, Resident Evil comes in to remind players that interactivity and enjoyable gameplay is what distinguishes games from movies. Immediate immersion into the action is not only unique, but also deep-rooted in the franchise. Take a look at the time it takes the classics to throw you in the chaos:
[list]
    [*]RE1: 10 seconds
    [*]RE2: INSTANTLY
    [*]RE3: INSTANTLY
    [*]RE4 OG: 15 seconds
[/list]

[quote=IGN] With all due respect to the likes of The Last of Us and God of War Ragnarok ‚Äì which are both excellent in their own ways ‚Äì Resident Evil 4 has no time for dialogue-heavy deep and meaningfuls. [/quote]

    [h2] The lake [/h2] is now a mini openworld section that you're free to backtrack into after Del Lago boss fight. The whole area is bigger in the remake and gives you a reason to spend some time doing merchant quests, solving new puzzles and searching for weapons, files, treasures, etc. It is a big jump in quality compared to OG where the whole lake area was hollow and not worth going back to after the boss fight because the church key is simply located in a generic area behind the waterfall with no puzzles. This time the key is locked behind 2 puzzles pieces you need to find while you explore the lake. 

    [h2] Combat [/h2] still feels tight and satisfying. Also worth mentioning that moving while aiming comes at the expense of some accuracy (unless you unlock a laser sight for a handgun) so most of the time you will find yourself aiming while standing still like the OG, it's a modern game yes but after all, it's not a Call of Duty.

    [h2] Crouching [/h2] is not only introduced for stealth purposes but also for combat. Early on, you encounter a new type of enemy called Brute wielding a sledgehammer madly swinging it around, requiring you to crouch down to evade it while the guy does you a favor mauling surrounding ganados. Also used to get around tripwire bombs, using them to your advantage.

    [h2] Enemies' AI [/h2] is better than expected. They are more aggressive and show some intelligence in their approach. When I tried camping up a ladder in the Fish Farm to throttle ganados, they didn't even wait to climb up and instead started throwing axes even though they can't see me.

    [h2] Stealth [/h2] RE4R introduces a rudimentary stealth system using crouch + knife takedowns, Sadly, Ganados AI is lacking at this point. There are some congested sections both in the main game and the DLC where you can stealth your way out which is very fun to have.

    [h2] Knives [/h2] The knife is overhauled in the remake, introducing around 5 main types of knives, varying in upgradable stats, i.e. damage, durability and attack speed, in addition to 2 basic disposable weaker knives you find around to temporarily rely on if your main knife is broken (more on that below). The new knives' system is one of the remake‚Äôs most praised additions for their many added benefits while still giving a sense of strategic resource/durability management. Some of these benefits are:
[list]
    [*]Parrying most attacks and thrown weapons.
    [*]Finishing off staggered enemies.
    [*]Killing knocked off twitching enemies preventing them from becoming Plaga heads.
    [*]Stealth kills.
    [*]The option to break out of grab attacks instead of wiggling out like in the OG.
    [*]Krauser's QTE knife duel cutscene has been transformed into a gameplay section reliant on parrying and counterattacking.
[/list]
     You got a gamelength-long quest shooting dolls resembling Salazar distributed around all 16 chapters, doing so rewards you with a very unique knife, that being the [spoiler] OG Primal Knife with an exclusive upgrade to become indestructible, although weaker than Krauser's knife [/spoiler].
     This enriches combat without compromising any of the challenge as these changes are balanced out by the depletable durability knives, with some actions wearing out knives more than others (e.g. Parrying the chainsaw man and the one-shot plaga zealot attack have the most effect on knives' durability) before breaking. Main knives are repairable at the merchant.

    [h2] Running [/h2] feels heavier (likely to tone down intensity of action and balance enriched combat) but you get used to it. Gone are the days of flying across the game with the Ditman Glitch, but hey at least they paid homage with a striker charm granting 8% movement speed.

    [h2] The Merchant [/h2] has a ton of voice lines. Spinels, instead of being a very common jewel in OG, are now the main currency you get from doing merchant quests (20 in total). The merchant has a new menu called (Trading) where you trade spinels for useful resources, weapons/weapon parts, treasures, etc.

    [h2] Shooting Range [/h2] is a lot better with more stages, earning higher ranking rewards you with tokens you drop in a machine to get charms of different tiers. You can hang up to 3 on your Attache Case to activate the charm passive.

    [h2] Attache Case [/h2] There are now 7 different kinds of them, each granting a passive bonus for diffrerent drops and crafting.

    [h2] Storage [/h2] The old storage box from the classic games is back, accessible through the typewriter menu and used to store weapons and first aid sprays. Super useful if you're planning to go NG+ as you won't need to sell any of your upgraded weapons for space.

    [h2] Files [/h2]: For the geeks who enjoy Resident Evil's files more than the main story, 4R features more files expanding on various and several topics not present in the OG. They won't disappoint.

    [h2] The Castle [/h2]  This is the most changed and improved of the 3 main stages of the game, and the one you will love the most. It has all the iconic areas of the OG castle, with several new beautiful areas, they all interconnect with different arrangement from the OG, this way you never know what the upcoming area will be.

    [h2] Ashley's playable section [/h2] is also massively improved. You can backtrack to this section as Leon to do quests or do puzzles to get weapons and so on.

    [h2] Backtracking [/h2] along with exploration in general is highly rewarded. You have different means to help you with that. Be it a special key or puzzle item used to unlock the several locked contraptions you come across earlier, or just getting Ashley to help you get to those out-of-reach areas.

46/46 achievements, Def would still do another run. 

Make sure to grab Separate Ways as it's the best DLC in the franchise.

This game is a masterpiece and improves upon the original Resident Evil 4 in almost every way, although there are cut sections and some of the goofyness the original had, those changes make more sense here and the good way outperforms the bad. And even better, The Separate Ways DLC includes the sections that were cut from the original game, but instead of playing them from the perspective of Leon, you play them as Ada Wong. And this DLC could perfectly be it's own full length Resident Evil game, with lots of content and serves as a way to solve some plot-holes from the main campaign.

Only few things I didn't like are the Salazar redesign and dialogues. Since he no longer looks like a creepy child, now more like a dwarf, and also doesnt personally speak to you via intercom but from speakers now, it feels like a downgrade to his character and personality.

This could be the best entry in the franchise, being so addictive to play, the gameplay very responsive, gorgeous graphics and highly replayable, I give it a 9.5/10. And the ending of the DLC sets up a possible remake for RE5, which I hope Capcom handles it some day.

As a long-time fan of the original Resident Evil 4‚Äîmy entry point into the franchise‚ÄîI honestly can't describe how much I love this remake. The original game wasn't just a unique experience that sparked my interest in this genre, it has always held a special place in my heart. Back then, I didn‚Äôt have access to the older RE titles, and as the years went by, going back to the pre-RE4 entries became even harder.

Thanks to Capcom‚Äôs incredible remakes (let‚Äôs not count RE3 Remake), I‚Äôm really glad I was finally able to get a better understanding of the events leading up to RE4.

This remake is masterfully crafted. Every cut element from the original has been replaced with something better. Every chapter has been expanded upon, and best of all‚Äîthere‚Äôs the Separate Ways DLC.

In the original game, Separate Ways felt like a lazy excuse to reuse assets and throw together a shallow campaign for Ada. But this time around, it delivers an experience that‚Äôs just as good‚Äîif not even better‚Äîthan the main campaign itself.

Wow. Just wow. I have never played the original RE4 and when starting this I was a bit sceptical at the beginning because I am usually no type for village settings. I knew it was often considered the best Resident Evil game but I usually want to make my own opinion. I was unsure if it was actually for me.

But it actually blew my expectations into orbit. It's one of the best games I have ever played!

Resident Evil 2 Remake is what got me into the franchise and so I had a pretty big bias towards that game. 
I did not expect it to be beaten in a long time. But here comes RE4 Remake and smashes my previous expectations into the ground. 

Despite it being pretty much "Save the damsel in distress", the character interactions as well as acting made the duo of Leon and Ashley pretty enjoyable! I think making her more mature in the Remake was 100% the right choice and it made me sympathise a lot with her. Leon being more serious after everything he has been through is also a nice upgrade, even tho many lines in the original are just legendary. 

The gameplay is very smooth and rewarding, it has insanely good gun play and also enjoyable variety in the weapons! 

Visuals and sound design are fantastic. The game is absolutely stunning looking, with music and sound effects adding wonders to the atmosphere. It's very good at capturing the horror of the plaga and the monsters it creates! Those have also been greatly visually upgraded from the original and offer the awesome body horror Resident Evil is so good at!

What I also really appreciate is the detail in Leon's model. In RE2 Remake, his facial features are softer, nicer looking. He has this touch of innocence and positivity. 6 years after the horrible events in Raccoon City, the RE4 Remake model makes his face look tougher. It has hardened, his eyebrows are significantly lowered, he has a permanent frown and his eyes have dark rings below them. Such details truly show the development Leon went through over the time skip and how much he has changed. This is peak story telling and character design and I am just in love with it.
 
Resident Evil 4 Remake is the prime example of a game people love nowadays. Yes, it is only a remake, however the changes and improvements it offers make it a game that other developers can take inspiration from. 

With 99.9% positives and 0.1% nitpicks about this game, I can confidently give Resident Evil 4 Remake a 10/10 and is in my opinion a must play for Survival Horror Lovers - especially people, that love Resident Evil!

Back with a remastered vengeance! Resident Evil 4 Is a staple with Capcom and Horror. Being able to see the story told almost identically but also seperate from the original RE4 makes it feel fresh and approachable with the timeline. The game has changed so some bossfights/scene transitions have either been removed or replaced (Caged Bat Monster Fight and Titan Clockwork Salazar). 

From start to finish the pacing is set and the remastered details have you itching for more gameplay. At the time of writing I have not accomplished seperate ways but I always come back to the game after a couple of days (It's become a ritual at this point)

TLDR: Game is very good, I played it with my dad growing up and we bonded so hard over it. The remaster is everything and more! Can't wait for Requim

I love this remake.
I was excited for so long as I never truly appreciated the original until a few months before the remake. And once I heard it was getting a remake I was so excited. I played the shit out of the Demo and bought the game on Launch Day.

This remake stays true to the original's format while also adding things and taking away things that were unneccesary or wouldn't work in the remake, It took roughly the same amount of time for me to complete the remake as I did for the original, On my OG Account I think I got around 360 total hours spent playing the game alone. Half without mods, and half with mods, I couldn't have asked for a better remake, it has honestly made me prefer it over the original just because the style of it and how smooth it is so appealing and satisfying to me.

It's a must play for any Resident Evil Fan.

An incredible remake which pays tribute to the original while simultaneously being it's own masterpiece.

After 100% completing this game, and playing through the original a few times, I have found a new game to add to my favorites list. This game is a masterpiece, I'd wipe all my achievements and do the 100% all over again. (But who has the time?).

I HIGHLY recommend this to anyone who has or even hasn't played the original, because so much of both games are the same and kept that way. Going for all achievements is incredibly satisfying and rewarding, as well as a ton of fun.

For one, the graphics are incredible. Anyone with a good pc or better will marvel at the new shiny details. The gunplay is also phenomenal, and unlocking all the upgrades is worth every penny. 

Running through the game on subsequent NG+ runs is a blast, you get to keep most of your items from the previous playthrough. All your guns and upgrades will stay in your inventory. (Also a few secret weapons that make the game difficulty laughable!).

Separate Ways could very well be its own game! Playing as Ada is a nice breakaway from the main game, with the bonus of a grappling hook.

I will definitely be coming back to replay this masterpiece year after year, and I recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of the franchise or looking to start!

Another great installment in the RE Remakes series. As usual, these games show us that optimization is still possible by developers who really try. Each and every one of these games has ran flawlessly on my PC, this time around even with ray tracing on I was still at a solid 60 fps at 1440p, never once experiencing a frame drop throughout my playthrough. This alone should continue to make these games stand out.

Gameplay also continues to be fun and engaging. The shops system in this game keeps things interesting with exchanging and upgrading weapons along the way, while managing space makes you have to choose your arsenal carefully.

There's very few complaints about this game. Leon's dialogue can be so bad it's comical at times, and yet I loved hearing whatever he had to say next. My only real issue with the game is [spoiler] the lack of recurring monsters like RE2 and RE3 had. Leon faces many grotestque bosses, yet all of them are defeated after the first standoff with them. There isn't a big man that keeps showing up and chasing you, Leon takes on the boss fight and then moves on. Not a bad thing, but it was different from the other games, the reappearance of a scary, unstoppable boss had a nice buildup to the final fights of RE2 and RE3. [/spoiler]

This is a good one though, and on sale for $20 is great.

This is a good game, no doubt about it, its a remake of a classic. But I'm giving it a downvote because it could have been a lot better.

PROS:
- Good graphics.
- Additional content.
- Not exactly the same game (different layout, some new enemies).
- The knife has more usability.

CONS:
- Again very limited modding capability because Capcom wants to sell its DLC costumes, weapons and Ada's campaign (didnt even make many DLC content).
- It would have been nice to have new areas instead of only changing the layout of rooms.
- Some content got cut out for some reason.
- A good feature for this game would have been Wall Leaning since many enemies have projectiles.
- The CQBR Assault Rifle is kinda disappointing since its not used as expected--an assault rifle. Instead its designed to be used as a marksman rifle and therefore have a low amount of ammo.
- The devs once again made Ashley an annoying character to protect. She wont run away from danger but instead will stand in the middle of enemies.
- Luis also doesn't run away from danger and gets damaged unnecessarily.
- Not many good DLC content, and they removed Ashley's armour costume.
- Multiplayer would have been a good addition.

In conclusion this Remake is kinda disappointing and could have been better.

This game is a great fit for the survival horror genre, even though it doesn't lean too heavily into horror. Item drops are generous enough that taking down enemies is rarely a struggle. Because of that, even the highest difficulty mode ‚Äî Professional ‚Äî isn't overly challenging to beat.

Unlike the Resident Evil 2 remake, this game allows the use of unlimited ammo weapons to achieve an S+ rank (though, of course, you‚Äôll need to fully upgrade them first). One standout feature is the parry and deflect mechanics, which are surprisingly well done and feel inspired by Souls-like games.

That said, I still find some aspects of the game a bit ridiculous. For example, how does a girl who can‚Äôt even fight back when being kidnapped suddenly know how to operate a giant crane? It doesn‚Äôt make much sense!

The graphical overhaul does this game a lot of justice while remaining exceptionally performant.

Resident Evil 4 is the latest series of remakes produced by Capcom after the releases of Resident Evil 2 and 3 in 2019 and 2020 respectively. After the previous, albeit they were quite short, sensational creations, I didn't expect Resident Evil 4 to be any different compared to its predecessors at all. The experience was totally different from the ones of RE 2 and 3, which played on certains parts of the devastated city of Racoon. You are thrown into a rural area controlled by insane, vicious and mercyless cultists seeking to take over the entire planet. The gameplay is faster and much more action-oriented compared to the two previous games. It hardly ever felt like even a single minute was wasted with just sneaking around and stumbling across nothing. That means the whole 15-20 hours of gameplay are fully utilized.

Enemies move in a dangerous, erractic manner and having them overwhelm and surrounding you happens so quickly that you can never really feel safe, so making snap decisions when it comes to prioritising targets is extremely important. You also have to be aware of the surface you're walking on, as it's not uncommon to get your foot stuck in a bear traps, which can turn out to be very problematic, especially during a fight. You might have a very expansive tollset, but that doesn't mean you can afford to lose focus or be unaware of your surroundings.
A one-size fits all strategy doesn't work in this game, as the enemies can suddenly pull up with shields or helmets forcing you to use different styles how to exterminate the hostile targets.

What starts as a very straightforward rescue mission, with Leon Kennedy being tasked to locate and free the US President's missing daughter, Ashley, soon turns into a heart-stopping series of bloody clashes against giant sea monsters, crazed hordes in boarded up cabins and bloodythirstly, possesed cultists in and around a heavily fortified castle, skulking sections through shadowy laboratories, explosive and thrilling minecart chases and countless run-ins with some twisted and insane freaks infected with the dangerous Las Plagas parasite.

Additionally it's noteworthy to mention how terrifying and frightening the audio design is. When it comes to a cultivating sense of dread, that game almost belongs to the "unreachable" category. Whether it's the manic chanting of the parasite-mutated peasant farmers or the snarl of wolvees as they wander through the area around you in the castle's confusing hedge maze. All of which had me at the edge of my seat, you can believe that.

When you need to take a breather in order to restack your ammo, heal up, get recipes to craft exact desired ammo types, increase the capacity of your case or simply purchase new weapons, a mysterious merchant always having a saying ready, returns to give Leon the chance to get fully equipped before moving on to the next chapter. Furthermore, you can complete certain tasks (e.g. shooting down hidden blue medallions, killing a small amount of rats in certain, small areas, tracking down a rare golden chicken egg) written down on flyers distributed across the whole map in exchange for spinel gemstones which can be traded for unique items and upgrades.

The question whether to give this game a shot or not is a total no-brainer. It's just the perfect fit for action-horror fans. The  world is just so beautifully designed with lots of surprises, fun, plently of explorable areas and tasks to be completed. To be honest, I didn't particuarly like this game at the beginning, because I'm not the biggest fan of this cult, medieval-like stuff and clearly prefer the atmosphere, world and vibe of the Resident Evil 2 and 3 games. The design of the inventory is also something I didn't particular like and I clearly preferred the one from RE 2 and 3 as well. Moreover, the different mixtures of yellow, red and green herbes was way to confusing. However, this game finally started to grow on me during chapter 11, from which I had an intense 3.5 hour stint till the end of chapter 13. From then on I was glad to not have given up on that masterpiece to early.

Mostly an amazing game. Some may see it as more of a shooter, but as a newish player to the genre, going through on standard was a little challenging with a death or two per chapter. Never felt tedious like it was in re2r (while playing re2r, I had to run back in forth because my inventory filled up with items every single room  or repeatedly retracing your steps because of a somewhat convoluted puzzle)

Beyond that, the ability to now upgrade your chosen weapons gave me (and I assume other players) to adjust their preferred playstyle and favored weapons, which adds to the whole experience. Game still has a lot a horror moments with certain enemies. Along with that comes with reason for map exploration.

Characters and story was interesting and fun.

As for the cons, it's honestly a bit nitpicky:
-There are a few instances towards the end where a cutscene happens, and then your character's position get thrown into a 'cage', and by the time you gain control of the character again, multiple enemies are already rushing at you from every direction. Honestly was very disorienting, and felt like a cheap way to create 'desperation'.

my name is slit, welcome.

i‚Äôve played the resident evil 2 remake, 3 remake, 7, and 8. i 100%'d part 3 and 7
resident evil, to me, has always stood on two legs: survival or horror or let's say mixed between the two. 

then along came re4 remake.
this game doesn‚Äôt give a damn about either. it‚Äôs not survival, it‚Äôs not horror‚Äîit's a third-person shooting gallery wearing a resident evil costume. it plays like doom without the metal soundtrack, without the adrenaline, and without the charm. just a never-ending stream of mindless enemies charging at you, and you spray bullets until your brain turns to oatmeal. rinse, repeat.

you want fear? tension? resource management? atmosphere? too bad.
what you get is a million spanish villagers with pandemic-grade aggression storming you like it‚Äôs black friday, and you‚Äôre the last guy with toilet paper.

if i wanted to play something like this, i would‚Äôve loaded up doom eternal. at least doom knows what it is. it embraces the chaos and gives you carnage with style.
resident evil 4 remake? it‚Äôs stuck somewhere between a john wick movie and a low-effort anime filler arc.

now let‚Äôs talk about the character you play:
you‚Äôre leon‚Äîsome supposedly badass american agent. except he's not. he's a walking anime trope with the emotional depth of a tea spoon. clearly written to bait people who think eren yeager is a personality type.
‚Äúoooh, he‚Äôs so cold.‚Äù
no. he‚Äôs boring.

but let‚Äôs be honest slit‚Äîno one plays resident evil for the dialogue, right? okay cool.

gameplay? let me draw it for you:
loot.
70 villagers charge at you.
kill them.
walk 3 steps.
70 new villagers show up.
kill them.
go to a new area that looks like it was built by someone asleep at the keyboard.
guess what? more loot.
guess again: 70 more villagers.
think you know what‚Äôs next?
nope. no loot this time‚Äîjust ashley.

ashley: the gameplay downgrade nobody asked for.
once she shows up, the already repetitive combat becomes a babysitting simulator.
it‚Äôs like escorting a cracked-out npc through a war zone while trying not to lose your mind.
and at that point, you finally understand why gavi fucked the spanish princess and dipped.
just play re4 and it‚Äôll all click.

story? what story?
every cutscene feels like it was written by someone who has alzheimer disease.
you kill a horde of enemies, get a pointless cutscene, ada shows up, vanishes, ashley gets kidnapped again (surprise!), and the loop begins anew.

if you‚Äôre into plot progression, character arcs, or stakes.. this game offers none.
it‚Äôs just: shoot...  cutscene.... ashley screams.... repeat.
you could fall asleep between encounters and not miss a single narrative beat.

but wait... there was one, one, actually great moment.
there‚Äôs a section where you play as ashley alone.
leon‚Äôs locked up (thanks god) and you have to save him.
you‚Äôre armed with nothing but a flashlight, and suddenly.. finally... the game remembers it‚Äôs supposed to have horror elements.
the area design is tight. the atmosphere is creepy. the gameplay is actually engaging.
i was really shocked and i said to myself: DAMN SLIT.. even in a pile of shit, sometimes you strike gold. it felt like i was playing resident evil.

and i‚Äôll say this: that one section is one of the best areas in the entire franchise. deriod.
but it lasts, what, 15 minutes? then it‚Äôs back to the spray-n-pray fiesta.

final thoughts?
this is the worst resident evil game i‚Äôve ever played.
i don‚Äôt care how much praise it gets. that just proves one thing:
the fanbase is full of sheep with zero taste.
trust a brainless donkey before you trust a fanboy shill.
would‚Äôve been better throwing my money in the trash, at least then the trash would‚Äôve had purpose.

Resident Evil 4 Remake has cemented Capcom in the modern age as the premier gaming company re imaging IP for new generations.  While RE2 Remake proved it was possible(lets ignore RE3), RE4 was such an iconic and transformative game for the genre that bringing it back would be a herculean task.  The OG immersive 3rd person survival horror.  The RE2 Remake brought that immersion to the second game, and this time, Capcom has brought back the King.  Outside of maybe Evil Within 1, I have never played a 3rd person horror game with so much variety in gameplay, environments, enemy types and bosses.  This is an epic horror in all the best ways, and a masterclass in encounter design, quality animations, and excellent melee systems.   Movement is weighty, guns feel impactful, and just about every aspect of the gameplay is best in class.  RE4 always stradled the line of action and horror in a compelling way, creating the blueprint for the Last of Us and Evil Within.  Hopefully if Capcom continues the Remake trend, they try to bring 5 or 6 back more in line with what they have done here.

[h1]This Game Is A Blast From The Past[/h1]
I was blown away by the release of the original Resident Evil 4, and I didn't think that a remake was needed. However, I was surprised by how good the remake is. It improves upon many aspects of the original, including gameplay. It may be similar to the original, especially the combat, but I am so glad that they made a lot of things different, such as the settings. The environments and boss fights seem familiar, but they are different enough to make the experience of the game refreshing. The game does feel easier than the original, but I might be biased about that because I put in countless hours playing the original.  

The control is no longer rigid as it is in the original. The original required you to stand still to fire a weapon, but the remake allows you to move while shooting. The game also allows you to quickly select weapons in the game with your D-pad if you're playing on a controller, or with the number keys if you're on a PC, so you don't have to switch to the menu and pause the game, something that hurt immersion in the original version. Also, the developers did an amazing job making Leon's character animation look fluid and natural as he moves around while you're controlling him. 

What this remake did WAY better than the original is that it built a stronger aspect of horror, while maintaining a good balance of action. You find yourself navigating in dark corridors and pitch black dungeons. It keeps you guessing what kind of monsters lurk in the dark.  

What I also love is that stealth is added to the gameplay. Unlike the original, you can sneak behind enemies one by one and take them out silently without alerting the rest of them. Although you cannot travel through the areas relying solely on stealth, I am glad that you have more options to deal with the challenges an area presents. 

This is a nitpick, but the main villain is not as compelling as the original. In the original, he had more screen time and had a very snarky and sinister persona. You love to hate him. However, the one in the remake is more one-dimensional and bland. Thus, he is just a standard movie villain that I've seen countless times and doesn't stand out. 

The remake does polish some aspects of the story. It gives a backstory to certain characters so they have more depth. I don't want to go into more details to avoid spoiling anything. 

Overall, this game is great for people who love survival horror, whether or not they played the original. Just like the original game, it throws you into extremely perilous situations that get your adrenaline pumping. And its improvements on the original make it a refreshing experience for fans of the original RE4, which I argue is the best in the franchise.
This game is an absolutely must play. If you are for some reason on the fence about purchasing, I can assure you that you will not regret picking this up. Also mommy Ada is hot

Highly Recommended

Resident Evil 4 Remake is a near-perfect reimagining of one of the most iconic action-horror games ever made. It modernizes everything ‚Äî from combat and visuals to character depth ‚Äî while staying faithful to the tone, pacing, and absurd charm of the original. Whether you're a veteran or newcomer, this is essential survival horror.

Pros:

Incredible third-person combat with smooth gunplay and satisfying feedback

Gorgeous visuals, atmospheric lighting, and improved level design

Expanded story and character moments, especially for Ashley and Luis

Smart reworks to puzzles, boss fights, and pacing

New parry and stealth mechanics add variety

High replay value with New Game+, Challenges, and Mercenaries Mode

Cons:

Some iconic lines and campy moments were toned down or changed

Knife durability might annoy players early on

A few boss encounters are less memorable than the original

Final Thoughts:
This isn‚Äôt just a remake ‚Äî it‚Äôs a redefining of what a remake should be. Capcom nailed it. RE4 Remake respects its legacy while boldly pushing the franchise forward. Action, horror, and cheese ‚Äî perfectly blended.

Alright, so I finally got around to playing the Resident Evil 4 Remake, and holy moly, they absolutely nailed it! As someone who's played the original countless times, I was a bit worried they'd mess it up, but nope ‚Äì they actually made it better.

First off, it looks incredible. The village, the castle, the island ‚Äì everything is just jaw-droppingly detailed and atmospheric. It really makes the horror hit harder when everything looks so grimy and unsettling. The sound design is top-notch too; hearing those Ganados muttering in the distance or the chilling whispers of the "it" creature genuinely gave me goosebumps.

The combat feels fantastic. The controls are super fluid, which is a massive upgrade. And the knife parry? Oh my god, that's a game-changer! It turns frantic close-quarters moments into these epic, desperate struggles where you can actually fight back with style. Learning to time those parries properly felt so rewarding. It really encourages you to get in there and mix it up, instead of just backing away and shooting.

They also did a great job with the story and characters. Leon feels a bit more grounded, and Ashley is less annoying this time around, which is a huge plus. Even characters like Luis feel more fleshed out. They kept the cheesy charm of the original but balanced it with a more serious, darker tone that fits the horror perfectly.

Honestly, my only tiny gripe is that some of the darker areas can be a bit too dark even with the brightness up, but that's a minor thing. Overall, if you loved the original, you're going to adore this. And if you've never played RE4 before, this is absolutely the best way to experience it. It's a masterclass in how to remake a classic. Go play it! You won't regret it.

While this remake marks a drastic tonal shift from the original and cuts a few corners, it still stands strong on its own thanks to a satisfying combat system and dense atmosphere.

The story takes a more grounded, believable approach, with characters that are less over-the-top than in the original ‚Äî and in my opinion, the remake delivers the horror aspect more effectively. While it's not Resident Evil 7 levels of terrifying, some moments are genuinely unnerving.

Combat feels precise and rewarding. It borrows some elements from RE7, like the initial spread when aiming, but tightens up quickly to reward patience and accuracy. The addition of a parry system using the knife adds more depth and dynamism to encounters.

That said, the Mercenaries mode takes a bit of a hit. The more "realistic" combat fits well in the main campaign but feels off in an arcade-style setting like this. The original‚Äôs more pinpoint-style shooting was simply a better fit here.

I don‚Äôt see this remake as a replacement for the original, as some people claim ‚Äî but rather as a solid and enjoyable reimagining that stands proudly beside it.

This is a lovely game and opportunity for folks to experience an updated and enhanced version of Resident Evil 4. While I missed out on the original, I do feel like this game pays respect to it while also enriching it with lore that wasn't available at the time and adding more depth. The game plays well, is enjoyable, authentically Resident Evil, and not too long. 

This game brings plenty of challenge even on standard difficulty with the swift enemies and survival elements at play. The first person view and lack of tells means you could very well get enemies sneaking up on you as well. If you play the game blind you will find yourself with plenty of opportunity to push yourself. Things can be missed. There are some enemies you may not know how to dispose of without a bit of advice. There are situations you may be better off not fighting. Everything is there to push you in a controlled manner.

I'm glad I gave it the time and enjoyed playing through and experiencing the story. Would definitely recommend, though if you're like me and don't like the surprises, play with a guide.

Resident evil 4 is a fantastically well-put together game that manages to include new aspects of gameplay without straying far from the original game. As a hardcore fan of the resident evil remake series, I believe that this is one of the best survival horror RE games in the franchise. 

The first major improvement from the original game is definitely the Ashley AI, going from players treating her as a nuisance, to actually making players want to protect her. I particularly love Ashley's realistic character development and growth as she journeys with Leon Kennedy, coming to trust him over time and be useful in her own way. Aside from Ashley, other characters also feel realistic and natural in conversations, movement and behaviour. Enemies are well-modelled as well and most bosses all feel unique in their own ways and have unique battles, I especially love the knife-fight and "obstacle course" with Krauser.

Aside from incredible graphics and characters, the soundtrack generally suits the game just right, allowing for tensions at the right moments (especially around later chapters when *THEY* make their appearance) and less tense situations (with our dear merchant) + hardcore music during the boss fights. However, there are occasional times where the soundtrack sounds awkward (E.g: Sudden fighting village ost when you‚Äôre standing at a safe sniper distance out of view). The plot sails smoothly from chapter to chapter, with few chapters feeling redundant or unnecessary, and nice switches of game style from the village, to the castle, and eventually the Island. Lastly, voice-acting is top-tier for characters like Leon and Ashley, I LOVE the emotion that their voices carry. However, other characters like Ada feel slightly unnatural and unsuitable for the character, especially compared to her VA for RE2.

Having said that, one of the major problems RE4 faces is difficulty, which is almost abnormal in harder difficulties like hardcore of professional. RE uses the difficulty adjustment (DA) system, which varies depending on how well the player does. E.g: Player is overloaded with supplies, defeating optional challenging enemies like brutes -> DA points skyrocket, making the game MUCH more challenging (stronger enemies, damage taken, supply drops etc...) On professional, this game is INSANELY difficult, especially if one attempts the S+ run, with many enemies having the ability to one-shot or stunlock the player, along with the 15 save and 5h30 time limit. I can confidently say that most gamers will certainly feel frustrated trying to play professional on NG+, especially without learning all the tricks required/ following a walkthrough. 

For new players who come for the plot and enjoyment, I recommend playing assisted/ standard despite the DA system as the difficulty is still relatively easy for those modes. 

Characters: 9/10 (Only Saddler‚Äôs character falls slightly short as a final boss)
Art: 10/10 (Absolutely fantastic graphics and art style, the concept art is immaculate)
Gameplay: 8/10 (Great for a survival horror fan, however the DA does mess with the experience for hardcore and professional)
Soundtracks: 9/10 
Plot: 9/10 

Final rating: 9/10

Having never played the OG game this was my first experience with Resident Evil 4 & it's been a very positive one, it felt like the stakes were always high, had that classic one liner charm I'd expect from an RE game, and the blend of modern controls with RE4 made for a pretty harmonious combination. Music is underwhelming sure but thats easily fixed by toggling the original soundtrack, (thankfully without needing an additional purchase like RE2 remake, showing Capcom learns from mistakes), and truthfully there's very little that I can say that'd dissuade anyone from wanting to experience this extremely well made game.

Any fan of Resident Evil owes themselves a playthrough of this game, and for fans of the original try it out and see how it compares to your memories of the what its based on. Trust.

The GOAT remake

This was my first introduction to the Resident Evil Franchise, and I loved every second of it. The atmosphere and the narrative were amazing, and the game does a great blend of action, horror, and comedy, making an enjoyable experience. The game itself is also well optimized, it might be one of the best optimized AAA games I've played (other than Red Dead Redemption 2, also a really good game) in a few years. The game ran at a steady 60 fps for the entirety, with some easy tweaking of the graphics.

Overall, I would give it a good 9.5/10.

Decided to update this review after beating the game on Hardcore about three times, almost four-- which I will get back to why it is almost four-- my enjoyment has hardly increased and I have found even more reasons to not like this game. What I immediately want to say is how frustratingly long it takes for this POS to boot up and how long it takes to load into save files, which is supposedly tied to how many save files you have. That would be fine...ish, it's annoying and quite shitty but hey, you can just delete the save files-- Just not in game though :) 

Awesome choice Capcom, that's really fucking cool actually, thank you for that. You made the game harder, made resources stricter, which are very good changes, love the fact this remake has more player accountability! Remake makes this game more like the original survivor horror titles, but in those titles, you often saved in multiple locations in the chance that you may have or eventually will put yourself in an unwinnable situation, requiring you to go back to an older save. I had that happen a couple times which I had no problems with, but that was when the game wasn't taking three fucking years to load into each save and when I had less save files! Why can't you delete them in game? Why was that a choice actively made??? I don't even have mods installed so that can't be the sole reason it is taking so long! I am actively trying to load into one of them as I type this lmao 

The other problem, the one that has been absolutely detrimental to my enjoyment of these games, the one that has killed any desire or urge to replay the prior remakes is the guns; everything about them is painfully unsatisfying. The sounds are weak, the sensation of hitting an enemy with them feels limp, like I'm shooting a paintball gun at wet sacks of flour. The enemy animations upon impact are just so heavy and wet in a way that kills any enjoyment the gunplay may give. The shotguns in these remakes are the ones most damaged by this pernicious little problem, they feel like ass, they're horribly inconsistent at blowing someone's head off-- which is something that I kinda don't like in OG RE4 admittedly-- but in this game, that happens more often, even when they are not upgraded! I know for a fact the guns are doing damage because I can see the corpses I'm leaving, I can see the exploding heads but man, I don't get to enjoy any of that when every enemy running at you is a wet sack of flour instead of a being made of flesh. Enemy animations suck, they are so heavy and hit you with a wet plap - there is no catharsis in meleeing an enemy, there is no crunchy, meaty sensation when an enemy's axe digs into Leon's shoulder. 

It's just unreal to me how they managed to fix one issue I had with the remakes, the guns not really doing anything to the enemies, but did not fix how shitty it feels to shoot guns in a third person, over the shoulder shooter :/

Speaking of being an over the shoulder shooter! Why is the aim zoom unmodded so closed in on you? You have a lot more enemies coming at you in EVERY single arena so what is that supposed to achieve? The aiming system and aim camera zoom is ripped straight out of the prior remakes without any consideration in how it effects a game that is way more open - the arenas you are fighting in are much larger but they often feel 3x smaller because of this shitty zoom - game is nauseating like this, I NEEDED to install the no aim zoom mod, game was and is genuinely unplayable for me without it.  

I want to say some things I actually like about the game, there is a lot more that I like than I actively hate but, those things that I hate ruin the entire package for me.

I love how willing and eager Capcom were in screwing with the player in the same way RE1R did, an RE game that is significantly better than 7,8, and every other project they have released for this series since 2017. Arenas have been retooled in pretty significant ways - some locations and the way you traverse them have  been reversed and or expanded upon - many of them were pretty insignificant in the original game and I am quite glad I get to see a better, bigger version of them. The double Garrador room is absolutely a highlight of this game - it blows the original fight out of the water. Ashley is a lot harder to protect in this game, which many reviews have described as being a bad thing, and yeah, wrangling her is much clunkier but I hardly had issues with the changes - it made her a variable I actively had to take into account more often which led to her and the game to be more engaging. Pool Room, which was not a room I found all that challenging in the original, is harder in this game and the enemies harass you in it to an annoying (affectionately using the word here) degree. The Bolt Action Rifle and the Stingray are the only guns in this game that do not feel like dick to shoot, very fun guns with great reload animations and sound effects <33  

The game is hard and is tuned pretty well on Professional, enjoyed the difficulty immensenly. The change to enemy stuns I am kinda iffy about? - I like that one headshot is not a guaranteed stun anymore but sometimes, even three is not enough - it just feels really bad and stupid when half or more of my unupgraded pistol mag was required to get a tiny amount of breathing room. Will say however that this is mostly an early game problem, so I hardly consider it a significant flaw and mostly an okay change. I like that the stun change forces me to be in a more reactive headspace than the predictive one in OG RE4. The Armaduras are really fun in this game, I like that the parasite is exposed immediately and that it requires precise aiming to expose them further. There is a request that involves fighting an even tougher gold one and man, that was absolutely sick. Iron Maidens have a bigger presence in this game which is kinda nice - they were very forgettable in OG in my opinion. 

My god, the shooting range in this game is absolutely incredible - it is flat out better than the original and the rewards are too, love the charms in this game. I honestly found it more fun than the main game. 

Obviously the game looks nice, not really all that impressed by a pretty game like this but it does deserve some props I guess. Music is nice too, but I like the original OST way more for its ambient tracks.

I like Mercenaries in this game, it is as close as I can get to playing a fun version of RE4R but it is also significantly easier than the main game which is not what I want. 

This game loses just about everything in its gameplay that made the original so snappy and enjoyable to replay. Leon doesn't move like a person, he just kinda staggers and limps everywhere even when he is not hurt - there was no need to add inertia to his movement especially when you've added a new mechanic where enemies you've downed can mutate where a prompt will pop up that allows you to kill them before that happens - I missed that a lot because Leon will stop 30 seconds after you let go of W, which leads to an enemy turning into a much more dangerous one because they thought it was a good idea to make Leon not move like a normal fucking human. 

Edit: Forgot to mention Separate Ways; it's a waste of fucking time lmao - It feels like a mod made by semi competent devs instead of an actual campaign expansion. Every room and arena feels lifeless and barren - U-3's arena sucks and the new second phase is ass - U-3 sucked in the original too so they stayed pretty faithful. There is hardly anything to say about it  other than the crossbow is cool, waow, what an accomplishment :/ - My save files for Separate Ways was the reason I couldn't load into any saves in a decent time, once I was able to nuke them from my PC, I was able to load into every single one of my saves in 5-10 seconds, incredible work from the team that brought us Resident Evil 3 Remake :)
‚ÄúIt's perfect. Perfect. Down to the last minute detail.‚Äù
Nice graphics and thrilling story

Never played the original, which I know is a crime, but this game is fantastic. Interesting story, cool characters, lots of stuff to collect, great graphics. I love the merchant and all the weapons you can get and upgrade. Plus, the shooting gallery is a lot of fun. I was a big fan of RE2 remake, and this game feels just as good if not better despite being a little more action/combat focused than 2. Combat feels nice and smooth. And lastly I have to say, if you're like me and getting a little burned out on every game being a massive open world these days (not to say those are bad), this is a very nice change of pace.

They made RE4 feel much more like a horror game than a cheesy action game with too many one-liners.  The lighting is great; the sound design is great; the environments are great; many sections are given more gameplay depth; the mechanics feel less janky than the original; the voice acting is hugely improved, especially from Ashley and Luis.  New Ashley makes you want to help her out of understanding her horrible situation and good intentions, not because you are required for your mission.  My only artistic gripes with the game are occasional where the original did 1 small scene or interaction slightly better than the remake, and for some reason Ada's voice acting just feels off.  On the whole, however, the remake improves basically every aspect of the original game.

My main dislike of the remake is honestly the shooting range sections--I think the shaky aim and bloom mechanics mesh horribly with a minigame centered around being a sharpshooter.  I also think the final fight against Saddler is too easy, and aspects of the Island area feel out of place in a resident evil game (although, same with the original game I guess).  The village and castle arcs were significantly stronger imo.

How do you Remake perfection? You can't, it's a literal impossibility, Nothing at humanities disposal can create something more perfect than perfection... My god they did it. They made this game even better than the original and you can see all the effort and care the devs put into this game. They knew they were handling very precious material and ensured that they would not fumble the outcome. This game is incredible everything has been improved upon. The graphics, the character design, the game play from movement to implementation of new mechanics, the gun play, they added new weapons, and a crafting system, they improved the level design, the story, and pacing, they improved the shooting gallery, and added key chains that give you buffs. There are new areas with new puzzles, new challenges that let you buy special items within the store. There is so much more. I am baffled at how they were truly able to improve upon an amazing game to the extent that they were able to produce such a masterful product that once again shocked the industry showing everyone how it's done when it comes to improving upon an already amazing product. If you play one game in this franchise, make sure it is this one.

Super good game

After Warcraft 3: Reforged I have been hesitant to approach remakes. This was the only one from the franchise where I had played the original game. Thankfully they not only honored it, they expanded and improved upon it. 

The graphics and combat are updated to modern standards with some additions. You have access to a parry, which allowed them to add more complexity to enemies and bosses. Most of the quick time events that frustrated me in the original were replaced with this.

Levels that dragged like the castle were trimmed, and others were expanded such as the lake area, which made for perfect pacing.

The escort sections are far less frustrating. Ashley no longer has a health bar, and you can call for her to stick to you or play more passive. She is also more self-reliant, no longer screaming at you to drop off ladders.

They shifted the tone to be more serious than the original. It works in some ways and not others. It complements the horror better, and characters such as Luis and Ashley are given more depth, but other characters such as Salazar feel out of place. I understand why the phone conversations were removed, but they needed to be replaced with something.

Most of the things I was sad were removed ended up being moved to the DLC, which is more fleshed out and enjoyable than the original. 

Rating: 9.5 / 10

I always saw the original Resident Evil 4 on nearly every YouTuber‚Äôs list of ‚Äúbest games ever made‚Äù or ‚Äúmost influential games of all time.‚Äù I was told it was a classic because it revolutionized the action-horror genre‚Äîwith its over-the-shoulder camera, intense combat, and smart enemy design. It struck a perfect balance between survival horror and fast-paced action, delivering a fresh experience that was both terrifying and incredibly fun.

While I never played the original, I now have finished this remake (still working through the DLC), and I can now fully understand the praise. The pacing, the action set pieces, the gunplay, and the atmosphere are some of the best I‚Äôve ever experienced in a game. The characters are beautiful and lovable‚ÄîAda, Ashley, and the absolute goat Luis totally won me over. And oh boy, Leon‚Äôs cockiness and those ridiculous backflips‚Äîit's such a joy to watch every cutscene. I fell in love with the game, and more than that, I‚Äôm now excited to try other Resident Evil titles too.

I've been waiting to play this game for quite some time, but at first glance, what surprised me was the graphic quality. They really excelled at it.
I like the movement and the mechanics they implemented, like the knife theme (I know many don't like it, but personally, I do). I've played Resident Evil 4 from 2004 quite a bit, and this new Resident Evil represents it very well. The cinematics are very well-animated and clean. You can feel Leon's emotions and way of thinking. Regarding Leon, his personality has changed. He went from being charismatic to more serious and depressed. I don't mind the change. I feel like I can identify with the character better because he's more "realistic."
Leon's campaign was pretty good. They removed some important things from the campaign, although some other mechanics returned in Ada's campaign, so it makes up for it a bit.
Mercenary mode is fun. I'm not a big fan of it, but I really liked the one in this game, so they did pretty well.
As for the DLC, I would only recommend buying the Treasure and Ada DLCs; I don't think the rest are worth it.
Overall, this is the best game of its kind I've played so far this year. Highly recommended if you like the series. 9.2/10

This game takes 2 things that I love most about games and puts them into 1. The first being that it's a story game with an actually good story, now story games are fun but with pretty much all of them it's hard for me to come back to them just because you feel like you've seen it, you've done it, the end. With this game it takes the second thing that I love about games and that's replayability. By getting achievements and playing the game good you get fun unlocks and cosmetics some that actually enhance your gameplay. (Ex: less damage taken, infinite ammo..) Overall this game is absolutely fantastic in terms of just about everything all around. To me it's worth it full price, (though it goes on sale for around 20 bucks sometimes.) Maybe not gold edition at full price because it's pretty much mostly cosmetics and of course the DLC, unless you want to collect those I'd rather get the gold edition on sale.

When I was a kid, RE4 pretty much disappointed me, but I didn't really understood why at the time. People that dislike the game usually say that there's too much B-Movie over the top action. And while it's true, Resident Evil always has been Action Horror to me (compared to Silent Hill).
In 2025, I just finished the Remake and even if I still don't like it that much, I think I know why.

First of all, RE4R IS a good game. It really is. Everything's fine and you should play it.

But today I know why something feels off with this game.
Resident Evil 1/2/3 were Action Horror games that played like a Horror game.
Resident Evil 4 and 5 are Action games that plays like a Horror game.

People usually dislike the 6th, I think it's a totally fine game in its own : at least the controls feels in line with what the game is trying to achieve (Combat / Action). In RE4, the game plays like a Survival Horror (with heavy and clumsy controls) while trying REALLY HARD to be a 3rd Person pure action game.

In 2025, RE4R feels SO CLUMSY, SO outdated when it comes to that it hurts. Took me at least 2 hours to get used to the controls. 

Still, RE4R is a very enjoyable game, very close to the original, so you'll be happy to revisit this spanish swamp if you loved it when you were young... or discovering it if you missed it.

And now, go play Silent Hill 2 Remake.

Finally got around to the Resident Evil 4 Remake on my chronological playthrough, and wow! The original was too hard for me as a kid, but this remaster is easily top 3 RE games for me. The community's praise for this game is spot on.

Everything about it hooks you: the sound, graphics, and story. Even on standard, it's a solid challenge that tests your resource management. Leon and especially Ada Wong's character models are phenomenal, a big step up from RE2 and the OG RE4

The Separate Ways DLC is fantastic playing as Ada truly completes Leon's story and feels like a main game in itself. It's essential for anyone wanting to see the full picture, and its ending just makes you want more RE!
