This remake does a lot of things well : 
+ Makes the story more coherent (with some mishaps).
+ Makes some characters much better (Ashley/Luis).
+ Changes the original game enough for veteran players to be invested and enjoy going through the new, or redesigned areas.
+ Does a mostly excellent job at modernizing the most antiquated parts of the original (shortcuts for weapons, making the different parasites more interesting gameplay-wise, removing most of the annoying QTEs).
+ Some story beats and character interactions, especially between Leon and Ashley, are a vast improvement.
+ Adds a few interesting gameplay mechanics (parry mostly).
+ Is a good-looking game.
+ Pretty much every boss fight is better.
+ Some voice actors do a marvelous job (Ashely, Luis), some do a pretty good job (Leon, Mike, Salazar, Saddler in boss mode).

But if you enjoyed the original game in the higher difficulties, I think you'll rapidly identify the massive downgrades and downright incomprehensible gameplay design choices the devs made. I finished the game in Hardcore after around 20 hours of playtime, and I'm burned out: I'm not even sure I'll make a Professional run. I'll try to identify the issues:
- The shooting feels terrible. Instead of the good old laser pointer, you mostly get crosshairs in the game, that grow wider when Leon moves as he aims, but also when you simply move the mouse around when aiming, meaning you have to stay entirely still to get them to focus. This is entirely inexplicable, and causes a good amount of shots to whiff because of RNG.
- Leon moves like a tank. I kinda understand that with the modern, shoot-and-move style they adopted in this remake, they couldn't make him too fast. However, he's extremely slow and feels clumsy, which is massively frustrating when you want him to get out of the way. Each time he gets hit, he stumbles around forever, leading you to often get hit from another source after recovering.
- Enemies don't consistently stagger. In original RE4, when you shot an enemy in the head (or leg), it triggered a stagger that allowed you to melee him. Now, in the original, this was extremely reliable, and, true enough, could make the gameplay a little stale after a while (headshot-melee-repeat). I don't mind the decision to make it harder to trigger the melee-able state of enemies, but the way the remake took to do so seems to be RNG, especially on higher difficulties. I've often found myself headshotting a guy repeatedly, waiting for him to stagger, and he just ate three handgun bullets to the face without even wincing. Worse, it appeared to me that even light stumbling (enemy getting stopped in his tracks when taking a shot) followed the same principle. That makes the game extremely frustrating: for instance, some enemies that can kill you with one attack are sometimes staggered by shotgun headshots (allowing you to melee them), sometimes simply stumble (giving you the option to run away), and sometimes... just keep moving or attacking as if nothing happened.
- The ammo economy feels terrible. The game showers you with handgun ammunition, and introduces an utterly crappy crafting system that replaces the natural flow of various types of ammunition being granted by the game. In the end (at least on Hardcore), you'll find yourself using your handgun 70% of the time, constantly annoyed by its unreliable nature when trying to stagger or stumble enemies.
- The game offers you ways to parry (with the knife key) or dodge (with the crouch key) certain attacks. However, the option to do so only appears on the bottom right of your HUD, with a very little, unremarkable pop-up, leaving you in the dark about how you're supposed to survive one attack. For instance, if a villager comes at you with an axe, should you parry (knife key) or dodge (crouch key)? You won't be able to glimpse at the tooltip, and end up trying one key or the other randomly. Are you supposed to learn every attack's counter by heart? It makes no sense, especially since the tooltip for the staggered state allowing you to perform a melee attack on enemies is huge, appears on the enemy from a long distance, and even tells you which button (melee move, or knife stab) you're supposed to use.
- The AI is stuck in a weird limbo: it's mostly more aggressive and in-your-face, while keeping the goofy "standing around and waiting for my turn to attack" that this kind of game requires to prevent the player from getting stun-locked or combo-ed into oblivion. However, I ended up getting stun-locked and combo-ed into oblivion much more frequently than in the original game, where it happened rarely. Ashley is also much more frustrating, as you can't tell her to wait somewhere, a clear downgrade from the original.

=> These are my main issues with the gameplay. It's a typical case of blatant disregard for the good old: "if it works, don't mess with it". Ammo economy was fine in the original game. Laser pointer aiming was fine. Stagger and stumbling were fine, and the melee option being reliably offered to the player was fine too. The feeling of consistency when your actions produced the expected results, depending on the choices you made, were fine. Now granted, the remake did grant the player with some new options that allowed Leon to be much stronger, mainly: better maniability (although moving him around feels terrible) and the ability to move and shoot or reload, knife parries, dodges. Balancing the game around that was possible, by making the enemies more numerous, aggressive and accurate, or even by making them tankier and making melee attacks deal less damage to them. The devs decided to do some of that (making the enemies more aggressive), but in the same move, they also opted to introduce RNG mechanics robbing you of your sense of agency when trying to make enemies stumble, to have Leon stumble endlessly when hit, or to make the player shoot inaccurately because of unavoidable RNG, while making every ammo type but the handgun's a rarety. 
In the original RE4, I remember making a run with only the knife and the unupgraded basic handgun in Professional. I wouldn't even consider it with this game, because the gameplay isn't fun, which is why I don't recommend it.
EDIT : With mods, the game is much more enjoyable, as you can easily get ones to incorporate the original RE4 stagger mechanics into the remake, and fix most of the aiming issues. I'm still not recommending the remake because mods are supposed to increase your enjoyment of a game, not fix bad design decisions.

Now, I'll end up with other negative points that are less overwhelming:
- They tried to make the story more grounded and less cheesy. This works sometimes, but is mostly a vain endeavour because the basis and the main beats of the story are ludicrous. In the end, the game feels uncertain about its tone. 
- The script is downright terrible and uninspired for some characters (Ada, Bitores Mendez, Saddler in human form, Krauser). 
- Some voice actors do an unremarkable, boring job (Saddler in regular form, Hunnigan), some do a bad job (Krauser, Bitores Mendez), some do an immersion-breaking, atrocious job (Ada). 
- The merchant won't shut up.
- The bolt thrower is a boring, terrible weapon.
- The difficulty is somewhat inconsistent. 
- Some sceneries are uninspired and generic (edgy "blood and animal sacrifices everywhere"), they don't recapture the feeling of the original (some parts of the village, mostly).
- Some puzzles (actually, a couple of the same design) are utter time-wasting trash.
- Some fun content from the original game was cut.
- Maybe a nitpick, but Leon's stances are just much less cool than in the original game. For instance, in RE4, Leon held his handgun up high, always ready to draw and shoot. Now, after running for a tiny bit, he adopts a limp-wristed state that just feels odd.
- Can't turn on the flashlight outside of scripted parts.

Even years after this game came out, I still occasionally just stop and think about how I cannot believe they managed to not only meet but in my opinion go above and beyond the absolutely monumental expectations that I had for this remake. I thought there was absolutely no chance they would be able to capture lightning in a bottle twice but somehow they completely reinvented my favorite game and managed to expand on it in ways that made me love it even more. Characters like Louis and Ashley have been vastly improved and the tweaks made to combat makes this by far the best feeling RE game to date. It's crazy how this game can make you feel like John Wick one moment but the next make you feel like a scared little baby running away from dummy thicc lab monsters. 10/10.

They took one of the greatest video games that didn't need a remake, and made an incredible remake. Gameplay, characters, story, graphics are all adapted very faithfully, with enough variation for this game to truly stand out despite the quality of the original. The parry system is an excellent addition, the game's story is largely improved with standout moments and characters like Luis, whilst keeping much of the original's lovable campiness in tact. 

My one big issue is the enemy AI on Hardcore+ difficulties. It took a lot of adjustment to get used to the fact that headshots no longer instantly stagger an enemy, which made combat feel clunkier and less refined than it did in the original. 

Despite this and some small issues like the way the game handles its DLC, making Seperate Ways a paid addition compared to the free expansion in later releases of the original, the game succeeds in every manner it should.

I haven't made it too far yet, but I'm having a great time. I still think the RE2 remake is my favourite, but I can definitely see why this game (and the original) have such a strong following. It's definitely not what I would call "survival horror", since it is way more action packed and you collect ammo constantly, but as far as "action" horror or "panic" horror go it certainly ticks all the boxes. You have to manage the enemies and your surroundings carefully, or you can easily get overwhelmed. Leon is a tough dude but even with his action movie hero levels of toughness, taking axe wounds to the shoulder and still firing off an entire clip afterwards, you will die a few times if you haven't played before. Or at least I did.

The game might seem a bit laughable at first if you came from the other remakes, particularly RE2. Where in that game it made sense that you would find some 10mm ammo laying around, since you start in a police station, here you have to suspend your disbelief a bit as you collect seemingly endless amounts of bullets and gunpowder from farm houses and pensioners with pitchforks. And that also takes you back at first, charging around with your custom handgun blowing the heads off old women, rather than carefully navigating eerie corridors and trying to avoid attention from gross looking zombies.

But honestly, it doesn't matter, because this is a totally different type of game and it does it so well. I am only in the third chapter and I am having so much fun with it. Fighting off chainsaw dudes, a chunky boy with a cow head, gangs of crippled old women coming at me like I just cancelled bingo night. Of course it's ridiculous, but then this is a world where zombie monsters took over an entire city and the government decided to blow it off the face of the planet.... it seems sort of natural that the series went in this direction. If you played RE3 then you can easily see the transition, especially by the end of that game.

Anyway, highly recommended. Do play.

It's a remake of one of the greatest games of all time, and a fine example of what a remake should be- Taking all the things that were great about the original, sprucing them up, and adding a little bit of extra spice to keep things interesting. If you enjoyed the original, there's plenty of reason to come back and play this one. And if you never got the chance to play the original, this is a great, definitive way to experience RE 4. That isn't to say it's perfect. I miss the original's voice acting as well as some of the lines that were changed from the first release, but it is still overall a fantastic game and a standout title among the Resident Evil series. You can argue which is the best game in the series, but I don't think you can say there's a better game in this series. Equal, yes. Better, no. I wish Capcom would extend this kind of care, level of polish and detail to some of their other series. I'm glad they did right by this one, at least.

I still own my old copy of Resident Evil 4 on Gamecube. I remember really enjoying the game and finishing it. It's been a long time, so when I saw RE4 remake on sale, I knew I had to pick it up.

This game is as good as I remember. The zones are dark and atmospheric and some areas genuinely distilled a sense of dread in me. The sound design is phenomenal. Cows moan, crows caw and the trees blowing in the wind rustle in the background. There is a great ambience to make the world feel real and threatening. The Las Plaga enemies are a great addition to the game. Headshots are not always rewarding as tentacled horrors emerge from decapitated enemies. Later enemies like the Regenerators slither and slide along the ground in an unnerving, unnatural way.

 Leon is a great leading man. Cool, calm, collected and when his arsenal is built up, he feels like a juggernaut. Men want to be Leon. Women want to be with him. Happy to hear he'll be back for RE9.

This game is highly recommended. The only downside to RE4 is the fact the Ada Wong missions that explain more about her motivations are a seperate purchase. I will get it. I want more RE4. I want to see more of the story and how it connects to RE5. It's just a shame it's not included with the base game.

Resident Evil 4 is not just a game to me. It is a piece of my soul. It is the heartbeat of my gaming identity. It is the moment my relationship with video games changed forever. Before Resident Evil 4, I played games for fun, for distraction, for a way to kill time. But after it, I realized games could be so much more. They could be transformative. They could be unforgettable. They could touch something deep inside you that you didn‚Äôt even know was there.

The first time I launched the game, I wasn‚Äôt expecting much. I had heard it was good, sure, but nothing could have prepared me for what I was about to experience. That opening village encounter hit like a freight train. I remember standing there, controller in hand, heart racing, surrounded by enemies closing in, and thinking to myself, ‚ÄúThis is not just a game. This is survival. This is war. This is art.‚Äù The fear was real. The panic was real. The desperation was real. And somehow, in the middle of all that chaos, I felt more alive than I had in months.

I became obsessed. Every corner I turned, every building I entered, every enemy I encountered added to the story I was building in my mind and in my heart. I was not just watching Leon Kennedy. I was with him. I was him. His journey became mine. His pain, his determination, his strength, his struggle, I felt it all. It was not just about rescuing Ashley or taking down Los Illuminados. It was about pushing forward no matter how bad things got. It was about holding on to hope in the face of absolute madness. It was about never giving up, even when the whole world wanted you dead.

The gameplay was revolutionary, but it was more than just mechanics. The way it made me feel in control, the weight of every bullet, the decision to fight or flee, the risk of reloading mid-combat, the satisfaction of a perfectly timed grenade, it all built this beautiful tension that never let go. And that inventory system. I loved managing my attache case like it was a puzzle within a puzzle. Organizing weapons and healing items wasn‚Äôt a chore. It was a ritual. A preparation for the unknown horrors that always lurked ahead.

The world of Resident Evil 4 felt so rich, so detailed, so alive in the most horrifying way possible. The fog-covered village, the grotesque castle, the cold and unforgiving island, each area had its own personality, its own mood, its own nightmares. The game never let me rest. Every time I thought I was safe, it threw something else at me. A chainsaw-wielding maniac. A room full of cultists. A regenerador breathing just around the corner. I was always on edge. But I wanted to be. I craved that feeling. Because that‚Äôs what the game does. It makes you feel like you are constantly dancing on the edge of disaster, and somehow that dance becomes a thrill you never want to end.

And then there‚Äôs Leon. Leon S. Kennedy became a symbol for me. Not just because he was cool or funny or badass. But because he was resilient. No matter what was thrown at him, he stood tall. He pushed through. He made hard decisions. He never gave up. In some strange way, he became a source of strength for me in my own life. Whenever I was dealing with something tough, I would remember the way Leon kept going, through hell, through pain, through monsters both literal and metaphorical. And I would think, if he can make it, so can I.

The supporting characters only added to that emotional depth. Luis, with his charm and secrets, left a mark on me that I wasn‚Äôt expecting. His sacrifice hurt more than I ever anticipated. Ashley may have frustrated players at times, but I saw her as a symbol of innocence trapped in a world of evil, and protecting her gave me purpose. Even the villains were unforgettable. Salazar, with his twisted arrogance. Krauser, with his personal vendetta. Saddler, with his cult-like manipulation. They weren‚Äôt just enemies. They were forces to be reckoned with. They were obstacles I had to overcome not just in the game, but in myself.

And the Merchant. What can I say. ‚ÄúWhat are ya buyin?‚Äù became a phrase etched into gaming history. But to me, it was more than a catchphrase. It was a brief moment of relief. A reminder that amidst the chaos, I had a friend. A strange one, sure, but a constant presence who somehow made me feel safe, even in the darkest parts of the world.

Resident Evil 4 did something few games ever do. It stayed with me. Long after I turned it off. Long after I finished it. Long after I played it again. And again. And again. It‚Äôs been years, and I still think about it. I still remember specific encounters. Specific sounds. Specific lines of dialogue. I still dream of those eerie hallways, those desperate boss fights, those close calls that made me jump out of my seat. And I remember how I felt. The intensity. The adrenaline. The triumph. The awe.

This game changed how I view horror. How I view storytelling. How I view perseverance. How I view gaming as a whole. It is not just a masterpiece. It is the masterpiece. The one I hold above all others. The one that reminds me why I fell in love with games in the first place. The one that reminds me who I am.

Resident Evil 4 is more than a classic. It is more than a survival horror benchmark. It is a legend. And for me, it is sacred.

If I could relive the experience of playing it for the first time, I would. A hundred times over. Because in that moment, I wasn‚Äôt just playing a game.

I was discovering a part of myself I didn‚Äôt know I was missing.

And I will carry that with me for the rest of my life.

So how would describe this game? Resident evil 4 (original) was a masterpiece for it's time, now this game took that masterpiece and expanded it, giving characters more background and personality. 
One thing people hated about the original was Ashley being pretty much annoying, she is more tolerable in the remake and more helpful, she also now lacks a health bar so a lot less to worry about, if she's knocked down, you just have to help her to her feet now.

Let's talk bosses, very well done, a lot more terrifying than the original, but with del Lago, the Easter egg was toned down, that is my only complaint.

Let cycle back to Ashley again, there is a segment in the original where she must navigate an area and use gas torches to attack enemies, in the remake however, you now use a single lantern and can briefly stun enemies with it, the area is also near enough pitch black making it more difficult and scary.

Ada in this game has got more of a part with Leon, helping him a little more and even shows signs of remorse towards the end of the game.

Leon was perfectly done, they kept the sarcasm and his cocky nature but kept it to a level that didn't seem like he was trying too hard.

The enemies come in many styles and have a more dangerous role in the game, they can now grab the player and hold him in place for other enemies to 1 shot him, but you can still use a knife and melee combat against them.

Quick time events have been toned to combat and not at random cutscenes, I prefer this personally.

The location was impressive, they kept as much of the original location as possible and upgraded it, adding new routes and traps for the player.

The merchant has a great role in the game as he did with the original, but now you cannot shoot him which does make sense as he is essentially part of your alliance, he has all the same weapons from the original but a couple of extras.

Speaking of the merchant, in the original you had to shoot 10 medallions and you'd earn a free gun, while this mechanic is still preset, it is expends into little side quests the merchant gives you, in exchange for spindles, which you can the trade for exclusive items.

All in all, this game was definitely in line for game of the year.

Resident Evil 4 Remake is, without a doubt, a masterful reimagining. It successfully preserves the core essence of the original masterpiece while injecting new life into it with modern graphics and refined gameplay.

Visuals and Atmosphere
The game's visuals have reached new heights, boasting incredible detail. Every dimly lit village, eerie castle, and damp underground area is rendered beautifully, significantly amplifying the game's horror atmosphere. The lighting effects and character models are also impeccable, making the entire game world feel more believable and immersive.

Gameplay Experience
Capcom has optimized the controls in the remake, making aiming and movement much smoother and more fluid. Modernized Quick Time Events (QTEs) also make combat more intense and thrilling. The classic melee attacks and knife parry mechanics from the original have been retained and enhanced, adding more strategic depth to combat encounters. Resource management remains a core element, with every decision about ammo and herbs testing the player's wisdom.

Story and Characters
The story largely stays true to the original, with Leon's search for the President's daughter, Ashley, remaining as gripping as ever. While some minor tweaks have been made to the plot, the overall pacing is tighter, and character development feels more nuanced. The return of classic characters, in particular, will be a welcome sight for long-time fans.

Minor Gripes
Despite the remake's outstanding performance, there are a couple of minor points. For instance, some areas can feel a bit repetitive, and the later stages of the game might tire some players out. Additionally, for players seeking a purely horror-driven experience, the remake might feel slightly less terrifying in certain aspects, leaning more towards action-shooter mechanics.

Final Verdict
All in all, Resident Evil 4 Remake is a must-play. Whether you're a long-time fan of the series or new to the world of Resident Evil, you're guaranteed to have a top-tier survival horror experience. It's not just a successful remake; it's a brilliant game that will immerse you in a thrilling adventure. Highly recommended!

Resident Evil 4 has always been my favorite game in the series thanks to its atmosphere and gameplay, so I‚Äôm really glad that the remake did not disappoint me.

Resident Evil 4 Remake truly impressed me with its tense atmosphere and action-packed gameplay. The graphics are stunning and do a fantastic job of enhancing the game‚Äôs dark, oppressive atmosphere. The lighting especially adds to the tension, making the experience even more immersive. When it comes to action, I‚Äôve always loved the pacing of Resident Evil games, and this remake is no exception. The addition of the parry mechanic with the knife is a brilliant change‚Äîit‚Äôs useful, satisfying to use, and became something I relied on constantly throughout my playthrough.

One of the most intense moments for me was the iconic village sequence. From the second you enter the village, everyone comes after you, and you have no idea how long you need to survive or where to go as you scramble around trying to stay alive. The endless waves of enemies created a constant sense of panic, and those moments were both terrifying and incredibly exciting for me.

However, there were a few aspects of the game that didn‚Äôt work for me. In the last three chapters, especially on the island and in the laboratory sections, the difficulty felt unnecessarily ramped up. Enemies that just wouldn‚Äôt die and endless enemy waves, along with the Regenerador appearing in random places seemingly just to increase difficulty, made parts of the game feel frustrating. There were even moments where I found myself just wanting the game to end. Other than these moments, though, I can confidently say there‚Äôs nothing else I found lacking in this game.

Overall, Resident Evil 4 Remake is a highly successful remake with its atmosphere, visuals, and action-packed gameplay. While the unnecessary difficulty spike in the final sections might be a downside for some players, it‚Äôs definitely not a reason to skip this game.

Score: 9/10

The remakes of the Resident Evil series in this RE game engine are truly amazing. I hope one day that the first can be remade in the same engine and we see 5&6 soon added so I may play them in their best forms. This game is also (of the remakes that I have played) where they go from SURVIVAL horror to ACTION horror. They definitely learned from 3 having a lot cut (I think for S rank you have to beat the game in under 2 HOURS which is crazy) to keeping in the full experience. I had about 16 hours into my FIRST hardcore playthrough and I found it so fun I want to do the new game plus when I finish 7&8. The action part is well done, even if at times I did find some parts annoying, I enjoyed it thoroughly. 

I highly recommend if you play any Resident Evil games however, you should 100% play 2&4. 3 isn't necessarily bad but it doesn't diminish the experience if you skip it and I believe that those 2 are the ones of the remakes that are 100% worth a spot in your steam library.

Its okay I guess.  It's weird to me that RE4 is the game held up as he gold standard for the franchise meanwhile pretty much all the other ones were all horror leaning.  And what did the lessons from RE4 get us?  5-6 some of the worst.  Also I was lead to believe that the original was really camp and funny and that they toned it down for the remake.  Why?  The stuff in there could be funny but its just sorta not.

The heavy arena style combat kills the horror vibes.  The escort stuff is fine but weirdly intermittent.  Oh and the loot is terrible.

The loot is run by an algorithm and rng based.  While you'll rarely get truly low on anything you need you similarly will never really be given the chance to get ahead.  At one point I had like 8 parts and no gunpowder to make anything with.  Did you want to make a meaningful amount of magnum ammo?  Prepare to wait a million years to do it.

But fine. The REmake team at Capcom is devastatingly effective at its job. The game looks great functions pretty well and other than sandblasting off some of the personality from the original did a good job with this one as it has with the others.

It is my least favorite of the good Resident Evils.  But it is a good Resident Evil

I've been a huge fan of the 2005 version, and replayed it maybe a dozen times.  After putting some time into this version, I can say that I really enjoyed it as a game in its own right and also loved going along and seeing how the remake is different.  At first I wasn't a huge fan of the knife durability and the changed aiming reticle in the remake, but I soon adjusted to them and accepted them as part of the combat system.  The aiming especially seems to be a way to trade off for the increased mobility that you have in the remake, as you can only get max accuracy by standing completely still.  

The atmosphere is great, especially if you're in a dark room with headphones.  Fans of the original RE games may consider this one too easy and action oriented, but the resource management helps provide tension to the action, at least in the first playthrough or in a professional run.   Trying out the different guns is great, as they each have specific characteristics and a unique upgrade.  

tl;dr-This game is a lot of fun.  Mercenaries mode is fun, and Separate Ways is worth it.

Resident Evil 4 Remake is everything a remake should be: faithful, modern, and absolutely unforgettable. Capcom somehow managed to improve one of the most iconic games of all time without losing its soul. The visuals are jaw-dropping ‚Äî environments are darker, more detailed, and dripping with atmosphere. Every village, castle, and lab area feels reimagined with care, yet instantly recognizable to fans. Combat is tighter and more responsive, with smarter enemy AI and satisfying gunplay that rewards accuracy and planning. Knife parries are a game-changer ‚Äî adding layers of strategy without overcomplicating things. Leon‚Äôs character is fleshed out just enough to feel more human, but he still drops just the right amount of one-liners. The new side quests and expanded character moments (like Luis and Ashley) are surprisingly solid additions that feel earned, not forced. Boss fights hit harder, the pacing is excellent, and the soundtrack has been completely revitalized without losing its creepy charm. If you played the original, this remake will blow you away with its respect and polish. If you‚Äôre new to RE4 ‚Äî you‚Äôre playing survival horror at its absolute peak. No fluff, no filler, just an expertly crafted experience from start to finish.
As Always Great Game By CAPCOM

If you've played the original, this is still worth the time. 

The maps are tweaked and resized for the better. The placement of events are tweaked to feel more fresh. There's also some completely new events. Enemies are more aggressive and believable. Treasures are reworked to make combining pieces more flexible. There are more weapon types and sub objectives.

The knife has been totally revamped: some will hate that it breaks, but you also do so much more with knives now. It feels like an improvement on Shivs from the original The Last of Us and I'm loving it. There's several quality of life improvements. The game is not just prettier, but new rendering tech has led to improving on an old puzzle (I can't wait to see more of this).

This remake feels like such a unique experience in it's own right. I'll edit this review accordingly if this doesn't hold up for the rest of the experience (only 4+ hours in currently).

Resi 4 remake is my favorite so far out of the franchise and the separate ways dlc is the cherry on top. I really enjoyed it. Such a video-gamey video game packed with action. The combat is very fun, I had a blast with it and the game looks sooo good. In the dlc, I gasped at Ada's zip-zap grappling gun the first time I saw it in action. The grappling animation is so cool and the feature itself added a lot to the dlc in my opinion, thus making it very fun. Moreover, the fact that you get to pull shields away from enemies as Ada if you wish to use the charm that enables it, is another feature that I enjoyed. The dlc was just as fun as the main game, going through it as Ada was its own kind of special. Impressive. Highly recommend.

Resident Evil 4 Remake was exactly what I imagined it would be and even more. Capcom has done an incredible job of taking a real classic and giving it a new look, without losing the essence of the original. The visuals are sensational, with incredible graphics and lighting that really makes everything darker and more immersive. The forest, the castle, the village - everything is perfect, really. The gameplay has also changed completely for the better: you can now move around while shooting, use the machete more freely. The combats have become more varied, and you can still feel the tension of facing those hordes of Ganados in the same way as always, only now more immersive and fun. The bosses are still striking, and the improvements to the battles have made everything more dynamic, much cooler. The story has been deepened, the characters now have more personality - Ashley is more useful, Luiz appears more, and even Krauser has become more interesting. The pace of the game is perfect, the dialog feels more natural, and the voice acting is sensational. Without a doubt, one of the best remakes ever made.
